cs_en: Petr Čech: A last-minute move?
Everything is possible
Today is the last day when you can still jump through the transfer window and make a big transition.
Another chance will come in the winter.
Petr Čech, currently Chelsea's substitute goalkeeper, does not currently have a new professional contract in Madrid, Monaco or Paris.

He is sitting in the funny NH Hotel, talking to Czech journalists and preparing with the Czech delegation for the game general with the Americans and then also for the sharp start of the qualification for Euro 2016 against the Netherlands.
Chelsea goalkeeper Thibaut Courtois takes the lead in the Premier League for the first time in ten years.
It was previously speculated that Real Madrid might be interested in Czechoslovakia.
He lost the Spanish Super Cup to Atlétik at the start of the season and did not manage to enter the league season, losing 2–4 to San Sebastián.
There was also speculation about the interest of Paris SG.
He scored two goals and two rebounds during the French League season and shot St. Etienne 5–0 on Sunday.
The club AS Monaco's shoes are the most pressured relatively.
He had a 1–2 record in the league and was defeated by Lille 1–1 on the weekend.
The news that Czechs might want to play in Queens Park Rangers has leaked on the English tabloid websites today.
According to English bookmakers, however, Czech's departure from Chelsea at the last minute is not too likely.
Skybet gave him a 4:1 pass.
Peter, is it possible you'll change your jersey in the next few hours?
I'm not counting on that, but there's never anything 100 percent in football.
Maybe during the day there'll be an offer that won't be rejected.
What would such an offer have to look like?
(Laughter) "Well, I don't know how an offer that can't be rejected actually looks.
All sides must agree First of all, it would be up to Chelsea to decide whether or not to deal with a possible offer.
Is it technically feasible to make such a transfer when you are in Prague?
Wouldn't it be necessary for you to sign a possible new contract somewhere in the new site?
I didn't think about it that much.
But in such a situation there are a lot of players today, they're all somewhere at the representative meetings and there's certainly still a lot of transfers to close today.
So it would certainly be feasible somehow.
How many clubs on the planet can afford you?
I really don't know.
So you don't push to leave?
The situation that I didn't catch in the first three games of the new season is new to me after fifteen years of career.
However, there is no reason to panic, pack up and go somewhere.
I want to continue to participate in Chelsea's goalie competition, and it's up to the coach who chooses to make the decisions over the next few weeks.
What role does the family play in your decision making?
I take all the factors into account.
Of course, the sporting aspect is important to me, but I also look at it from a personal point of view, to which the needs of the family of course belong.
Is it possible that you'd be caught for another club in England?
That's the question I thought would never concern me.
But in football, everything is possible.
I don't want to exclude anything.
I don't know the answer.
Prime Ministers of India and Japan to meet in Tokyo

The new Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi is in Tokyo to meet with his Japanese counterpart Shinzo Abe. On his first major visit since his May election victory, he is to discuss economic and security commitments.
Modi is on a five-day trip to Japan to strengthen economic ties with the world's third largest economy.
The list includes, first and foremost, plans for more extensive cooperation in the field of nuclear energy.
According to reporters, India also hopes that both nations will agree to cooperate on defence issues.
Police arrest a 20-year-old young man after a motorcycle chase in Karrat
The motorcycle was stopped after travelling at 125 km/h in a zone with a maximum permitted speed of 70 km/h and crashed into a bush to escape the police.
In the morning of Karrata, the traffic police tried to stop the blue motorcycle by the side of the road when they noticed it was going 125 km/h when exiting the petrol station on Bathgate Road.
According to police, the driver did not stop and continued on Burgess Road, then turned into a bush, so the police lost him from sight.
The motorcycle and the person who was in the driver's description were then seen at a house on Walcott Way in Bulgaria.
Karrath police accused the twenty-year-old of failing to comply with the call for a stop and of negligently conducting the proceedings.
He'll be on trial in Karachi on September 23.
The motorcycle was seized for three months.
George Webster accused of rape at hotels in Nairn and Pitlochry
The man will be tried on charges of raping women in two hotels.
George Webster, 28, was convicted during a hearing at the Glasgow Supreme Court.
He allegedly raped a woman on 7 June 2013 at Scotland's Hotel in Pitlochry, Perthshire.
Webster allegedly attacked her while "she was unconscious, asleep, and unable to give her consent."
Webster is also charged with raping another woman at the Golf View Hotel in Nairn, Scotland, on 4 May 2014.
Judge Lady Rae has set the date for the transfer to the Edinburgh Supreme Court on 17 November.
Restoring the very American ideal that labor rights are human rights at the same time
Congressmen Keith Ellison and John Lewis have proposed a law to protect trade union organizations as a civil right.
“Depending on how the trade unions work, there are middle-class jobs,” says Ellison, a Democrat Senator for Minnesota who co-chairs the Congressional Committee.
That's why I'm so proud to be able, together with John Lewis, the model of occasional rights, to introduce a law that strengthens the position of employees.

This breakthrough legislation will give workers the same legal options as to prevent discrimination in trade union organisation as in other forms of discrimination - and will stop anti-community forces

Amendment of the Labour Relations Act to enable all employees facing discrimination, if they wish to join trade unions, to take legal action before a civil court - and to order compensation or damages - is the right and necessary initiative.
But it's certainly not a radical initiative - at least not by American standards.
The best way to understand what Ellison, Lewis, and other legislators are proposing is to re-establish the American ideal.

Despite the trade union struggles that have taken place in recent years - in Wisconsin, Michigan, and other states - Americans once supported countries around the world in accepting, expanding, and respecting labour rights.
There were times, and millions of Americans still remember them, when the country, in one breath, championed democracy, freedom of speech, freedom of the press, and the right to assembly.

When the United States occupied Japan after World War II, General Douglas MacArthur and his advisers supported the country in adopting a constitution designed to ensure that Hideki Toja's military autocracy was replaced by democracy.

They believed that employees and their trade unions played a role in shaping the new Japan, included language and openly recognised that “the right of employees to gather, negotiate and act collectively is guaranteed.”

When the United States occupied Germany after World War II, General Dwight David Eisenhower and his advisers chose the Germans to create a constitution that would ensure that Adolf Hitler's fascism would be replaced by a strong democracy.

The Germans realised that workers in the new nation would need to be organised and promoted, and therefore included a clause that openly states: "The right to create societies that will safeguard and improve working and economic conditions will be guaranteed to every individual and to every occupation or profession.
Any arrangements that will restrict or attempt to damage this right will be repealed. The measures leading to the achievement of such a purpose are illegal.

When former First Lady Eleanor Roosevelt chaired the International Commission on Human Rights, which proposed the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, which was adopted by the United Nations in 1948 as a global treaty, the sponsors included it, and Roosevelt guaranteed that “everybody has the right to form and join trade unions in the protection of their interests.”
For generations, Americans have accepted the basic premise that labor rights are human rights.

When the country advised other countries how to create civil and democratic society, Americans explained that the right to create trade unions – and their participation in collective bargaining with firms and government agencies as equal partners – must be protected.

Now that these rights are being challenged in America, it is absolutely necessary to return to the American ideal that working people must have the right to organize and promote themselves in a free and open society.
As Reverend Martin Luther King, Jr. said fifty years ago:
History is a great teacher.
Today everyone knows that the trade unions have not reduced the power of the nation, but have expanded it.
They raised the standard of living of millions of people, created a market for industry and raised production to untouched levels.
Those who attack the trade unions forget these simple truths, but history remembers them.
History does not forget, and we shouldn't either.
The formal recognition of labour rights as human rights - and the extension of the protection of civil rights to prevent discrimination in the organisation of trade unions - is long overdue.
Keith Ellison and John Lewis are re-establishing the ideals that lifted America and made it a true promise of democracy.
The judge temporarily blocked a law that could close all abortion clinics in Louisiana
A federal judge on Sunday temporarily blocked a Louisiana law that lawyers say would probably shut down all five abortion clinics in the state.

The regulation, signed by Louisia Governor Bobby Jindal in June and due to enter into force on 1 September, would require abortion doctors to have the right to receive a patient in a hospital within 30 miles of their practice.
The Judge's order means that doctors may temporarily continue to carry out legal abortions and must, in the meantime, obtain this authorisation.
"The proposed party will be able to carry out its activities legally and, in the meantime, obtain a permit," stated Federal Judge John deGravelles.
The hearing will be scheduled within one month so that the judge can issue a more permanent resolution on the law.
The abortion rights activists welcomed the resolution, which is the last in a series of similar measures, saying it will give doctors more time to obtain permission.

“Today’s decision ensures that women in Louisiana will be safe from the insane law that is threatening their health and their rights,” said Nancy Northup, President and Executive Director of the Reproductive Rights Centre, who has filed a lawsuit to block the law on behalf of three out of five clinics.
It was not immediately clear whether the decision concerned doctors from two clinics which were not among the defendants and also applied for that authorisation.
Louisiana is among the eleven states that have passed similar laws, with courts in Alabama and Mississippi declaring such measures unconstitutional.
Key parts of the Texas law that would close most of the remaining clinics in the state were blocked by federal judges on Friday.

Fighters for the rights of women to abortion, together with the Association of American Obstetricians and Gynecologists and the American Medical Association, argue that the need for this authorisation places medical requirements on doctors that are not necessary from a medical point of view.
Opponents of abortion opposed the measures aimed at protecting women's health and some also welcomed the fact that clinics would be closed because of the measures.
The Centre for Reproductive Rights stated that in Louisiana there is only one authorised doctor carrying out abortions.
If all doctors in the state were forced to stop performing abortions, this doctor would also stop performing the procedure for fear of his safety, the group said.
In response, the Louisiana authorities stated that they would not stop doctors performing abortions while waiting for a claim to be granted rights.
Rural ovarian cancer kills more frequently due to late diagnosis and poor availability of treatment
Angelina Jolie and her brother James released a video holding their deceased mother, who died of ovarian cancer in 2007.
Women in rural Australia are more likely to die of ovarian cancer than their urban counterparts.
Researchers analysed the medical records of more than 1,100 Australian women diagnosed with ovarian cancer in 2005 and found that only 35% lived five years after diagnosis.

Research Director Susan Jordan of the QIMR Berghofer Medical Research Institute said that women in rural and remote areas of the country were about 20 percent more likely to die during the study than women in urban areas.
STUDY: New drugs can slow lung and ovarian cancer
Researchers followed the woman for seven years of treatment.
Dr. Jordan said the chances of survival were influenced by women's age at the time of diagnosis, type of ovarian cancer, other existing diseases, and socio-economic status.
The lowest survival rate occurred in older women diagnosed with advanced cancer.
Women in rural and remote areas of the country were about 20 per cent more likely to die during the study than women in urban areas.

Although the study was not designed to determine why women living outside the city were more likely to die of ovarian cancer, Dr Jordan argues that factors may be late diagnosis and poor access to treatment.
"The best way to treat the illness are gynecologists, who usually live in larger cities," she said.

Despite improving distance medical services to overcome the barrier in terms of distance, the doctor suggested that it would help to strengthen transport services that allow specialists to treat women closer to their homes, and programmes to support people who are treated far from their families and friends.

Dr Jordan stated that the study revealed that the long-term survival of women with ovarian cancer is low regardless of geographical location, highlighting the need for better treatment and prevention programmes.
Research funded by Rio Tinto Ride to Conquer Cancer will be published today in the Medical Journal of Australia.
In March 2012, at the age of 33, Elisha Neave, a young mother from Gold Coast, was diagnosed with aggressive ovarian cancer.
Garden centers regret reduction in number of homeowners

According to a study by HTA published by the Financial Times, the drop in the number of homeowners under 35 could lead to garden centres losing up to £10 million a year until today’s younger generation of consumers reach the “main age group of gardeners.”
According to the report, people renting houses spend on average 55% of what people living in their own homes spend on their gardens.

Other factors threatening the industry, which earns an estimated £5 billion a year, include the increase in the number of people living in highly urbanised areas without gardens, the popularity of the use of parking spaces instead of courtyards and the decreasing size of gardens.
In the Greater London area, where the share of owned houses fell from 61% to 43% over six years, one household has the lowest expenditure on garden products in Britain.
HTA and the Royal Horticultural Society stated that housing in rent or a lack of space does not mean that people cannot grow plants.
Guy Barter, the chief garden advisor for RHS, said: “In tenants, it’s very popular to grow plants in flower pots – when they move, they can take the plants with them.”

The HTA report revealed that the "golden age" of the retail gardening sector was between 1997 and 2005 and was the result of a higher share of homeowners and economic prosperity lasting from the 1980s to the mid-1990s.
He also predicted higher sales this year due to better weather, which came after adverse conditions in March and April.
When the Eastern dictator speaks of democracy.

After Putin, at the meeting of his youth organisation, which reminds me most of all of the Hitlerjugends, rescued with atomic weapons and basically showed everyone that their views were stolen from him, gave us a lecture today on democracy.
But I have the feeling that the current regime in Russia shows many features of a fascist state.
The great nations have one thing in common, and that is that they can be ruled both by outdated nationalism and by the complex of inferiority transformed into imperialist traps.
Time seems to run differently in the east than in the west.

Whereas the Western world thought that the era of the wars of domination over Europe was long gone, the East believed that they had been overrun for a long time and that it was necessary to regain its international position.
Such a mood and frustration prevailed in Germany in the 1930s, just before the Nazis took power, and then followed an outbreak of nationalism similar to today's situation in Russia.

And then the very similar cult of a strong leader, the silence of journalists, the elimination of uncomfortable political opponents, discrimination against minorities and homosexuals, it is therefore, to believe it, quite similar.
Vladimir Putin, and certainly most of the Russians, are probably missing a time when Russia ruled half the world and the other half was shaking in front of them.

Maybe the Western politicians blamed themselves, maybe they didn't pat Vladimir on the shoulder, maybe they didn't invite him where he wanted to and maybe they started to underestimate him, and he just acted like a typical Russian man.
He kept his house in order, pretending he didn't want to go anywhere, and broke his knives.
Now he's decided to take back his lost position.
He starts slow, he's got time.
The leader's probably a lifetime old, so where would he hurry?
He scolded the Caucasians, now he scolds the Ukrainians, then there are the dwarfs of the Balkans.
They've been sniffing a Russian bear in a coat for a long time.
That's sure to be noticed by China, too, which is jumping up and down, and is sure to make a long way east.
And the Germans are really pissed off about Vladimir as well, and I gave them that on their ass at 45.
How about a new Novorosia in Karlovy Vary?
It would have been a basement, and there were a lot of ours there, and as they pressed them there, they already wanted to destroy some of them.
After all, our veterans still remember how they were in that Czechoslovakia.
Well, their Prime Minister, Mr. Sobotka, he's so soft, he can be broken like an onion and eat the whole of their EU.
It would be a game of leaps and bounds on big Russia.
They need to be reminded of where their place is.
And as explosives, we'll use our soukmen who live in their territory.
There's enough Russians everywhere, and when it's said they're pressing them in there, they're just pressing them in there, and we don't let that happen, we're protecting them.
And again, the Russian will rule, for he is born for something else.
After all, Europe is only good as a prelude to which a proud Ivan can dance a coconut.
Turkey summoned an American diplomat for a spy report
The Turkish Foreign Minister has called the highest-ranking US diplomat in the country to explain the report on US and British spying activity in Turkey.
Deputy Prime Minister Bulent said the American charge d'affaires and Turkish officials discussed the report Monday.

German magazine Der Spiegel and Internet magazine The Intercept stated that according to documents provided by a former analyst of the U.S. National Security Agency, Turkey was a priority target of U.S. and British intelligence services.
According to Turkish media, Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan underestimated the importance of the report and declared that all the major states were watching each other.
An earlier report that the German intelligence service also targeted Ankara provoked a more angry reaction from the Turkish government.
Game of Thrones series introduced the next tricks of the fourth series
The creators of Game of Thrones are currently shooting episodes of the fifth series of the cult series.
At the same time, they were honored with the creation of the tricks of the fourth series.
The most visible are computer adaptations of the series environment and the mass scenes where from the depths of the soldiers become a huge army of the famous Daenerys.
Chief of Police in Magaluf accused of corruption
On Friday, the complainants presented to the Mallord State Prosecutor's Office evidence of police and city council officials being blackmailed in the municipality of Calvia.
The head of the police in Calvia on the holiday island of Mallorca was arrested after allegations raised by businessmen and bar owners in the notorious party district of Magaluf.

Chief Inspector José Antonio Navarro was taken into custody after he was accused of corruption by several businessmen from Punta Ballena, the street where most of Magaluf's bars and night businesses are located.

According to the online diary Mallorca Diario, on Friday the complainants presented to the prosecutor of the Mallorca Office for Combating Corruption evidence of corruption by police officers and public officials of the city council in the municipality of Calvia.
Two other local police officers have been arrested by the Spanish State Police on charges of corruption and will be heard by a judge along with Navarr.
The Spanish national daily ABC quoted dissatisfied owners of night businesses as saying that the advantages given by public actors had a serious impact on their business.
"It's no longer about making money, it's about survival," said one of the entrepreneurs at the courthouse.
Don't play with our livelihood.
We have nothing to lose.
Magaluf reached the front page of magazines around the world after a video appeared on YouTube of an 18-year-old British tourist who gave oral sex to 24 men during a tour of bars.
Since then, the island authorities have been trying to monitor drunkards and hawkers among the participants in Magaful's holiday parties by reducing the number of notorious alcoholic bar tours.
In addition, the Playhouse club, where an oral sex event took place, was forced to close for a year and to pay a fine of €55,000 ($73,000) along with Carnage's bar tour organizers.

The tourist resort Magaluf, which is popular mainly among Britons, has also witnessed many alcoholic accidents, including a fashion wave known as "balconing", in which people jump from one balcony to another or from the balcony to the hotel pool.
The first spring day was marked by rain and storms that affected flights at Adelaide Airport
JARO brought an ice surprise to southern South Australia, with heavy rain and strong winds that seriously hit Adelaide Airport.
Another 5 mm of precipitation is expected in the city until nine o'clock in the evening and another 6.6 mm falls during the night on Sunday.
The last rain occurred along with a few short storm surges and wind disturbances that began eight o'clock in the evening and brought nearly 4 mm of rainfall in about ten minutes.
After several early spring doses came after the winter last week, temperatures in the city fell again on Monday to just 15.8 °C.
Hurricane weather is believed to have contributed to the delayed arrival of Virgin Airlines from Melbourne to Adelaide.
The aircraft was supposed to land shortly after 19:30, but was hit by a change in speed or direction of the wind over a short distance and was forced to delay landing.
Wind gusts at Adelaide Airport at the time reached about 50 km/h on the ground.
Flight data indicated that the aircraft had to depart from the second landing and finally reached about 20:40.
The delay resulted in further flight delays, including Emirates flights from Dubai and Qantas flights from Sydney.
The temperatures in Adelaide are forecast to reach a maximum of 16 °C on Tuesday and one or two overshoots may occur.
Israeli children return to school after the war in Gaza

Thousands of Israeli children from areas near the Gaza Strip returned to school Monday after spending the summer in anti-bomb shelters, while rockets and mortars attacked their homes during the fifty-fifth war between Israel and Hamas. However, schools in Gaza remain closed while the territory recovers from the fighting.
The beginning of the school brought a sense of joy and excitement to the communities in southern Israel known for the attacks, but the signs of fighting are still visible.
In Ashdod, a city in the south of the country, staff of a schoolhouse hit by a rocket have removed the remains of the stumps from the wall and are awaiting the return of the children.
"We're a little scared, but otherwise we're looking forward," said Ronit Bart, a resident of Kibucu Saad and an English teacher at the local school.
Many children in this area really need to return to their daily routine.
Her eleven-year-old daughter, Shani Bart, told her it was "a little strange" to go to school again.
"We had a hard time, and we didn't leave the house at all," she said.
Kibuc, which is close to the border with Gaza, visited President Reuven Rivlin to offer his support to the population.

Until the ceasefire last week ended the war, thousands of border settlers like Saad remained inside their homes or left their homes and went to safer areas farther away from Gaza to escape missiles and mortars.
Many residents of Nachal Oz, a village near the Gaza border in which a Palestinian mine-gun shot killed a four-year-old boy, are struggling to return.
The Minister of Education said that about twelve families still did not return.
Their children were temporarily placed in secondary schools.
Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu visited a school in Sderot, a city on the border with Gaza that was heavily affected by Palestinian fire.
He encouraged the children to study diligently, adding, "We will provide you with education and safety."
Israel and Hamas agreed last Tuesday on an unlimited peace.

While the ceasefire led to an immediate cessation of the fighting, it did not resolve key issues such as Hamas’ demand for an end to the Israeli-Egyptian blockade of Gaza and the reopening of Gaza airports and ports.
Israel demands the disarmament of Hamas and the return of the bodies of two soldiers killed in the war.
A new round of indirect negotiations is expected to begin later this month in Egypt.
According to estimates by Palestinians and the UN, more than 2,100 Palestinians died in the war, three quarters of whom were civilians and at least 494 children.
Israel disputes these figures and estimates that at least half of those killed were radicals, although there is no clear evidence to support these claims.
On the Israeli side, 66 soldiers and six civilians, including a Thai worker, died.
Hamas and other radicals from Gaza fired 4,591 rockets and mortars at Israeli cities in the southern part of the country during the fighting.
The Israeli army again carried out more than 5,000 air strikes and other attacks.
The Israeli attacks have damaged or destroyed thousands of homes in Gaza, and an estimated 250,000 people have been hiding in hundreds of UN schools that have been converted into temporary shelters.
Due to tens of thousands of people still in hiding and ongoing fighting, school officials postponed the start of the school year last week.

“I hope the school will open soon so that we can complete our education like Jewish children and other children around the world,” said Mohammad Amara, a 13-year-old boy from a school in Gaza’s largest city.

And Lafat suffers from the temperature

The Czech football team met today before noon in Prague before Wednesday's preparation match with the USA and the subsequent opening match of the European Championship qualification against the Netherlands.
The twenty-three-year-old team has problems with Spartan striker David Lafat, who suffers from fever.
David's not here yet, but Sparta had some problems last week, it was more players, and David still has a little bit of those problems.
But we want him to be here and be all right as soon as possible," coach Pavel Vrba told reporters.
"If it's two or three days, or if it's fit tomorrow, it'll depend on his condition, which our doctor will decide," he added.
The other players are fine.
"Of course someone has some illness, but it is not such that they could not train or participate in a match on Wednesday with the USA," the Czech coach said.
On Sunday night Vrba called as the last player of Spartan backup Luke Vach.
He admitted that it was not an easy decision, and other Central Poles considered it.
I decided on the basis that Luke is a prospective player who is 25 years old.
The decision was very complicated, but I stand by it," Vrba said to Vách.
What about Shural?
Let's see what happens to Latata.
It is not excluded that, in the event of health problems, the nomination could still change.
On the weekend, for example, Josef Šural, a Liberal, shined with a great performance, giving a hattrick.
Of course, there are players who have recently shown the form.
Let's see how David Lafat's going.
If he can't be available on Wednesday, I'm not saying that I can't bring in any of the players who have taken interest in the Czech League," Vrba said.

This afternoon the national team is waiting for training in Strahova, on Tuesday then the classic pre-match training before the duel with the USA on Summer, which will be open to fans and followed by autograms.
The race against the Americans will be played on Wednesday from 20:15 and the national team in it will strive for a premier victory under Vrba.
In the previous three matches, he played two rebounds and lost one.
The qualification match with the Netherlands is then scheduled for September 9th from 20:45.
The dog is going to the Netherlands to Italy
Vrba is glad that he has more time to practice than before.
There is an advantage when you have eight days of players and you can train with them certain things that we might not have had so much time for before.
Now we can only concentrate on making the best possible preparations for the Netherlands," Vrba said.
The Dutch will be represented in Italy on Thursday before the match in Prague and Josef Pešice, the former temporary coach of the team, will be watching the duel in person.
He'll give us the information that's from the game.
But it's not just about him, we're going to have a game shot and we're going to pick it up.
A new coach is coming to the Netherlands, we'll see what changes there will be," Vrba told the bronze medalists from the recent world championship.
According to highly monitored statistics, winter apartment prices have risen the most in the last seven years.
According to the housing value index in the Australian capital RP Data CoreLogic Hedonic housing prices rose by 1.1% in August, the agency said Monday.
The increase resulted in an overall increase in July, July and August to 4.2 %, the highest increase in the winter months since 2007.
Annual price increases reached 10.9%, more than double the year before August 2013, but profits were not evenly distributed in the country.
Research Director of RP Data Tim Lawless said Sydney and Melbourne are leading the market.
RP Data figures show that Sydney apartment prices rose 16.1% last year, while Melbourne prices rose 11.7%.
Among the other strongest markets were Adelaide, Brisbane and Darwin, with prices rising between five and six percent on average.
On the other side of the scale, Canberra, which suffered from the state's ordered cuts in expenditure, where prices rose by only 1.4% during the year.
Lawless said that as spring now began, there will be an increase in the number of properties available for sale in the coming months, which will be a "true test" for the market.
"Given the persistent high levels of auction sales, generally high sales rates and low interest rates, it is likely that the value of housing will rise further over the next three months," he said.
Lenny Henry: My father never hugged me.
He never said "I love you" to me
Henry was born in 1958 as one of seven children of Jamaican immigrants in Dudley, Midlands.
They had a cooler relationship with their father, who died when Henry was 19, and who worked in the factory.
Henry explores comedy, Rudy's Rare Records, which is partly based on an imaginary interview with his father and is part of the Radio 4 series.
The soundtrack is a mixture of reggae and rap and the melody is optimistic.
Henry had to deal with a few unpleasant memories of his childhood.
After his mother's death, Henry underwent "in-depth" therapy and is now thinking about his relationship with his father.
He knew very little about him.
You've never seen his face, you've just heard his voice: "Stop with that whisper.
Leave your sister alone.
Get out!
I want to look at the cricket.
My older brothers Seymour and Hilton—when I was a kid, they were grown-up—went to the bar with him and talked about things like the shape of a beer glass or the beauty of a strike in a cricket.
I've never talked to him like that.
For most of my life, he was a serious guy in the corner reading the paper.
Henry had recently visited the Dudley Dairy, and although the conditions were better than at his father's time, he had seen what life had to be like for him.
There's a little more light in there today, but it's still a dark, smoky, cloudy labyrinth where flames are burning and there's a lot of smoke and sage.
Dad always went in the tub and just lay there, and then you could hear him slowly start singing for himself, because he was pouring out the brewery.
As I walked around, I realized that he'd been doing this for years to enjoy his family, and I began to value him more.
Nevertheless, Henry lived a childhood without parental love.
Dad didn't hug anyone, didn't say "I love you."
It wasn't until my mom was sick and dying that we started to say, "I love you, I love you, I love you."
His daughter Billie, who he has with Dawn French, has made it possible for him to experience the love he missed as a child.
Can you stop saying "I love you"?
Don't hug me all the time!
Dad, I'm 22!
With Dawn French.
Why shouldn't we be friends?
She's a great mom
With French, with whom he was married for 25 years, they are still good friends.
Dawn's good.
Why shouldn't we be friends with Dawn?
She's a great mom.
Henry's own mother had diabetes.
It was one of the things that killed her.
So when I was very, very overweight and had symptoms of diabetes, the doctor said, "You need to make a radical change."
So I started going to a big fitness center, and I also had to keep a drastic diet to get rid of the symptoms.
It's very hard.
And exhausting.
Nobody wants to eat carrots.
A change in Henry's career may be reflected in his elegant, short-cut bra.
After receiving acclaim from critics for his Othell, he dived into the theatre.
It was followed by The Comics of August Wilson and Plots of August Wilson.
It's a different experience than the sitcoms and comedy that filled his hectic work life.
He started when he was 16 and worked in a factory.
DJ noticed him performing on stage and wrote about him in the New Faces talent contest.
His television career began in the mid-1970s: "For a long time I was the only black imitator/comic in television."
He taught at the march.
Besides having to be noticed by the public, between 1975 and 1985 I also had to learn how to make working jokes, be a star and appear on television, and it was really hard.
Lenny at New Faces 1975

Since his manager owned the rights to the stage production of The Black and White Minstrel Show, an entertaining show in which actors turned black, Henry eventually appeared in it with his comedy for five years.
My family was already upset about it.
I wish it never happened, but I don't hate it.

Kenya registers civil servants to welcome non-existent employees
Kenya has started to biometrically register all its civil servants to try to remove non-existent employees from the government's payroll.
According to the government's statement, employees who do not register in the next two weeks will no longer be paid.
The government believes that thousands of people are still paid after leaving the state service.
After taking office in 2013, President Uhuru Kenyatta pledged to prevent corruption in government.
An audit conducted this year showed that the state receives at least $1 million (£700,000) per month from non-existent employees’ salaries and from further abuses of official power.

All civil servants must be admitted to identification centres within the next two weeks where their data will be biometrically recorded, the government statement states.
It also says that anyone who fails to meet without sufficient apologies will be expelled from the payroll.

According to Berkeley, the housing market is returning “to normal”
One of London’s most prominent developer companies has warned that the housing market in south-eastern England has “returned” to normal activity.
Housing in the capital was the subject of high demand and rising prices, and widespread concerns about the credit bubble prompted the Bank of England to introduce mortgage limits in June.

Tony Pidgley, founder and president of the Berkeley developer company for demanding clients, said on Monday, “Since the start of the current fiscal year, the market has returned from its peak of 2013 to a normal level of transactions.”
London's housing market did well during the downturn, as foreign buyers flocked to the capital.
Prices in the city jumped by 18.5% last year alone, far ahead of the average of 6.7% in England and Wales.
Average retail prices of private, affordable and student housing from Berkeley rose by about a fifth last year and reached £423 000 at the end of April.

However, due to the strengthening leverage, they have not been so attractive to foreign London property buyers in recent months – some of them have also been threatened by the introduction of new property taxes and the talk of a possible “seat tax” that politicians have come up with before next May’s parliamentary elections.

London-based real estate firm Foxtons warned last week that the April mortgage market review, which introduced stricter loan rules, will also slow the pace of market growth in both real estate sales and prices during the second half of the year.
New Bank of England data on Monday showed a decline in the number of approved mortgages for July, indicating that the housing market is calming down.
Hamptons International, another real estate agency, has reduced its forecast for London real estate prices to 3% in 2015 on the grounds that house prices have already begun to fall.
Meanwhile, the volume of transactions in London's most expensive neighborhoods such as Chelsea, Mayfair, and Kensington has dropped by a quarter each year, according to WA Ellis.
Nevertheless, the demand for housing in the capital was a blessing for Berkeley, as it increased cash for forward sales to over £2.2 billion.
Pidgley added: “The demand for the right, well-looking housing in a good location has remained the same and forward sales have therefore been maintained.”
In June, the company reported that it had sold 3,742 properties between the beginning of the year and the end of April, almost a third more than before the crisis in 2007.
Annual pre-tax profit increased by 40% to £380 million, revenue by 18% to £1.6 billion.

4 tips on how to get better photos and videos underwater
If you are interested in underwater shooting or shooting, you have a wide range of equipment available.
The cheapest option is a compact Nikon Coolpix AW120 or an outdoor GoPro Hero3+ Silver Edition camera, which costs around $300.
I took these pictures at a family party with a couple of cameras, and they all cost less than $350.
It doesn't matter what equipment you use, but there are a few rules for achieving the best results.
Check your equipment.
Even if you have a waterproof camera, make sure the batteries and other parts are tightly sealed.
Additionally, set the camera according to the type of photos or videos you want to take.
Some cameras and video cameras have a scene or shooting mode that optimises exposure to a dark underwater environment.
And before you get into that, find out how deep you can dive with your equipment.
Some cameras are limited to 5 feet, others to 50 to 60 feet.
Read our guide to purchase and evaluate digital cameras in both standard and waterproof versions.
Always take a few shots - not many of them will come out.
Compact cameras have an LCD that helps you to compose pictures, but outdoor cameras don't.
Even if you have an LCD, underwater it will be difficult to see and the composition of the shot will be unpredictable.
So always do more shots.
If the camera has a bracketing mode that takes a series of shots with slightly different exposure range, use this.
Stay close to the surface.
With a deeper dimming, the light is significantly reduced.
If possible, keep your photo in the pool, lake or sea near the surface.
This also allows you to capture more light in your photos - the deeper you dive, the fewer colors you will see.
Get close to the photographed object.
That's great advice if you're shooting on the ground, but underwater is even more important because of the darker light.

This is especially important when shooting with an outdoor camera: Such devices usually have a fixed and wide angle lens, which means that if you want to fill the frame, you need to get closer to the objects.

The most dangerous type of asbestos has not been used in Britain since the 1960s, when the ban on the use of asbestos in industry came into force.

The 2 500 deaths due to this disease each year are twice the number of victims of car accidents.

The mesothelioma epidemic does not only affect veterans of the construction industry.

The law created a 350-million-dollar financial reserve to be paid for by insurance companies and is intended for people diagnosed after July 2012, who can prove that they have been exposed to asbestos but have no one to prosecute.
In such a case, the victims will receive 80% of the amount normally awarded to them by the court as compensation - around £120 000.
300 successful applications are expected each year.
Andrew Morgan, like patients with mesothelioma, thinks £350 million is a “good job.”

"It's an agreement signed by the insurance companies for the insurance companies," he says, pointing out that the sum is a quarter of what the insurance companies would have to pay if it hadn't taken time and people with mesothelioma were able to come back to the former employers and prosecute them in a normal way.
Even Mike Penning, a former Labour and Social Affairs Minister, admitted that the law “had gaps.”
But both Penning and Morgan admit that, given the seven deaths every year, quick action was needed.

Despite mounting discussions about democratic reform on Sunday, the Chinese parliament decided not to allow Hong Kong voters to nominate candidates for the 2017 elections.
It is likely that this move will trigger long-awaited protests in Hong Kong's shopping district, as activists have only begun to organize and gather hours after the announcement.
The Chinese People's Congress basically allows communist leaders to remove any candidate who is not loyal to Beijing.
"It didn't surprise us at all, but it angered us," said legislator Emily Lau, chairman of the Democratic Party.
That's not what Beijing promised.
People in Hong Kong lied.
And it's clear that we have to do with an authoritarian regime.

In defense of the Chinese decision, Deputy Secretary-General of the Standing Committee of the National People’s Congress Li Fei said that allowing public nomination in Hong Kong’s leadership elections would cause “chaos.”
Since 1997, when Britain returned Hong Kong to China, Beijing has promised that, starting in 2017, citizens will be able to vote for executive power.

The Chinese leaders presented Sunday's decision as a democratic breakthrough, because Hong Kong is allowed to vote directly, but the decision also clearly shows that the Chinese leaders are firmly in the hands of the committee nomination process, which is strictly controlled by Beijing.
And under the new clause, only candidates who “love the country and Hong Kong” will be eligible.
The decision came after the summer months that marked one of the largest and most followed protests in Hong Kong in several years.

Behind most pro-democracy protests in Hong Kong lies the Center for Love and Peace Purchase movement, whose organisers have threatened to close the financial district unless Beijing grants them universal voting rights.
On Sunday evening, just hours after the announcement, hundreds of supporters of the Purchase movement gathered in the rain in front of the Hong Kong government headquarters.
At the demonstration, the organisers announced that their movement was entering a new phase of civil disobedience and that they would start waves of protests in the coming weeks.
However, they did not provide any further details, apparently seeking to avoid problems with the authorities.

In an online statement, the organizers said the movement "has only regarded the occupation of the Centre as a last step in the event that all possibilities for dialogue are exhausted and there is no other choice.
It is regrettable to note that today all the possibilities for dialogue have been exhausted and the occupation of the Centre is inevitable.
The Hong Kong authorities had been preparing for Beijing's announcement for days, and on Sundays they reinforced the protection of the government's headquarters and deployed police and barricades.
Influenced by the unrest, many inhabitants of Hong Kong feel that they are slowly losing control of the city.

There are also growing concerns that values such as democracy and freedom of speech are being circumvented by increasing pressure from Beijing.
Some people criticise the Centre Purchase movement and say their demonstrations threaten the Hong Kong rescue boat business.
"The protest he's talking about could cause much greater economic damage depending on how many people take part and for how long," says Regina Ip, a politician who has long criticized the movement.
We do not want fears to grow that Hong Kong is getting out of control.
Such a perception could harm investment.
Chinese state media have also come in recent days with reports depicting the democratic activists in Hong Kong as subversive agents ruled by the West.
In the summer, activists organised an informal referendum on voting rights, attended by 780 000 people - more than a fifth of Hong Kong voters.

Election agitation?

Feminists protest racism and police behaviour after Ferguson events
At the beginning of the month, he killed an unarmed young man in Ferguson, Missouri.
Those present waiting for the funeral with their hands up shouting, "Hands up, don't shoot!"
After two weeks of protests in Ferguson, Missouri over the shooting of an unarmed young man, Michael Brown, blogger Miriam Zoila Perez noticed a shift in online discussions of white feminists.
It found that when it comes to promoting reproductive rights and income equality, white feminists prefer gender over race.
With rising tensions in the Midwest, which attracted the attention of the national press, Perez noticed that the white reaction was 100% focused on race.

Compared to the reactions of blacks soon after the 9 August shootings, personal articles with headlines such as "A white woman's thought of Ferguson" or "Feminism is not just about oppression of women" appeared relatively late.
According to Perez, however, this represents an important change.
"I don't think there are many people in the feminist movement who would talk about race and privilege at this level," she said.
People felt that what had happened had to be expressed.
This is characteristic of the crisis that we are facing, because [the situation in Ferguson] is so racial-based that they had to draw attention to it.

According to Korithy Mitchell, an English professor at Ohio State University, Ferguson has brought to light problems that African-American women face every day and that are not perceived as “female issues” in the cultural sphere.
“I can publish funny stories from my partner’s life on Facebook and get 150 licks from people around the world,” Mitchell said.
When I write something about the colored being trapped in their own country, it's deafening silence.
"How is it possible that a woman can talk publicly about relationships but not about security in public?" she asked.
For blacks like Mitchell, who have addressed the issue of race, gender, and sexuality in American history, there is no dichotomy between race and gender issues.
Black women, she said, could not afford luxury to clearly divide these problems: they live in this mixed reality every day.

Although whites today combine the question of race and gender in mainstream feminist circles, Angela Hattery, a professor of women's issues and gender studies at George Mason University, says their predecessors did the opposite.
Between 1865 and 1890, at least 10,000 blacks were lynched, and the reason was almost in all cases the rape of a white woman," Hattery said.
To justify lynching, you needed the cooperation of the whites.

According to Hattery, the rift between whites and blacks came when campaigners like Susan B. Anthony examined the field at the end of the 19th century and realized that only one group of people could have the right to vote—women or blacks.
"They decided to bet on women's right to vote and blacks' right to focus later," Hattery explained.
If we realize this, we'll have an important insight into why women of color don't trust whites.
We haven't done a good job.
We've never helped black men protect their husbands and children.
Even after women gained the right to vote in 1920, it took them ten years to organize against lynching in the Association of Southern Women for the Prevention of lynching.
The group was formed 40 years after the blacks first asked for help.

According to Mitchell, the repulsive reactions of white feminists to the issues brought about by Ferguson – the question of police behaviour, racial discrimination – reflects a time when white feminists had to “focus” on the issues faced by blacks across generations.
“Wouldn’t it be great if activists in these spaces [traditional feminism] took the right to raise a child as seriously as they took the right to contraception?” Mitchell asked.
The second wave of feminists who have made a career of fighting for reproductive rights and access to contraception are now finding out what that means.

Significant feminist activists like Gloria Steinem took two weeks after Michael Brown's shooting with a Facebook attack, releasing a column by Rebeccy Carroll of the Guardian calling for white Americans to protest racism more vigorously.

"I hope that women who have different but similar reasons to understand the dangers in society - and opinions on race that differ significantly in public opinion surveys - will strive for change," Steinemová wrote.
Although Steinem advocates cross-sectional feminism, which encompasses race and gender issues, her comments on race issues in America make some people blind.

Christina Sommers, a professor at the American Enterprise Institute and author of "Who Stole feminism?", told She The People that young men in the United States, especially young men of color, are "much more vulnerable than their sisters," but Steinem's remarks on Ferguson face criticism she had raised earlier.
We now have hundreds of special programs for girls and young women, but almost none for boys.
But when the White House launched My Brother's Keeper, a small program to help vulnerable young blacks and Spaniards, it provoked outrage among many feminists, including Gloria Steinem.
The relationship of the police to the black community is not the only problem that is gaining prominence in mainstream feminism.

After the US border police detained nearly 63,000 unaccompanied youth in the southwest of the country this year, the question of reforming immigration laws has once again arisen - this time as a woman's question.

Formal agreement with employer can be a problem
Unfortunately, you did not get a work disability certificate from your doctor, which serves as proof to the organization that you cannot perform your work duties for health reasons.
Moreover, you did not immediately notify the employer of the absentee.
Subsequently, although it was agreed that the days in question would be recorded as holidays, the agreement was only oral.
Although the Labour Code does not impose an obligation to have the employer’s consent to take leave confirmed in writing, this procedure has proved to be good in practice.
If there is only an oral agreement, you do not have a confirmation agreement.

Later, the alleged consent to take leave, as in your case, may be denied and the absence at work is considered to be a long-term unconditional absence, thus a reason for immediate termination of employment under § 53 of the Labour Code.
In the event of a legal dispute concerning an agreement with your employer, you will thus lack proof.
However, the employment relationship with you has not been cancelled pursuant to § 53, only you have the dates listed in the balance sheet as an unavoidable absence.

The unauthorised absence in the scoreboard does not have the same consequences as Paragraph 53 (e.g. inability to receive material security in unemployment), yet it makes it difficult to find a new job.
We recommend that you visit your doctor again and confirm in writing that you actually had an injury that made you unable to work (this is not a "incapacity", it is just a doctor's document).
If you are looking for a new job, you can submit the document and explain the situation.

In practice, it is appropriate not to underestimate both the submission of a written medical certificate of incapacity for work, the prompt notification to the employer or the request for written consent to take leave.
You avoid any complications.

The laid-off employee took revenge, bought notebooks and sold them to the company
A condemned employee bought computers at the company and then sold them.
He was able to spend his money before he was arrested by the police.
In a short period of time, the man purchased in twelve cases a total of sixteen computers for more than two hundred thousand crowns.
"He took the notebooks to Olomouc after the takeover, where he sold them in the bazaars," said Rostislav Brückner, the Chief Commissioner of the šumper police.
The motive for the fraud was a bribe from the employer for the dismissal and also for the profit of money.
"He told us during the interrogation that he used the money to repay the loans," Brückner said.
The police also found that the fraudster is a pathological player who has repeatedly undergone psychiatric treatment.
The money could also end up in winning machines or video lottery terminals.
"The fact is, we didn't find any money from him," the Commissioner said.
The scammer, who has already been convicted of theft, now faces a prison term of one to five years.

However, none of the market owners have yet been charged.

Prison guards organise protests in Bulgaria
Hundreds of prison staff throughout Bulgaria took part in a nationwide protest rally in front of the Ministry of Justice in the capital Sofia.
At the peaceful demonstration, they reiterated their demand for the reintroduction of the original working conditions, which have recently changed.
There are also higher salaries on the list of requirements to be discussed with the Provisional Minister of Justice Hristo Ivanov.
The guards symbolically protested the new working hours for a month and demanded a return to the original twenty-four-hour shifts.
Although the prison supervisors' unions and representatives of the Ministry of Justice met, they did not reach an agreement, the Bulgarian State Radio (BNR) reported.
“The hunting is still going on,” said Rosen Zhelyazkov, head of the General Directorate of Prison Service, BNR.
Members of the Federation of Employee Trade Unions at the Ministry of the Interior are also expected to join the protests of prison staff.
Why can the universe have more dimensions and we don't see them
Physicists don't usually write best-selling books, but Brian Green of Columbia University made a black hit in 1999.

His book The Elegant Universe has become the most accessible way for the lay to get to grips with the complexity of the problems that a number of theoretical physicists deal with today - an attempt to unify two well-functioning but mutually incompatible discoveries of the 20th century: quantum theory and general relativity theory.
One of the reasons for the success of the Elegant Universe is undoubtedly that in the case of searching for a unified physics theory it is not a boring story.

The fundamental physics problem between the two key theories (although at the moment our universe is de facto divided into two worlds with different laws) has been solved and solved so imaginatively that it is worth retelling to the secularists.
Moreover, Greene handled the complicated material so freshly and compellingly that it was impossible to account for how much he had not included in his book.
Moreover, his "deficiency" was largely corrected in two other books: Structure of the Universe and Hidden Reality.

Obviously, neither the author would object to his book becoming obsolete faster, but the fact is that even after 15 years the Elegant Universe still provides almost everything essential that an informed secularist with ambition to understand the world should know about this important part of theoretical physics.

It is quite likely that in the coming years there will be a little more life in this area (e.g. because the LHC accelerator will finally go to "full gas"), and so it is a good time to enter Green's fiercely open door to the world of modern physics.
How many dimensions can our universe have?
The idea that our universe may have more than three dimensions of space may sound foolish, fantastic, strange, or mystical.
However, it is concrete and fully acceptable.
To understand this, let's turn our eyes away from the universe as a whole for a moment to something more underground, namely a long and thin garden hose for watering.
Imagine pulling a hundred-metre garden hose from one side of the canyon to the other and watching the whole scenery from half a kilometer away (as shown in the picture and on the next page).
From such a distance, you can easily see a long horizontally stretched hose, but if you do not suffer from sharpness, the thickness of the hose is difficult to recognize.
Given its large distance from the hose, you might think that an ant trained to live on a hose has only one dimension in which to walk: the left-right dimension along the hose.
When someone asks you where the ants were at the time, you will only give them one information: the distance of the ants from the left (or right) end of the hose.
All we're saying is, from a mile away, a long piece of hose looks like a one-dimensional object.
In the real world, the hose is thick.
If we zoom in, we suddenly see a second dimension - in the shape of a circle opening a hose.

In such an enlarged view, it is obvious that the ants can in fact move in two independent dimensions: in the already well-known left-right dimension along the length of the hose, but also in "the dimension in/against the direction of movement of the clock handles", i.e. around the circular diameter of the hose.
You're beginning to understand that to determine the position of a small ant, you have to enter two numbers: how far is it from the end of the hose and where is the hose opening on the circle.
This reflects the fact that the surface of the hose is two-dimensional (see Experts note that this chapter focuses purely on the fault theory of strings.
Non-compromising aspects are discussed in Chapters 12 and 13.)

The surface of the hose is two-dimensional: one long longitudinal dimension is represented by a straight arrow, the dimension in the direction of the circumference, marked by a circular arrow, is short and leady.
There is, however, a clear difference between these two dimensions.
The width along the hose is long and easily visible.
The diameter of the opening circuit of the hose is short, "shaped" and worse noticeable.
In order to understand the existence of the circular dimension, we had to test the hose with a much better resolution.
This example illustrates an important property of spatial dimensions.
That they're divided into two groups.
They may be large, wide, and therefore directly visible, or, on the contrary, small, dirty, and much worse observable.
Of course, in that case, we didn't really work hard to reveal the "developed" dimension of the thickness of the hose.
Just take a telescope to help.
But if the hose were thinner—like a hair or a capillary—we would only discover the filthy dimension with great effort.
Kaluza sent Einstein an article in 1919 in which he argued with the stunning idea that the spatial geometry of the universe could have more than the three dimensions that we all know.

Kaluza justified his radical assertions by providing an elegant and convincing framework in which Einstein's general relativity and Maxwell's electromagnetic theory could be integrated into a single, unified conceptual structure.
The question immediately arises as to how Kaluza's observation fits together with the obvious fact that we see three dimensions of space.

The answer which Kaluza quietly assumed between the lines and which was clearly expressed and specified by the Swedish mathematician Oskar Klein in 1926, stands and falls with the assertion that the spatial geometry of our universe can have both large and dirty dimensions.
This means that, like the dimensions of the length of the hose, our universe also has three large, wide-ranging and easily visible dimensions whose existence we are aware of at every moment.

But, analogously to the circular circumference of a garden hose, the universe may have additional dimensions, firmly plunged into space so small that they have hitherto remained hidden even before our best experimental apparatus.
To get a clearer idea of Kaluza's remarkable proposal, let's stay with the hose for a moment.
Imagine that we draw a relatively dense number of circles in black on the circumference of the hose.
From a distance, the hose still looks like a thin one-dimensional line.
With the telescope, now, thanks to the drawing, we can reveal the dumb dimension even more easily, because we will see the motif in Figure 2.
We can clearly see that the surface of the hose is two-dimensional, with one large and almost unlimited dimension and the other short and circular.

Kaluza and Klein came up with the idea that our universe had a similar structure, but apart from one small circular dimension, it had three large spatial dimensions, so four spatial dimensions together.
It is difficult to draw an object with too many dimensions.
To help your imagination a little, see the illustration in Figure 3; it shows two large dimensions and one small circular dimension.
In the picture, we zoom in on the geometry of the space just like we zoomed in on the surface of the hose.
Each subsequent level represents a huge expansion of the geometry of the space from the previous level.
Our universe may have additional dimensions (we see them on the fourth level of enlargement) if they are hollow enough in space; this explains that we have not yet directly observed them.
The square network represents the commonly known "large" dimension, while the circle represents a new, small and hollow dimension.

Just like thread loops in a densely carved carpet, these loops exist in every place of the usual dimensions - we only extended them to the intersections in the square network for the sake of visibility.

The background of Figure 4 depicts the commonly known structure of space - the ordinary world around us - on such common scales as meters, represented by the side of a small square in a square network.
For each of the following images, we will focus on the small area of the previous image; we will expand it to make it visible.
At first, there's nothing special going on, as we can see from some of the first levels of enlargement.

But if we go on our way to the microscopic properties of the geometry of space further - to the fourth level of enlargement in Figure 3 - we suddenly see a new, circle-shaped, lead dimension, similar to the thread loops in a densely woven piece of carpet.

Kaluza and Klein came up with the idea that an additional circular dimension existed at every point in the direction of large dimensions, just as a hose has a circular circumference at every point of its length.
For the sake of clarity, we only extended the circular dimension to some regularly located points.
Figure 4 summarizes Kaluza and Klein's idea of the microscopic structure of space geometry.
The similarity with the hose is obvious, although we note important differences.
First, the universe has three large, far-reaching spatial dimensions (of which we have drawn only two), whereas the hose has only one large dimension.
Even more importantly, the difference is that we're talking about the spatial geometry of the universe itself, not just some object inside the universe, like our hose.
But the basic idea is the same.

If the additional circular lead dimension is extremely miniature, it is much harder to recognize it - as is the circular circumference of the hose - than to observe the obvious, large, and wide-ranging dimensions.
If the size of the additional dimension is small enough, it will in fact be revealed beyond the power of our most modern enlargement tools.
Most importantly, however, the extra dimensions are not just a huge bubble within the normal dimensions, as the two-dimensional illustration misleadingly suggests.
A circle dimension is a new dimension that exists in each point of three common wide dimensions.
It is an independent dimension on the remaining three dimensions, just as the top-down, left-right and front-back dimensions are independent (and triangular) of each other.

A sufficiently small ant could move in all four dimensions, and to determine its position we would need four data, except for the three usual positions in the circular dimension; if we also count time, then data five, in any case one more than we would normally expect.
Have you been fascinated?
The book Elegant Universe by Brian Greeen can be purchased here on books.idnes.cz.
The price for the e-book is 149,- CZK.

To our surprise, therefore, we find that even though we are aware of the existence of only three dimensions of space, Kaluza and Klein's thinking shows that this does not exclude the existence of additional lead dimensions if they are small enough.
The universe may have more dimensions than we can see with our naked eye.
How small should they be?
The state-of-the-art technology can recognize structures of a billionth of a billionth of a meter.
We can hardly observe the smaller dumb dimension.
In 1926 Klein combined Kaluza's original idea with several ideas from the newly born quantum mechanics.
His calculations suggested that the additional circular dimensions could be about one Planck length, a size far beyond the distinguishing capabilities of modern instruments.
Since then, physicists have called the possibility of additional small space dimensions Kaluza–Klein theory.

Genetic disorders are often misdiagnosed
A British woman describes how she thought she would die after a bad diagnosis for many years.
After being diagnosed with another disease, Karin Rodgers spent most of her childhood believing that she had only a few years left to live.
In fact, it was Charcot-Marie-Tooth syndrome (CMT) - a group of hereditary disorders that damage nerves outside the brain and spinal cord.
The charity CMT UK stated that poor diagnosis is a common problem among people with CMT because there is very little known about the disease.
Approximately 23 000 people in the United Kingdom are believed to suffer from CMT, which can manifest symptoms in the area of motorism such as muscle weakness, involuntary walking and twisted toes.
Injured people may also experience indifference or pain, a condition that is incurable and progressive, which means that symptoms deteriorate over time.
When Rodgers was thirteen, she thought she was suffering from Freidreich's atxia (FA), a disease that had a very bad prognosis.
She believed that before she celebrated her eighteenth birthday, she would be tied to a wheelchair, and dead before she was thirty.
The mother of two children, now 51, says, "As a child, I knew I couldn't do the same things as the others.
I fell every day and it took me longer.
I've never been able to ride a bike or skateboard with the other kids, and I've been harassed at school for walking and running."

When Rodgers was thirteen and had undergone several operations to relieve her Achilles' heels and straighten her feet, she took advantage of her doctor's departure from the room and looked into her file where she found out she was suffering from FA.
"I felt guilty because I promised, so I didn't tell anyone, but when I came home, I looked up information about the disease in the library and I wrote to the FA Association," he says.
When they answered, I was shocked, completely panicked.
I thought before I was eighteen I would end up in a wheelchair, and before I was twenty-five I would be dead, and in the meantime I would gradually lose all my abilities.
I was on my own and I was planning my funeral."
When she was seventeen, she realized that her walking ability had not deteriorated as much as she had expected, and asked her surgeon.
He just stood up, embraced her, and said, "Honey, I don't think you have the disease, otherwise you'd be in the carriage already.
I think it'll be something much less dangerous to life."
After several genetic tests, he was found to have CMT.
"When he explained what CMT was, I thought I was a puppy," she said.
The charity CMT UK launched a month of CMT awareness to raise awareness of the disease.
Businessmen in Washington: Taxes increase as the economy turns around
The growing economy means more customers, higher sales and new jobs.
And higher taxes.
According to a new survey published last week, state and local corporate taxation in the country grew slightly last year as the recovery accelerated, and Washington firms were no exception.
Merchants in Maryland and Virginia have collectively transferred $27.6 billion to state and local treasuries in fiscal 2013, an increase of 3.8% over the $26.6 billion collected in 2012.
The tax burden – both national and local – rose by 4.3% last year to $671 billion, compared to 3.9% last year, and was the third year in a row after 2009 and 2010, when taxes were reduced.
According to a study carried out by Ernst & Young and the Center on State Taxation political group, state taxes have risen faster, by 4.3%, than local taxes, by 3.9%.
More than half of the county's tax revenue, 56%, comes from trade tax, and 36% of Maryland's revenue comes from companies.
Virginia, with 28%, has the relatively smallest business tax revenue.

Researchers argue that the majority of tax revenue growth is due to an increase in the value of property belonging to firms, which increased property taxes by 3.7 % this year for three consecutive years with -1% growth.
Although most of the profits come from large states such as California, New York, and Texas, the same seems to be true in Washington.
Companies in D.C., Maryland and Virginia paid more than $10 billion in state and local property taxes last year, an annual increase of 4.2% compared to 9.6 billion in 2012.
However, the apparent increase in the value of real estate does not drive up state and local tax revenues so much in Maryland, where property tax accounts for less than a fifth of corporate taxation.
For businesses in Virginia and D.C., property tax represents almost half of state and local taxation.
"Maryland owns a lot of corporate property, especially the D.C. tax base, the government or non-profit organizations that don't pay taxes," said Douglas Lindholm, CEO of the Center on State Taxation.
So Maryland is forced to rely much more on income taxes, for example, to pay for the same services that are in other states.
The recent increase in business tax revenue cannot be attributed solely to the recovery of the real estate market.
According to the data, business revenues also appear to be increasing.
Companies in the region issued a corporate income tax of $2.3 billion, up from $2.1 billion in 2012.
Maryland has raised one billion dollars in corporate income taxes, the largest in the region.
Although they are moving in the same direction, the local tax burden on entrepreneurs is not rising as rapidly in these three locations.
The growth rate in D.C. was at the national average of 4.3%, while growth in Maryland was significantly higher of 4.9%.
In Virginia alone, the tax increase was below average, to 4.1%.
Virginia has the lowest corporate income tax rate of 6% in all three counties (of which all have the same tax rate).
The corporate tax rate in Maryland is 8.25%, while the D.C. average remains relatively high at 9.975%.
A similar study conducted by the American Chamber of Commerce this year showed that Virginia has lower state and local taxes and a more favourable tax climate overall than Maryland.
D.C. did not evaluate the study.
Despite this advantage, Virginia faces pressure from the South.
North Carolina recently signed a law reducing the corporate tax from 6.9% to 6%, as did Virginia, and next year it will be reduced to 5%.
If the state continues to meet its revenue targets in the coming year, the tax rate on revenues as laid down by law could be reduced to as much as 3% in 2017.
According to a recent study, small businesses in Washington are doing better and therefore pay higher state and local taxes.

The livelihood tax levied by small businesses as a personal income tax - the structure of compensating for cost increases by raising prices according to which most companies are organised - in D.C., Maryland and Virginia increased by 20% last year to $2.4 billion, much faster than other taxes.

Researchers say that the trend and national increases in trade tax are likely to continue next year, with total sales tax revenues for both state and local governments rising to 6.2% in the first three quarters of 2014 compared to the same period last year.
Washington, however, may lag behind others, because cuts in state spending take their toll on the labour market.

It is also possible to set the automatic backup of photos from the phone to run only on wi-fi and after connecting to the charger.
So you'll be able to move sensitive images "safely" in time, and mainly you'll have space to delete unsaved images, so they won't unnecessarily take up space in the online storage.
Instructions on how to encrypt files and communication on the Internet are offered to readers of HN and IHNED.cz in the form of an electronic book by Michal Altair Valáška in PDF format.
A smart way to save on college scripts
Given that the cost of a university script for many students exceeds $1,000 a year, a prospective second-year student came up with a smart way to cut costs.

He lost 120.
According to the University Council, the average student spends more than $1,200 a year on textbooks and aids, but students have different options for managing these expenses.
Internet shops and creative solutions like Schroeder's are the preferred choice for students.
On the rise is the loan of textbooks, which allows students to use the semester book often with a significant discount than if they bought it.
Neebo Inc, which operates more than 250 bookstores in campus areas, says book lending has doubled since 2011.
A survey in the industry shows that around a quarter of the books in university libraries were borrowed in the last spring semester, says Vice President Neebo Trevor Meyer.
Less than half of the textbooks are purchased, according to the National Association of University Shops in University Libraries.
Here are 101 best ways to succeed.
Online shopping
Prices for some new books can be up to a third lower on the Internet than in university libraries.

The recommended price of the ninth edition of the book "Calculus" by Ron Larson, Bruce Edwards and Robert Hostettler is almost $290, but on the Internet it is possible to buy a new one at Chegg.com, a small shop specializing in textbooks, for $239.99.
Buy Used
If you do not mind other people's remarks or wear and tear, the appropriate option is to use textbooks.
On Chegg.com, Calculus is sold for $93.49.
Matt Casaday, 25, a senior at Brigham Young University, says he paid Amazon.com 42 cents for the used edition of Strategic Media Decisions: Understanding The Business End of The Advertising Business.
The new one was sold for $48.
University teacher Ingrid Bracey, head of the University of Massachusetts Amherst's College Without Walls, suggests that students check with their teachers whether older editions are acceptable.
Sometimes changes to work in seminars are not important.
If so, older releases may be sold at a fraction of the price of the last version.
In addition to Chegg and Amazon, eBay Inc's Half.com is also a popular alternative for buying used books.
Loans
It is also worth considering borrowing textbooks, if you handle them well, do not forget to return them and do not need to have them even after the seminar is over.
You can save up to 80% on the cost of a new book.
For example, a student could borrow Calculus for the entire semester for about $20.
Check the terms and conditions of the shop where you borrow the book, including penalties for notes, highlights or wear and tear.
Keep in mind: If you do not return the book in time, the fine may be higher than the price of the new book.
E-books
Another option is to purchase an e-book instead of a normal book.
Sometimes these books are essentially borrowed in the form of electronic licenses valid for a period of time from distributors such as Amazon.com, Chegg and Barnes & Noble Inc.
Chegg borrows Calculus for six months for about $61.

According to Bracey, so students of literary courses can find the most advantageous offers, because many classics are now available for free download, while natural and technical texts can be very expensive.
In any case, go shopping.
Joe Gault, 29, who will soon join Pepperdine Law School, recommends that you follow the ISBN because it guarantees that you buy the right book.
Before you order the book over the internet, make sure it's really in stock, Gault advises.
He was convinced of it on his own.
The book he bought was sold for four weeks, and he had to pay the full price for the book from the university library.
