That guy's just gonna survive.
The Ukrainian party also acts as a state in war.
A.cz: And how many Ukrainian prisoners have you saved?
If I understand it well, I'll exchange it.
Some sources say that it has long exceeded a hundred men.
It's been a long time since we stopped counting how many people we've helped.
We've only liberated them... not saved them from war if they decide to go on fighting.
The rescuers in the war are doctors, surgeons, but we certainly don't.
That's it.
And more and more are coming every day.
Every day we save someone.
Sometimes one, sometimes four or five.
And it doesn't always have to be an exchange.
Sometimes a simple human request is enough to release the prisoners.
A.cz: It is said that in a few months you have gained great authority and even confidence in the pro-Russian separatists... as well as in Ukrainian society.
How did you build respect on both sides?
Hard question.
One of the officers in Kiev gave me the nickname "crazy general with steel balls."
It doesn't offend me.
And maybe it shows the essence of our work.
As the head of the Ukrainian Police Corps, I've gained some authority before.
I never catch, I never cheat, and I always keep my word.
Whatever happens, I'm acting honestly and telling the truth.
Even when it is very uncomfortable for the Ukrainian Government, or the Donetsk or Luhansk Government.
If they torture and kill people?
So I'm just telling them they're torturing and killing them.
And that they're crimes.
I often risk my life, even being taken in exchange for prisoners... this job can mean an end to me at any time... I don't have to go back.
A.cz: How many corrections and torture of prisoners do you know?
... (long silence)... Ukrainians and separatists resort to torture of prisoners during interrogations.
I'm sorry.
And executions?
They're only happening on the inner side.
I have no information that the Ukrainian army is also correcting the prisoners.
There are no signs that the Ukrainian army is doing anything like this.
We have an idea of the number of corrections, but I cannot and do not want to give the numbers.
A.cz: Tell me the characters and motives of the Russian separatists.
Among them are officers, but also veterans from Afghanistan.
They are seeking independence and perhaps democracy in Donetsk or Luhansk - at least that's what they say.
They don't want to play games with Ukrainian oligarchs anymore.
The separatists already have teeth full of oligarchs and are their irresistible opponents - to life and to death.
As we say, they've eaten them to the throat.
By the way, the same dreams and desires were manifested in Maidan.
Now, let me be a little quick: Russia supports separatists and the West supports the Ukrainian state.
I consider one speculation to be large and the other to be small.
But already this sentence of mine has an inexcusable contradiction in it.
A.cz: For example, how does one of the strongest leaders of the Russian separatists Igor Bezler look to you?
Whenever I cross the line of the war front, I'm unarmed, showing the soldiers or armed men my bare hands.
And I'm always on both sides of those two or three hundred meters on a fly or in an optical pointer.
I can always see the faces of the people who are pointing at me... and they can press the trigger of their weapons at any time.
Colonel, experienced colonel with German and Ukrainian ancestors.
He is considered a Russian officer, but his family - his mother - lives in Ukraine.
They believe that Ukraine should not exist.
And if so, just like a small gubernia in a big Russian empire.
In any case, it is constantly being talked about and Ukraine is perceived as some sort of misunderstanding.
In his opinion, such a state should not even exist.
At the same time, it is an implacable enemy of all Ukrainian oligarchs.
A.cz: Speaking of characters - in the discussion show of Ukrainian TV you described your Prime Minister Arseniy Jacinyuk as a weak, helpless and tired "leader", who would do best if he left quickly.
I'll always get at least five times scared when I walk three hundred meters.
Why, then, should I conceal my opinion that Jacinyuk is a very weak prime minister and that he is harming our country?
A.cz: Do you think he was involved in the war in Ukraine?
You may know that Ukrainians call Jacinyuk a "chick."
And the rabbit is not an animal in the eyes of Ukrainians to be feared or to have respect and authority among others.
His behavior directly copies the rabbit's behavior.

He may be a good economist, but as a prime minister, he has no right in war to cry in parliament, to beg him, to play his intrinsics with him, to threaten to serve... he must govern, govern and protect the country in times of war.
When the country is threatened, the prime minister has no right to family, friends, rest for crying emotions.
He's the first minister of Ukraine.
And Jacink?
She's acting like a teenage girl.
Yes, he's tired, but he's also weak because he's never been strong... he's not fighting for Ukraine, he's just complaining all the time.
So he should leave.
The sooner, the better for Ukraine.

Norwegian Cruise approaches a three-million-dollar acquisition of Prestige Cruise

According to sources familiar with the whole matter, Norwegian Cruise Line Holdings s.r.o. (NCHL.O), the third largest cruise ship operator in the world, has advanced in negotiations for the purchase of Prestige Cruises International Inc. for approximately $3 billion.

The deal would allow Norwegian Cruise, a company with a market value of $6.8 billion, competing with larger competitors Royal Carrebian Cruises s.r.o. (RCL.N) and Carnival Corp (CCL.N), access to luxury cruise ships Prestige Cruises and rich clients.
The agreement could be published as early as this week, a source reported Sunday, but pointed out that the negotiations still may not end successfully.
The owner of Prestige Cruises, the private investment company Apollo Global Management LLC (APO.N), also owns a 20% stake in Norwegian Cruise.
The sources did not wish to be appointed because the negotiations were not public.
Representatives of Norwegian Cruise and Prestige Cruises did not respond to requests for comment, spokesman Apollo refused to comment on the situation.
Norwegian Cruise, based in Miami, operates thirteen cruise ships in North America, the Mediterranean and the Baltic Sea, Central America and the Caribbean.
The company's revenue in 2013 was $2.57 billion, 13% more than in 2012.
Prestige Cruises operates under the brands Oceania and Regent, which together own eight cruise ships sailing to Scandinavia, Russia, the Mediterranean, North America, Asia, Africa and South America.
In 2013, the company reported sales of $1.2 billion, 6% more than the previous year.
The twenty-nine billion segment of cruises is expected to benefit from the rise of the middle class in emerging economies such as China and India in the coming year.
Companies are competing to become the preferred option for these customers when choosing their cruises.
Prestige Cruises registered its first public offer with the U.S. regulatory authorities in January 2014.
Apollo has a majority stake in the company since 2007 with a trade value of $850 million.

Norwegian Cruise has existed in its present form since 2000, when it merged with the tour operator owned by Genting Bhd (GENT.KL), a consortium of leisure businesses and casinos controlled by Malaysian billionaire Lim Kok Thay.
In 2008, Apollo invested $1 billion in Norwegian Cruise.
Norwegian Cruise placed its shares on the stock exchange in January 2013.
According to the regulatory registration at the end of June, Genting owned 28% of the capital, Apollo 20% and TPG Capital LP 8%.
According to the registration documents of the first public tender, Carnival, Royal Caribbean Cruises and Norwegian Cruise together comprise 82% of the North American passenger volume.
Pro-democracy activists in Hong Kong provoke Chinese authorities the day after the vote
Nearby stood a group of people loyal to Beijing, wearing the Chinese flag.
On Sunday, the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress approved that only two out of three candidates participate in the 2017 Hong Kong elections.
All candidates must first obtain the support of the Appointment Commission, which is likely to be composed of members loyal to Beijing.

Because of this decision, it is almost impossible for opposition Democrats to get to the polls and persuade pro-democracy activists to renew their pledges and crush the financial center of Hong Kong’s protests of the “Century Purchase” movement.
In Hong Kong, political reform is the main cause of tension, and Chinese leaders fear that the demand for democratization will spread to other cities.

After Beijing published a detailed report on Chinese official authority in Hong Kong in June, democratic activists held an informal referendum on elections in a special district and hundreds of thousands of people marched into and occupied the city's commercial district.
The press conference, to be attended by Prime Minister Li, is organised by the Government of Hong Kong and the Chinese Liaison Office in Hong Kong.

Putin asks Kiev to start negotiations on “state sovereignty” with eastern Ukraine

According to a description of the events in Russian newspapers, on Sunday Russian President Vladimir Putin asked the Ukrainian government to stop fighting separatists in the east of the country and immediately start negotiations on the "state sovereignty" of the ousted areas.

His spokesman, Dmitry Peskov, later explained that Putin's remarks were not intended to suggest that the regions of eastern Ukraine under separatist control would become part of Russia, but that their status within Ukraine should be reconsidered so that the Russian-speaking region would have the power to protect its rights and interests.

Putin’s call for the Kiev government to treat the pro-Russian insurgents as equals corresponds to the obvious strategy it has followed since the outbreak of the unrest five months ago: Help the separatists occupy the territory and force the Ukrainian government to grant the newly declared Novorussia real independence so that it can join Russia instead of the West.

In an interview with the first channel of state television, Putin condemned the Ukrainian military actions aimed at regaining the eastern regions of Donetsk and Luhansk, which were ruled by separatists in March and April after Moscow annexed the Crimean Peninsula belonging to Ukraine on March 18.
The Kremlin and separatists have labeled the recently occupied territories as “Norway” or “New Russia,” a term that refers to the famous pre-revolutionary days of the Russian empire.

Russian press agency Itar-Tass published Putin’s words that anyone who believes peace talks are on the horizon is “a prisoner of illusions” because Ukrainian politicians have launched a campaign ahead of the October 26 parliamentary elections, while government forces are attacking civilians in separatist-controlled areas.

"In the interests of the people living in these areas, we must immediately start meaningful negotiations, not only on legal matters, but also on the political organisation of society and on the status of the state sovereignty of south-eastern Ukraine," he said.

Peskov said that Putin's attack on state sovereignty was conceived in the context of broader autonomy, which Kiev's leadership has been discussing for several months and which is intended to alleviate the concerns of Russian-speaking regions about the threat to cultural and linguistic rights.
Peskov said that only the Ukrainian government could grant the necessary autonomy to the eastern regions.
It is not a matter for negotiation between Ukraine and Russia, Peskov said, "because it is not a conflict between Russia and Ukraine, but an internal Ukrainian conflict."

The Kremlin spokesman’s interference, which was supposed to correct Putin’s “incorrect interpretation” of the remarks, underscored the Russian leadership’s approach to resolving the separatist insurgency in the east, which is different from the open occupation of Crimea, where most of the two-million-strong population belongs to ethnic Russians.

Moscow should also have much greater difficulty in announcing Donetsk and Luhansk in eastern Ukraine, as most of the 6.5 million inhabitants are not Russians, and public opinion surveys conducted even before the conflict have shown broad support for staying in Ukraine.

The autonomy discussed by Russian diplomats in international forums would give the regional governments in Ukraine the power to determine their own trade agreements and international relations, thereby essentially giving the Kremlin real control over the territory that would link the Russian mainland to Crimea.
The Black Sea Peninsula, annexed five months ago, is home to the main Russian naval fleet, a maritime commercial base and historical coastal resorts.
The areas between Russia's Rostov and Crimea are also a center of mines, factories and smelters that produce important components for the Russian army.

During his inaugural speech on 7 June, Ukrainian President Petro Poroshenko suggested that Ukrainian legislators - after the new elections - consider changes to the constitution that would give the diverse regions more control over their finances and language status.
But this vision of autonomy differs greatly from that of the Kremlin and separatists. Moscow is accused of arming and inciting violence.

Putin’s latest call for Kiev to treat separatists as equals followed a further insurrection last week after Russian troops and tanks penetrated eastern Ukraine from a previously peaceful area along the Azov Sea.

The separatists, reinforced by the Russians, took control of Novoazovsk with such force that the Ukrainian security authorities feared it was a campaign to occupy strategic coastal territory up to Crimea.

This hastened a huge civilian and military effort to fortify Mariupol, a port with 500,000 inhabitants of metallurgical combines, which lies between Novoazovsk and the narrow entrance gate to the Crimean Peninsula.

On Saturday, Poroshenko spoke at a meeting of EU leaders in Brussels and called for action to prevent further Russian aggression against Ukraine, the former Soviet Republic, which has been independent for the past 23 years.
"We are approaching a point from which there is no return," Poroshenko warned.
There are now thousands of foreign military units and hundreds of foreign tanks on the territory of Ukraine.
The EU summit did not take any definitive steps - the leaders call for further sanctions against Russia in the event of an unspecified escalation of the Ukrainian crisis.

Lieutenant Colonel Andriy Lysenko, spokesman for the Ukrainian National Security and Defence Council, told reporters in Kiev on Saturday that Ukrainian soldiers had to withdraw from their positions in Iowa after last week two columns of Russian armoured vehicles and 1,000 military units penetrated the Donetsk area to support the besieged separatists.
The first of 63 reported Ukrainian soldiers captured in Iowa during the Russian invasion were replaced on Sunday by 10 Russian paratroopers captured a week ago inside Ukraine, Lysenko said on Sunday.

de_en: The Prime Ministers of India and Japan met in Tokyo.

India’s new Prime Minister, Narendra Modi, will meet his Japanese counterpart Shinzo Abe in Toko to discuss economic and security relations during his first major foreign visit since his victory in May.
Mr Modi is on a five-day trip to Japan to strengthen economic relations with the third largest economic nation in the world.
Plans for enhanced nuclear cooperation are high on the agenda.
According to reports, India also hopes for a defence cooperation agreement between the two nations.
Police of Karratha arrest 20-year-old after faster motorcycle hunt
A motorcycle was seized after the driver drove it at 125 km/h in a 70 km/h zone and through Buschland to escape the police in Bilbara.
Traffic police in Karratha tried to stop a blue motorcycle this morning after watching it leave a petrol station on Bathdate Road at 125 km/h.
The police report that the driver then ignored the stop signs and continued on Burgess Road before descending into Buschland, where the officials lost sight of it.
The motorcycle and a person who corresponded to the driver's description were later seen at a house on Walcott Way in Bulgarra.
Karratha police accuse a 20-year-old man of ignoring a stop sign and of reckless driving.
He will appear before the court in Karratha on 23 September.
The motorcycle was secured and seized for three months.
George Webster accused of hotel rape in Naim and Pitlochry
A man stands trial for raping women in two hotels.
George Webster, 28, was read the indictment at a hearing of the Supreme Court in Glasgow.
He is accused of raping a woman at Scotland's Hotel in Pitlochry, Perthshire on June 7, 2013.
The indictment states that Webster attacked her while she was "unconscious, asleep, and unable to signal consent."
Webster is also accused of raping a second woman at the Golf View Hotel in Naim, Scotland on 4 May 2014.
Judge Lady Rae set the date for the hearing for 17 November at the Supreme Court in Edinburgh.
Reflection on the very American ideal of labour rights as human rights
Congressmen Keith Ellison and John Lewis have tabled a bill to establish the organization of trade unions as a civil right.
"As trade unions die, so do middle-class jobs," said Ellison, a Minnesota Democrat and deputy chairman of the Progressive Caucus in Congress.
That is why I am proud to present the Employee Empowerment Act together with John Lewis, a civil rights lawyer.

This groundbreaking law gives workers the same legal opportunities for discrimination on the grounds of the organisation of trade unions as for other forms of discrimination - and thus stops anti-union forces.

The addition of the national labour law to create a possibility for workers facing discrimination to organise a trade union representation, to lodge a complaint before a civil court for justice - and to receive compensation or penalties - is a sensible and necessary initiative.
But it is certainly not a radical initiative - at least not by American standards.
In fact, the best way to understand what Ellison, Lewis, and the other sponsors of their bill are proposing is to link back to a very American idea.

Despite the setbacks suffered by trade unions in recent years - in Wisconsin, Michigan and other states across the country - Americans once encouraged countries around the world to recognise, expand and respect labour rights.
There was a time that millions of Americans still remember when this country called democracy, freedom of speech, freedom of the press and the right of association in one breath.

When the United States occupied Japan after World War II, General Douglas Mac Arthur and his staff encouraged the country to adopt a constitution to ensure that the militarized autocracy of Hedki Tojos would be replaced by democracy.

In full awareness of the role of workers and their trade unions in creating a new Japan, they used a language that explicitly recognized that "the rights of workers to unity and to collective bargaining and action are guaranteed."

When the United States occupied Germany after World War II, General Dwight David Eisenhower and his staff urged the Germans to write a constitution that would ensure that Adolf Hitler's fascism would be replaced by a strong democracy.

In recognition of the fact that the workers would have to organize themselves and raise their voice in the new nation, the Germans added a clause which explicitly stated: "The right to form associations to secure and improve the working and economic conditions will be guaranteed to every individual and to every profession or trade.
Agreements that restrict or aim to diminish this right are null and void; measures that derogate from it are illegal.

When former First Lady Eleanor Roosevelt chaired the International Commission on Human Rights, which designed the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, as adopted by the United Nations in 1948 as a global agreement, Roosevelt and the other authors added a guarantee that "every one has the right to form or join trade unions to protect his or her interests."
For generations, Americans have accepted the basic premise that labour rights are human rights.

When this country advised other countries on how to form civil and democratic societies, Americans declared that the right to form a trade union - and that this trade union must then participate in collective negotiations as an equal partner with companies and governments - must be protected.

After these rights were destroyed in America, it is indeed very wise to re-conceive the American ideal that the working population must have the right to unite and to be heard in a free and open society.
As Pastor Martin Luther King Jr. said fifty years ago:
History is a great teacher.
Now everyone knows that the workers' movement did not limit the strength of the nation, but enlarged it.
By raising the standard of living of millions of people, work has miraculously created a market for industry and raised the entire nation to unimaginable levels of production.
Those who attack the work forget these simple truths, but history preserves them.
History is remembered and that is what we should do.

The formal recognition of labour rights as human rights - and the extension of the protection of civil rights as protection against discrimination in the creation of workers' representations - is long overdue.
Keith Ellison and John Lewis renew the ideals that made America great in the past and fulfilled the promise of democracy.
Judge temporarily stops law that could force all abortion clinics in Louisiana to close
A U.S. federal judge on Sunday temporarily stopped the implementation of a law in Louisiana, which lawyers say would probably have led to the closure of all five abortion clinics in the state.

This measure, which was introduced by Governor Bobby Jindal of Louisiana in June and is scheduled to enter into force on September 1, would force doctors performing abortions to acquire a patient admission right to a hospital within a radius of 30 miles of their practice.
However, the judge's decision means that doctors can continue to legally perform abortions while they apply for such a right.
"The plaintiffs can continue to work in accordance with the law while they strive to achieve these rights," stated federal judge John deGravelles in his ruling.
Within a month, a hearing will be held for the judge to make a more lasting decision for the law.
Advocates of abortion welcomed the recent decision in a series of rulings against similar measures and said that doctors would thus have more time to obtain hospital admission rights.

"Today's decision means that Louisiana's women are running away from an obscene law that wants to take away their health and rights," said Nancy Northup, president and chairman of the Reproductive Rights Center, which had filed lawsuits on behalf of three of the state's five clinics to stop the law.
It was not immediately clear whether the verdict was also directed at the doctors from the two clinics who did not join the lawsuit and had also applied for admission rights.
Louisiana is one of 11 states that have passed similar laws, with courts recently declaring such measures unconstitutional in Alabama and Mississippi.
Key pieces of legislation in Texas that would have forced the closure of most of the remaining hospitals in the state were stopped by a federal judge on Friday.

Advocates of abortion and the American College of Ostretricians and Gynecologists, as well as the American Medical Association, agree that authorizations from doctors require unnecessary restrictions.
Opponents of abortion oppose the measures aimed at protecting women's health, although some also welcomed the effects of closing hospitals.
Only one doctor who performs abortions in Louisiana has patient information rights, the Center for Reproductive Rights reported.
If all other doctors in the state were forced to stop performing abortions, this doctor would no longer perform the surgery for fear of his safety, the group said.
In their arguments against the verdict, Louisiana state representatives said they would not punish doctors for carrying out abortions while their claims on patient rights would still be binding.
Delays in diagnosis and lack of access to the best treatments lead to higher mortality rates from ovarian cancer in rural areas.
Angelina Jolie and her brother James have posted a video to pay tribute to her mother, who died of ovarian cancer in 2007.
Women in rural Australia have a higher risk of dying of ovarian cancer than women in urban areas.
Researchers analyzed the medical data of more than 1100 Australian women who were diagnosed with ovarian cancer in 2005, and found that only 25 percent were still alive five years after diagnosis.

Research leader Susan Jordan of the QIMR Berghofer Medical Research Institute said that those living in rural and remote areas of the state had a 20 percent higher mortality risk during the study than those living in urban areas.
CLOSE STUDIES: New medicines could slow down lung and ovarian cancer
The researchers examined the medical care of women over seven years.
Dr. Jordan said that the age of a woman at the time of diagnosis, the type of ovarian cancer, pre-existing conditions, and social and economic status also influenced the chances of survival.
For older women and those whose cancer was already further advanced by the time of diagnosis, the survival rate was lowest.
For those living in rural and remote areas of the state, the mortality risk was 20 percent higher during the study than for those living in urban areas.

Although the study did not investigate why women living outside the city were more likely to die of ovarian cancer, Dr. Jordan suspects a delayed diagnosis and lack of access to the best treatment centers as possible factors.
"This disease is best treated by gynaecological oncologists, and they are usually found in larger cities," she said.

Despite improving telemedicine services in order to counteract distances, she proposed, as a possible remedy, strengthening the service of incoming doctors in order to enable specialists to provide women closer to their place of residence, as well as treatment programmes for people outside their region.

Dr. Jordan said that regardless of geographical status, the study revealed a poor long-term survival rate for women with ovarian cancer and underlined the need for better treatment and prevention strategies.
The study, funded by Rio Tinto Ride to Conquer Cancer, is published today in the Medical Journal of Australia.
In March 2013, Elisha Neave, a 33-year-old mother from the Gold Coast, learned that she had an aggressive form of ovarian cancer.
Garden centers regret falling number of homeowners

The decline, combined with an increased decline in the number of homeowners under the age of 35, could lead garden centres to lose tens of thousands of pounds per year if today's young consumers reach the "age group for garden products", according to a study by the HTA, as reported in the Financial Times.
The report states that tenants spend on average 55 percent of what people with homes spend on their gardens.

The rise in the number of people living in highly urbanised areas without gardens, the popular process of asphalting gardens for parking purposes and the declining size of gardens are other factors threatening the industry, in which an estimated £5 billion is put into sales annually.
In the Greater London area, where the share of homeowners has fallen from 61 to 43 percent over a period of 6 years, the lowest expenditure on garden products per household is reported.
The HTA and the Royal Horticultural Society point out that living for rent or small gardens does not mean that people cannot draw plants.
Guy Barter, chief garden advisor for RHS said: "Container gardeners are very popular with tenants, for example, because they can take their plants with them when they move."
The HTA report identified the period between 1997 and 2005 as the "golden age" of garden retailing due to rising number of homeowners and economic prosperity from the late 1980s to the mid-1990s.
He also predicted an improved market situation for this year due to better weather after unfavourable weather conditions in March and April last year.
The protest movement in Pakistan, led by opposition politician Imran Khan and cleric Tahirul Kadri, continues.
In the capital of Islamabad, around 1,000 demonstrators stormed the state television station PTV.

The country's army, meanwhile, calls for a political solution to the conflict "without wasting time and without violence".

Turkey orders US diplomat for spying report
The Turkish Foreign Ministry has submitted to the country's senior U.S. diplomats a report on American and British spying in Turkey.
Deputy Prime Minister Bulent said that the businessman of the US embassy and Turkish officials had discussed the report on Monday.

The German magazine Der Spiegel and online magazine The Intercept reported that the reports by the former US analyst at the National Security Agency, Edward Snowden, show that Turkey was a major area of activity for the US and British intelligence services.
According to Turkish news agencies, Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan downplayed the importance of the report and said that all important countries were spying on each other.
An earlier report that Germany's most important intelligence agency was also in Ankara's sights caused much more angry reactions from the Turkish government.

Police chief of Magaluf accused of corruption
On Friday, the plaintiffs presented to the Office of the Prosecutor of Mallorca evidence of extortion by police and employees of the city of Calvià.
The chief of the police of Calvià on the holiday island of Mallorca was arrested after allegations of corruption by businessmen and bar owners at the notorious bingo-drinking hotspot Magaluf.

Chief Commissioner José Antonio Navarro was arrested by several businessmen from Punta Ballena, the street where most of Magaluf's bars and nightclubs are located, after allegations of corruption against him.

According to the online daily Mallorca Diario, the plaintiffs presented evidence on Friday to the Office of the Prosecutor for Combating Corruption of Mallorca for extortion by policemen and employees of the city of Calvià.
Two other local politicians were arrested by the Spanish Guardia Civil in connection with the allegations of corruption and are being questioned together with Navarro by a judge.
The national Spanish daily ABC reported that the angry nightclub owners stated that the government's pet business had a serious impact on their businesses.
"It's no longer about earning money, it's about survival," one of the businessmen told the court.
Let's get our basics out of the game.
We have nothing to lose.
Magaluf made international headlines this summer due to a viral YouTube video showing an 18-year-old British tourist performing fellatio to 24 men during a suction tour.
Since then, the island authorities have tried to stop the illegal behaviour of alcoholic holidaymakers in Magaluf by minimizing the number of participants in the notorious alcoholic pub tours.
The Playhouse Club, where the felony occurred, was forced to close for a year, while Playhouse and the pub tour organizer Carnage jointly had to pay a fine of €55,000 (73,000).

The tourist town of Magaluf, which is especially popular with young British holidaymakers, is also known for a number of alcohol-influenced accidents, including the trend of "Balconing", where people jump from one balcony to another or from one balcony to the hotel pool.
The first spring day with wet and stormy weather conditions affects flights from Adelaide Airport
The FRÜHLING has brought a winter surprise to South Australia, with heavy storms and strong winds affecting flights from Adelaide Airport.
In the evening until 21 o'clock, another 5mm of rain fell on the city, after 6.6mm, which had already fallen in the night to Sunday.
The last rainfall was the result of a series of short, stormy showers, including a shower that started shortly before 20 o'clock and caused nearly 4mm of rainfall in about 10 minutes.
After winter last week provided an early dose of spring, temperatures in the city fell again on Monday to a peak of only 15.8°C.
The bad weather conditions have probably led to the delayed landing of a Virgin Airlines flight from Melbourne to Adelaide.
The aircraft was supposed to land shortly after 7.30 p.m., but was hit by a gale - a sudden change in wind speed or direction over a short distance - and had to take off.
Winds reached about 50 km/h on the ground at Adelaide Airport at this time.
The flight data showed that the aircraft had to take off on a second landing and finally set up at about 20.40 a.m.
The delay resulted in the delay of several other flights, including an Emirates flight from Dubai and a Quantas flight from Sydney.
Adelaide is forecast to have a peak temperature of 16°C on Tuesday, with possible showers.

Israeli children return to schools after the war in Gaza

Thousands of Israeli children from the areas near the Gaza Strip returned to schools on Monday after spending the summer in air-protected areas, while rocket and mortar fire fell on their communities during the 50-day war between Israel and Hamas, and schools in Gaza remained closed while the area recovered from the fighting.
The start of the school brought a sense of joy and anticipation to the communities in southern Israel marked by rocket holes, but the signs of the fighting are still fresh.
In the southern city of Ashdod, employees of the "Pashosh" kindergarten, which was hit by a rocket, removed grenades from the walls and armored walls before the students arrived.
"We're a little scared, but excited," said Ronit Bart, a Kibbutz Saad resident and English teacher there.
Many children from our area urgently need to return to a routine.
Her 11-year-old daughter Shani Bart said it felt "a bit funny" to suddenly go back to school.
"These were difficult times, and we didn't leave the house at all," she said.
President Reuven Rivlin visited the Kibbutz near the border with Gaza to offer his support.

Until a ceasefire ended the war last week, thousands of residents of border communities like Saad remained in their homes or left their homes in order to move to safer areas further away from Gaza and escape the rocket and mortar fire.
Many residents of Nahal Oz, a community near the Gaza border where a four-year-old boy was killed by a Palestinian gunman, are still hesitant to return.
The Ministry of Education reported that about a dozen families had not returned.
Their children were temporarily accommodated in other schools.
Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu visited a school in Sderot, a Gaza border town heavily marked by Palestinian bombings.
He appealed to the children to learn a lot and said, "We will ensure that you acquire knowledge and provide you with security."
Israel and Hamas agreed last Tuesday to an unconditional ceasefire.

The ceasefire brought an immediate end to the fighting, but important problems remain unresolved, such as Hamas' demand for an end to the Israeli-Egyptian blockade of Gaza and the reopening of the air and sea ports in Gaza.
Israel demands the disarmament of Hamas and the handover of the bodies of two Israeli soldiers killed in the fighting.
A new round of indirect talks is expected to start this month in Egypt.
More than 2,100 Palestinians, three quarters of them civilians, and at least 494 children were killed in the war, according to estimates by the Palestinians and the UN.
Israel disputes this information and estimates that at least half of those killed are fighters, but has not provided any concrete evidence for this information.
On the Israeli side, 66 soldiers and six civilians, including a Thai worker, were killed.
Hamas and other fighters in Gaza fired 4,591 rockets and mortar grenades at Israeli cities during the fighting, most of them in the south of the country.
Meanwhile, the Israeli military carried out more than 5,000 air and other attacks.
The Israeli attacks damaged or destroyed thousands of homes in the Gaza Strip, and about 250,000 people sought refuge in more than 100 UN schools, which were converted into temporary shelters.
While tens of thousands of people continue to live in the shelters and the fighting continues, the education authorities postponed the start of the school year last week.

"I hope the school will be reopened soon so that we can continue to learn like the children in the world and the Jewish children," said Mohammad Amara, a 13-year-old boy who currently lives in a school in Gaza City.
After elections in Saxony: CDU-Vize Strobl questions NPD ban procedures
In the light of the NPD's vote losses in Saxony, CDU-Bundesvize Thomas Strobl has called for an end to the ongoing NPD-Prohibition proceedings before the Federal Constitutional Court.
Berlin - According to CDU-Bundesvize Thomas Strobl, the ongoing prohibition proceedings against the NPD should be brought to an end before the Federal Constitutional Court.
"The NPD is doing worse than the last time," Strobl, who is also CDU head of state in Baden-Württemberg, told the "Leipziger Volkszeitung".
This is a welcome development in the right direction and one that leads me to the conclusion that the NPD should be fought politically and not before the Constitutional Court.
The NPD failed at the vote on Sunday by just under five percent.
A first call for a ban on the far-right party failed in 2003, because the constitutional protection at the time also had informants in the NPD headquarters.
In December 2013, the Federal Council, after a long preparation, submitted a new application in Karlsruhe.
The Federal Government and the Bundestag did not join.
Harburg: Tents for new refugees
At Neuländer Platz refugees are now being housed in tents.
The Central Emergency Reception Centre for Refugees in Harburg stands out.
Now the interior authorities have set up three tents next to the Red Cross.
The district politicians were only briefly informed - they are not very enthusiastic.

"These Hauruck actions further discourage citizens and do not give district politicians the opportunity to contribute constructively to the humane accommodation of refugees," says Britta Herrmann, Green Group Chairman at the Harburg District Assembly.
Its party demands that the Harburg District Administration provide unused housing at present.
96 refugees can be accommodated in the three tents.
The reasons for the overcrowding at first instance are the influx of people seeking help - and the fact that the authorities are unable to provide sufficient seats in follow-up facilities.
Many refugees therefore stay longer than the regular three months.
House prices have experienced the strongest rise in winter in seven years, a widely observed index shows.
The RP Data CoreLogic Hedonic Home Value Index for homes in the Australian capital rose by 1.1 percent in August, according to the RP data from Monday.
Through this increase, the total increase in June, July and August is 4.2 percent, the largest increase in winter months since 2007.
The annual price rise was 10.9 percent, more than twice as high as the rise in the 12 months up to August 2013, but the increases were not evenly distributed across the country.
The research director of RP Data, Tim Lawless, shared that Sydney and Melbourne are driven by a two-tier market.
The figures from RP Data show that house prices in Sydney rose by 16.1 percent last year, while in Melbourne by 11.7 percent.
The following markets are Adelaide, Brisbane and Darwin, where prices rose by five and six percent on average.
At the other end of the scale is Canberra, which was hit hard by cuts in government spending and where prices rose by only 1.4 percent over the year.
Mr Lawless further said that with the beginning of spring, there would now be an increase in the real estate on sale for the next few months, which would subject the market to "a real test".

"If you look at the persistently high auction price rate, a generally fast selling rate and the persistently low interest rate environment, it is likely that home prices will rise even further in the next three months," he said.

German economy shrinks by 0.2 percent in spring
The crises around the globe have slowed the German economy in the second quarter.
Gross domestic product declined by 0.2 percent from April to the end of June 2014 compared to the previous quarter.
This was reported by the Federal Statistical Office, which confirmed preliminary calculations.
Consumption alone stimulated the economy in the spring, while investment declined.
Foreign trade also slowed down the economy.
Thanks to the strong start of the year, GDP for the first half of the year totals a 0.8 percent rise compared to the second half of 2013.

Konstantin Wecker's mercilessly honest memoirs

It is actually more a philosophical testimony than a biography, which Konstantin Wecker, songwriter, pacifist, politically conscious activist, ex-prisoner, put on paper in "Mönch und Krieger" on 287 pages.
Not chronologically, but more thoughts for thoughts, the Municher, born on 1 June 1947, has written down his memoirs, each chapter initiated by a suitable song text.
And he is ruthlessly honest: From the Onanie as a gymnast to the theft of shops and drug consumption, he does not expose human weakness.
Also to show how he himself learned tolerance in dealing with his fellow human beings.

Broad space also incorporates abstract but all the more important concepts: love, soul, ego, being in the present, spirituality - all of which he tries to get to the bottom of, in a very philosophical but also very personal way.

And he also explains his pacifism, his social criticism, his political commitment - and also how not only music has shaped him (the opera lover has become a soul and rock musician), but also his imprisonment.
The latter has also brought the living man Konstantin Wecker closer to the asketic monk, who is "created by subtraction", as he says, "by leaving behind everything unnecessary".

Between all the high-spiritual views, however, there are also short anecdotes about the earth: for example, about beatings in a local frequented by GIs, or a crazy car ride in which he pointed frontally at a tree.
Again, he is mercilessly honest.

Huthi rebels block roads in Yemen's capital
In the conflict between Shiite Huthi rebels and the Yemeni government, the Huthi have called for civil disobedience in the capital Sanaa.
Huthi followers had occupied central streets in Sanaa on Monday, a spokesman for the Huthi party "Ansar Allah" said.
Access to Parliament was also blocked.
Yemeni media reports a traffic jam in the capital.
According to the online edition of the newspaper "Yemen Post", Huthi leader Abdulmalik al-Huthi had called for the measures on Sunday evening.
According to the paper, Huthi threatened to escalate the conflict further if his demands were not met.
The Shiite Huthis fight for more independence from Sunni-ruled Yemen and demand the government's resignation.
The Huthi people have been besieging the Yemeni capital for almost two weeks.
Around 30,000 rebels have set up protest camps on the major access roads of Sanaa.
Around the country there are bloody battles with the Yemeni army.
Kenya registers officials to suppress "spiritual workers"
Kenya has begun to biometrically register all government officials in order to remove "spiritual workers" from the government's payrolls.
Employees who do not register in the next two weeks would no longer be paid, a government statement said.
The government suspects that thousands of people will still receive salaries after leaving the public service.
When President Uhuru Kenyatta took office in 2013, he pledged to fight corruption in the public service.
An audit earlier this year found that at least $1 million (£700,000) per month was lost in payments for "spiritual employees" and other misleading financial practices.
The government suspects that salaries will continue to be paid on accounts after a person has died or leaves the public service, Wanyama Chebusiri reports to the BBC from Nairobi.
All officials must now appear at identification centres within the next two weeks to ensure that their data is recorded via biometric registrations, a government message said.
Anyone who would not do so without a credible apology would be removed from the payroll, the statement continued.

"This process will make a significant contribution to rationalising the public service by establishing the actual number of officials and also adjusting the payroll at both levels of government - eliminating the'spiritual staff'," said Anne Waiguru, Cabinet Secretary at the Ministry of Decentralization and Planning.
The scandal surrounding the art consultant Helge Achenbach will be tried for the first time in court on November 11.

When cyclists take a break on their tour in Bad Salzhausen or Schotten, this in itself is nothing special.

Berkeley declares housing market "normal" again
One of London's most prominent developers pointed out that the housing market in the south-east of England has "returned" to normal levels.

Homes in the capital were highly sought after and subject to massive price increases, which prompted the Bank of England, due to widespread fear of a credit crunch, to impose limits on mortgage loans in June.

Tony Pidgley, founder and CEO of the high-end construction company Berkeley, said on Monday, "Since the beginning of the current fiscal year, the market has returned to normal transaction levels since its peak in 2013," adding that this offers a "stable operating environment."
The real estate market in London was well positioned during the downturn, as foreign buyers pushed into the capital.
Prices in the city area alone jumped by 18.5 per cent last year, far more than the average increase in England and Wales as a whole, according to the Agency.
Average sales prices at Berkeley's private, affordable, and student offerings increased by about a fifth last year and stood at £423,000 at the end of April.

However, a stronger pound in recent months has made real estate in London less attractive to foreign buyers - some of them have also been deterred by the introduction of new real estate taxes and political rhetoric about a possible "visa tax" before the general elections next May.

London real estate agent Foxtons warned last week that the April mortgage market report, which introduced tighter lending rules, would also lead to lower market growth in both real estate sales and prices in the second half of the year.
New Bank of England data from Monday shows a decline in mortgage approval in July, which also indicates that the real estate market is cooling down.

Hamptions International, another real estate agency, corrected its forecast for the rise in London real estate prices for 2015 down to 3 percent, based on an already weakening household price awareness.
Transaction volumes in London's most expensive areas such as Chelsea, Mayfair and Kensington have dropped by a quarter year on year, said broker WA Ellis.
Nevertheless, Berkeley's desire for a home in the capital is a blessing, as the amounts due for scheduled sales amount to more than £2.2 billion.
Mr. Pidgley added: "The demand for the right, well-planned product at the best locations has remained stable, and as a result, sales have also remained stable."
In June, the company reported that it had sold 3,742 new homes in the year up to the end of April - almost a third more than the 2007 peak before the crisis.
Annual pre-tax revenue increased by 40 percent to £280 million annually, and sales by 18 percent to £1.6 billion.
In a statement Monday before the Company's Annual General Meeting, Mr. Pidgley said that Berkeley's revenues for the current year are expected to meet current market expectations.
Analysts consistently estimate the annual pre-tax result at £450 million.
Berkeley shares stood at £23.96 in the London Stock Exchange in the afternoon.

Official representatives of the military in Lesotho refused to plan a coup to overthrow the government and said they were against policemen accused of arming political fanatics.
Prime Minister Thomas Thabane fled the country and reported that the country's army had surrounded his residence and occupied government buildings in the capital Maseru.
The prime minister brought his family to neighboring South Africa after he had reported threats of assassination.
Military spokesman Major Ntlele Ntoi said that there was de facto no coup, but that the military responded to the threat posed by "political fanatics" whose weaponization by the police was imminent.

"What happened this morning was that the Task Force of Lesotho's Defense Forces acted after receiving several intelligence reports that within the police there were elements who actually wanted to arm some of the political, party-political young fanatics who were just about to cause devastating damage," he told Voice of America.
South African government spokesman Clayson Monyela said the military action had given the impression of a coup.
"Even though no one has claimed to have raped the government, all reports agree that the activities of the Lesotho Defense Forces so far show signs of a coup," he said.

Production in the euro area at a 13-month rate
Growth in production in the eurozone slowed to the lowest point in the last 13 months in August, according to a closely observed study.
The final productivity purchasing manager index (PMI) fell to 50.7 in August, up from 51.8 in July.
A figure of over 50 indicates an expansion.
New orders returned and factories experienced breakdowns at a time of rising tensions between the EU and Russia over Ukraine.
The figures come before the meeting of the European Central Bank (ECB) on Thursday.
Markets expect the Bank to provide a clear plan for dealing with a delayed recovery in the euro area and for the impending deflation at an inflation rate of only 0.3%.

There is speculation that the head of the ECB, Mario Draghi, could give further details this week as to whether he is considering a quantitative easing for the euro area, in line with those made by the United Kingdom and the United States during the financial crisis.

"While small growth is better than no growth at all, the braking effects of increasing economic and geopolitical uncertainty have become clearer for manufacturers," said Rob Dobson, senior economist at Markit.
The factory PMI for Germany, Russia's largest trading partner in the EU, fell to its lowest level in 11 months at 51.4.
Meanwhile, in the bloc's second largest economy, France, the PMI fell to 46.9.
France remains a child of concern, as does Italy’s decline from a solid expansion to stagnation.
Indications that growth incentives in the key industrial mechanism in Germany, Spain and the Netherlands are no longer in place are also discouraging," said Mr Dobson.
The decline in industry is likely to fuel the fire of analysts expecting further monetary or fiscal stimulus.
Positive news came from the Republic of Ireland, where the PMI rose to 57.3, the highest level since the end of 1999.

Howard Archer, chief economics expert at IHS Global Insight, said, "The best thing to say about the Eurozone's manufacturing purchasing manager index in August is that the sector will continue to grow afterwards."

He added: "Producers in the euro area are obviously finding life quite difficult at the moment, as the current heightened geopolitical tensions - particularly with regard to Russia and Ukraine - are exacerbating uncertainties in the still difficult conditions in many countries.

These increased uncertainties have clearly affected the economy - in particular, and consumer confidence - and are likely to lead to some orders being delayed or even cancelled, especially large orders.
He said it "will always be more likely" that the ECB will eventually have to initiate some kind of QE, "although we suspect this will be limited."

4 tips for better underwater photos and videos
If you would like to take photos or videos underwater, there is a selection of devices.
The cheapest option is a waterproof point-and-shoot like the Nikon Coolpix AW120 or an action camera like the GoPro Hero3+ Silver Edition, both of which cost about $300.
I took these photos at a family party with several cameras, all available at a price below $350.
Regardless of the equipment, there are a few rules for the best results.
Check your equipment twice.
Even if you have a waterproof camera, make sure that the battery compartment and other compartments are close.
Add your camera to the photos or videos you want to record.
Some cameras and camcorders have scene and recording modes that optimize the exposure time for damp underwater conditions.
And before jumping in, check to what depth your equipment is functional.
Some cameras are only allowed for up to 5 feet, others up to 50 or 60 feet.
Search in our shopping guide and reviews for digital cameras for conventional and waterproof models.
Make multiple shots - because many will not clap.
Point-and-shoot cameras have an LCD with which you can compose pictures, action cameras normally do not.
Even if you have an LCD, it is difficult to see this underwater, and the correct image setting is a matter of luck.
So take many pictures.
If your camera has a row mode that allows you to take a series of shots with slightly changed exposure settings, use it.
Stay close to the surface.
The light gets dramatically worse as you move away from the surface.
So if possible, stay close to the surface when taking pictures in a pool, lake or sea.
This also allows you to bring more color into your photos; the deeper you go, the less color you will see.
Get close to the objects.
This is also good advice on land, but it is all the more important underwater because of the poor light conditions.

It's especially important when working with an action camera: these devices often have a fixed wide-angle lens, which means that you have to get closer to your objects if they are to fill the entire frame.
Andrew Lawson was a man of the sort whose character changed things, even in such a gigantic organization as the NHS.
As an advisory anesthesiologist, he devoted his career to the task of saving the sick both the agony of illness and the pain of treatment.
Among his patients, his wife recalls, was a MI6 employee who had to live with the devastating effects of torture.
Lawson knew that the diagnosis and diseases are important to doctors, while the treated are mainly concerned with something completely different: pain.
One day in 2007, however, he was the one whose path of suffering began.
"I didn't feel it," he wrote in May this year.
I had difficulty getting upset.
As he struggled with the flu-like symptoms, he noticed that he was reluctant to accuse his wife Juliet.
"I want everything sooner than later," he noted.
When Juliet was on a business trip for a week, Lawson felt uncommonly and unreasonably worried.
Something was in the air.
He asked a colleague to take a x-ray of his chest.
Only two weeks ago he had been skiing in the French Alps.
The results of the X-ray examination were available.
He suffered from mesothelioma, an incurable cancer that attacks the breast skin, that is, the skin that covers the lungs.
As with most cancers, the exact cause is usually difficult to determine.
While, for example, some smokers have lung cancer, not all lung cancer patients have been smokers before.
But mesothelioma is different.
In almost all cases, the trigger is an asbestos load - contact with the fiber material, which was once considered a "miracle" but has now been recognised as deadly.
For most of us, mesothelioma is a disease that can easily be ignored.
Asbestos is finally a product of the past.
The most dangerous type of asbestos has not been used in the UK since the 1960s, when the industry voluntarily undertook not to use it anymore.
Even where it was still used, only people in certain industries worked directly with the material - gluers, construction workers, room workers and shipyard workers, for example.
As an industrial hazardous substance from a different time, it seems hardly worrying today.
But this self-satisfaction is inappropriate.
Britain, it seems, is experiencing the peak of a mesolithiom epidemic today.
There are more deaths due to mesothelioma here than in any other country in the world.
With a total of 2,500 deaths per year, twice as many people die from this disease as from traffic accidents.
Annual figures of mesothelioma deaths since 1980 and projected future deaths in the United Kingdom
The reason why we are experiencing the deadly effects now, although asbestos has been illegal for years (all asbestos types were banned in 1999), is that a mesothelioma develops only after decades.
And the mesothelioma gypsy is not limited to former workers in the construction industry.
Asbestos was, and is often still, present in the houses in which we live, the offices in which we work, the schools in which we learn and the shops in which we shop.
And therefore Mesotheliom knows no class barriers, financial limits, professions or age.
The privileged bastions, from elegant shopping malls in London to private schools, are not a safe haven.
The parliament buildings are asbestos-free.
Even in hospitals, where we are supposed to get healthy, this deadly carcinogen has already been identified as a starting point.
Andrew Lawson was not old.
He was not a stickler either.
It was indeed difficult for him to imagine where he might have come into contact with asbestos.
Then he found out.
"It looks like there was a lot of asbestos in the tunnels at Guy's Hospital, where I completed my training for six years," he wrote.
All - students, nurses, doctors and pharmacists - use the tunnel.
One wonders, how many of my fellow elderly people will suffer from the same disease?
Unfortunately, he was able to answer this question at least partially.
"Of the four doctors who were trained at Guy's Hospital and who suffered from mesothelioma in the last five years," he wrote in a 2010 letter, "I am the last one who is still alive."
How many of us are still going to get sick?
Andrew Lawson was diagnosed with mesothelioma at the age of 48.
When he died on February 17, this year, he was 55.
This was an unusually long survival period.
Fifty percent of all mesothelioma patients die within 8 months of diagnosis.
The disease always ends deadly.
We can therefore only repeat Lawson's question: "How many of us are still going to get sick?"

The leading British expert on mesothelioma, Professor Julian Peto, estimates that between 1870 and 2050, when the asbestos epidemic in the UK is expected to come to an end, a total of 90,000 people will be affected by the disease.
Most of them at the moment have no idea that they will die like this.
Asbestos mines in Quebec, Canada Alamy
A brief look at the court files to which victims often turn for damages claims shows how widespread the plague of mesothelioma is already.
In June of this year, Marks & Spencer admitted, for example, that Janice Allen had improperly exposed herself to asbestos.
She worked for the chain for nine years, from 1978 to 1987, and was responsible for the clothing department at two locations, one of which was the flagship store on Oxford Street.
Mrs. Allen was only 18 years old when she started working at M&S.
Now she has two children in her twenties.
"Before this thing," she says, "I've never heard of mesothelioma, I didn't even really know anything about asbestos.
I never thought this would happen to me.
There are very few people who know a lot about asbestos.
The fact is that the term asbestos does not refer to a substance, but to a group of six minerals.
The name comes from the word "Asbestiform", a description of the fiber structure that makes the fabric resilient and flexible.
Three of the six were used in the construction industry.
Chrysotile, also known as white asbestos, is today by far the most common asbestos found in buildings.
It has been used for roof panels, floor panels, pipe insulation, boiler insulation, even for brake coverings in cars.
It is less deadly than other asbestos forms, but is nevertheless regarded by the EU and WHO as a "large health risk" with potential deaths.
However, the more dangerous are the brown asbestos (Amosit) and the blue asbestos (Krokydolith).

Britain was once the world's largest importer of brown asbestos, and experts suspect that "it gives clear, but indirect, indications that this was a major reason for the uniquely high mesothelioma rates."
An employee of Marks & Spencer was exposed to asbestos at the flagship store in Oxford Street, London Alamy
Janice Allen may not have seen herself as a typical mesothelioma victim, but the work of Julian Peto indicates that her story is not unusual.

He has presented a study of the affected in which it is presented that "a significant proportion of mesothelioma without known interruption by work or at home was probably caused by asbestos contact in the environment."
According to him, most of these contacts are based on the "normal use and ageing" of our buildings.
It looks like no one can assume to be safe.
A report by Goddard Consulting, which examined the Palace of Westminster, shows how people, even in the heart of the government, could have been unwittingly exposed to the substance.

In 2009, Goddard reported that the service bays and pipelines behind Parliament's committee rooms were contaminated with asbestos, whose deadly fibres could be wiped out by something as harmless as "strong air movements".
Members of Parliament are often accused of taking care of their own interests, but here it looks like the opposite is happening.

While the directive of the Parliamentary Labour Service insisted that Westminster Palace received a "clean health certificate", it is now clear that £1 billion of work over several years will have to be spent to renovate Parliament, modernise electrical installations and remove asbestos, and that after the 2015 general elections, MEPs will probably meet in the nearby QE2 conference centre rather than on the green benches in Westminster.
The Goddard report also pointed out that "the presence of asbestos was not handled in accordance with the relevant provisions."
No one can know if this mismanagement will cost lives.
All you can do now is wait.
One person who could never accurately determine contact with asbestos is Graham Abbott, a general practitioner.
As Andrew Lawson suspects, the 50-year-old Abbott was exposed to asbestos during his work in hospitals.
"I worked in a hospital where asbestos lawsuits were passed positively," he says, "but I cannot prove it in my case.
It is so difficult to remember all the places where you worked and the data.
What he remembers exactly is the day at the beginning of December 2009, when he got this kind of fever.
He was 45, and had just undergone an operation late in the evening.
Suddenly I had shotgun rust.
It came all of a sudden.
I felt terrible.
I thought I couldn't make the journey home any more.
As a doctor Abbott knew that the pain from the chest skin, the skin around his lungs.
But like Janice Allen, he had no reason to suspect a mesothelioma.
He did not go to work for a month.
Surprised doctors took X-rays of his chest and used pleuracathethers to extract fluid from his lungs and test it in the laboratory.
His complaints, however, remained undiagnosed.
His health improved slowly, and he returned to his workplace.
However, from time to time the symptoms returned, often after sporting activity and heavy breathing.
In 2011, a patient Abbotts came to his clinic with similar symptoms and was later diagnosed with mesothelioma.
But even now Abbott did not associate this with his own case.
Finally, his patient was several decades older and had worked directly with asbestos.
The connection in the case was clear.
In September 2011, Abbott's condition deteriorated again and his home doctor brought his CT scans and X-rays to an expert group.
In December 2011, exactly two years after Abbott felt sick for the first time, a camera-equipped probe was launched into the cave between the ribs and chest.
I am an optimist.
Most of the time I just keep going," he says.
Honestly, I hadn't worried so much at all.
But Rachel, my wife, was worried.
The result of the biopsy was in the week between Christmas and New Year: "I was told it was mesothelioma."
Graham Abbott: Diagnosis of mesothelioma
Suddenly Abbott had appointments with Macmillan's nurses, one of whom advised him to get a lawyer.
Only now did he understand the extent of the epidemic.
"It turned out that asbestos was very widespread, especially in large public buildings where pipes were often isolated with asbestos," he says.
People who were exposed to asbestos in these buildings are now getting sick.
And so Mesotheliom now meets younger people who have not worked in the typical professions.
The most dangerous tubes with asbestos insulation in hospitals were underground, so patients were probably not exposed to the substance.

But many employees who moved from one building to another in pedestrian tunnels (like Andrew Lawson) or ate in underground canteens (as Graham Abbott often did) were most likely to come into contact with the toxic substances.
It turns out that for several decades after the war hospitals may have been life-saving for patients, but life-threatening for the doctors treating them.
It is still removed today.
Students put their bunsenbrenners on asbestos mats.
And it is not just about hospitals.
Due to its fabulous insulating and flammable properties, asbestos has often been used in offices, shops, libraries and city halls.
Schools too.
In fact, many people probably had their first contact with asbestos in the classroom.
Throughout the country, in thousands of chemistry classes, students have put their toothbrushes on asbestos mats.
The topic of asbestos in schools is now frequently mentioned on websites.
And meanwhile, asbestos is standardly contained in innocuous objects in our houses, such as floor tiles or ceilings.
"It's an industrial poison that is contained in large parts of our real estate," notes Andrew Morgan, the lawyer Andrew Lawson represented in his trial against Guy's Hospital.
In one case, the only contact a woman encountered was the demolition of a garden shed in the 1970s.
So adjust how you cut your garden chucks.
The impact of the diagnosis, and the knowledge that the disease is incurable, is immense.
"It takes a while to process that," says Graham Abbott.
I went back to work and tried to continue, but I noticed that I couldn't focus on what I was doing.
I was in practice for two weeks.
Then I knew I had to go and take care of myself.
Well, I won't see another Christmas party.
With the greatest difficulty was the change of perspective from the position of a doctor to that of a patient.
Like countless patients before him, he remembers how overwhelmed he was by all the information he had to deal with.
"It was very difficult to record all this," he says.
"I asked my doctor, "How long do I have yet?"
And I was given about 12 months.
I remember thinking, "Well, I'm not going to experience another Christmas party.
That was it then.""
Mesothelioma is particularly harmful because it is our life support mechanism - breathing itself - that causes the deadly cancer.
Most cases of mesothelioma are caused by asbestos contact.
Asbestos consists of the smallest fibers.
When the asbestos is unwrapped and the fibers are inhaled, they can be embedded in the breast skin, the skin around the lungs.
Asbestos fibers irritate breast skin and can cause cell mutations.
"The problem arises with the inhaled needle-shaped asbestos fibres," says Professor Tom Treasure, a heart-to-horax doctor who moved to Guy's Hospital in 2001.
The very hospital Andrew Lawson suspects has exposed him to asbestos is now, ironically, a leading centre in the treatment of mesothelioma.
Treasure knew Lawson and treated some others who were probably also exposed to asbestos during their training at the hospital.
As soon as the asbestos needles reach the lung tissue, Treasure says, "they will be pushed to the edge where the skin is from the breathing process.
It is naturally invasive from the beginning.
The usual options for other cancers do not work as well for mesothelioma.
For example, the effectiveness of an operation is highly controversial.
Some think it is worth a try.
Treasure denies this.
"You can't cut out the breast skin," he says.
They don't come around with the knife.
Meanwhile, cancer "does not speak very well on chemotherapy," which "shows efficacy", but does not cure.
"Sometimes there are long-term survivors," Treasure says.
But in the end they all die.
Fortunately, some patients actually live longer, much longer than expected.
The author Stephen Jay Gould died 20 years after the diagnosis.
Two and a half years after his own diagnosis, Graham Abbott is still struggling.
After contacting Mesotheliom, Abbott contacted Andrew Lawson, who, four years after his diagnosis, had become a one-man support and advisory office for clients.
"Hello, Cancer Center," he said cheerfully when called.
"He was very positive," says Abbott.
He had received his diagnosis four years earlier and was still very active.
Initially, Abbott had been offered six chemotherapy cycles, which would last four months and would probably extend his life by only one month.
"I was desperate," he says.
I wanted to give up.
Lawson, however, managed to "show things in a somewhat more positive light."
After consulting several doctors, Abbott decided to continue his treatment with Prof. Loic Lang-Lazdunski, a cardiothorax specialist at Guy's.
"We had an advantage because I didn't have to be redirected, I just called and got an appointment," Graham admits.
A normal patient would have to receive a transfer and wait for treatment approval.
Money is crucial for mesothelioma sufferers to be able to realize the best available therapies.
But when these treatments eventually inevitably fail, many affected people are left with another financial worries - about the future of the families who leave them behind.
And so they turn to the courts in the hope of compensation.
Andrew Lawson contacted Andrew Morgan of Field Fisher Waterhouse LLP.
"It has been known since 1898 that asbestos is extremely dangerous for health," says Morgan.
But what changed in the 1960s was that it was recognized that even a very low load posed a health risk.
And here the negligence of the companies started to play a role.

Andrew Lawson and Guy's Hospital eventually filed their case, but it was not what Morgan calls "full compensation", as Lawson could not prove with absolute certainty that his mesothelioma was due to asbestos contact at Guy's.
After the investigation into his death, however, a Guy's spokesman confirmed that "the asbestos fibres in the affected basement area were removed in the 1990s."
It was too late for Andrew Lawson.
How to remove asbestos
In fact, it is a huge problem for mesothelioma sufferers seeking compensation to attribute the deadly asbestos contact to a company or a workplace - usually decades after the incidents.
Many of their former employers have been sold or closed.
Insurance documents can be lost.
And those who defend themselves against claims know that the time is right for them, but certainly not with the plaintiffs.
In response, this year there were clear new legislation that makes it easier for mesothelioma patients to sue for compensation, even if their former employers are no longer to be found.
The law has set up a £350 million fund, funded by the insurance industry, for anyone who has been diagnosed after July 2012 to be able to prove a contact, but not to sue anyone.
In these cases, the plaintiffs receive 80 per cent of what a court could have promised them in a normal damages process - about £120,000.
Approximately 300 successful applications for the programme are expected per year.
Andrew Morgan thinks, like so many mesothelioma patients, that £350 million was a "very good job" for the insurance industry.

"This is a deal between insurers and insurers," he says, indicating that this is a quarter of what insurers would have had to pay if time hadn't gone by and mesothelioma sufferers would have found the companies and could have filed a lawsuit normally.
Mike Penning, then Minister of Labour and Pensions, also admitted that the law was "not perfect".
But both Penning and Morgan admitted that, in the face of seven deaths a day, rapid action was needed.
"People are suffering so much and need help today," Penning said during the second hearing of the Mesotheliom Act last December.
At that time, Graham Abbott had been in the hands of Prof. Loic Lang-Lazdunski for 19 months.
After their initial consultations, Lang-Lazdunski recommended an operation that he expected to have a positive effect, unlike Tom Treasure.
This was accompanied by radiation therapy and chemotherapy - a triple therapy, with which Lang-Lazdunski can present a survival rate of up to 40 percent over five years.
Abbott felt strengthened.
"That's of course the most important thing," says Abbott.
You see this again and again in patients.
There is something that keeps you going.
If you give up, you'll get worse very quickly.
Graham Abbott underwent surgery in March 2012.
At the end of August he had the last of the six chemotherapy cycles behind him.
Postoperative scans showed no signs of the disease.
Then I had a scan in March 2014.
There were several cancer spots around my chest.
I just turned 50.
This is not life-threatening.
This is life-threatening.
Abbott underwent six chemotherapy cycles again.
Now no trace of the tumors is visible.
But the process is physically and psychologically very stressful.
You need to think about practical things - about the money when I'm gone, for example, or show my wife how the boiler time setting works.
If you get bad news, you become negative.
You have to look forward.
As the father of Ellie, 16, and Tamsin, 14, this is not always easy.
"It's hard for parents," he says.
It is difficult to know what to say and how much.
When I received my first diagnosis, I told my girl that I had a disease with which I would not get old.
They reacted very differently.
Tamsin is very loving and uncomfortable.
She told her friends and we soon got a lot of calls.
Ellie was reticent.
She didn't say much.
Such conversations are something that all cancer patients have to go through.
But for patients with mesothelioma such conversations are not conducted by hope, not by a trace of hope for survival.
The illness brings (as in the end also for Stephen Jay Gould) a grim security.
As Andrew Morgan says, "Mesothelioma is not life-threatening.
Body of embalmed Pharaohs wrapped in asbestos clothing
Asbestos fibres used for strengthening cooking pots and for greater heat resistance.
Plinius the Elder describes asbestos.
A fabric has been developed that is not flammable.
I've seen napkins smell of it at parties in the cafes.
The use of modern commercial asbestos begins in Italy, where it is used to produce paper (also banknotes) and fabric.
Important asbestos mines will be opened in Canada and South Africa and shortly thereafter in America, Italy and Russia.
It is the ideal insulating material for steam engines and turbines of the industrial revolution.
Global asbestos production is increasing to more than 30,000 tons annually.
Statisticians at Prudential identify a premature death rate among those working with asbestos, who are no longer insured for life.
Nellie Kershaw dies in Rochdale.
Dr. William Cooke states that asbestos particles in the lung "without any reasonable doubt are the main cause of death".
This is the first case of this kind.
Kershaw's employer, Turner Bros Asbestos, assumes no liability.
No damages will be paid.
During the Second World War, ships were built intensively, one of the deadliest installations with asbestos contact.
Voluntary industry opt-out from blue asbestos imports
An appeals court confirms the first successful claim for compensation for personal injury in the United Kingdom for contact with asbestos.
Global asbestos production is increasing to more than 4,213,000 tons annually.
The United Kingdom imports 139,000 tons.
A health and safety executive in the UK obliges all companies working with asbestos to obtain licenses.
The import and use of blue and brown asbestos is prohibited by law in the UK.
Any use of asbestos is prohibited in the UK.
The Mesotheliom Act is passed in the United Kingdom.
