Asbestos is banned in more than 50 countries, but white asbestos is still used in many countries of the world as a cheap building material.
The worldwide production is about 2 million tons annually.
China denies Hong Kong right to government election, demonstrators swear retribution
On Sunday, despite growing calls for democratic reforms, the Chinese parliament voted against the nomination of candidates for the 2017 elections by the Hong Kong electorate.
This is likely to fuel the long-anticipated protests in Hong Kong's business district, while activists initiated planning and mobilization within hours of the resolution.
The decision of the Chinese People's Congress allows the Communist leaders, in principle, to reject all non-peking candidates.
"This is not unexpected, but it makes us angry," said Emily Lau, a legal expert, chairman of the Democratic Party.
That is not what Beijing has promised.
The inhabitants of Hong Kong have been lied to.
And it is clear that we are dealing with an authoritarian regime.

In his defense of the Chinese decision, Li Fei, Deputy Secretary General of the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress, said approval of public nominations in the Hong Kong government elections would be too "chaotic".
Since 1997, when Great Britain gave back control of Hong Kong to the Chinese, Beijing has pledged to let the inhabitants vote for the government from 2017.

The Chinese leadership presented Sunday's decision as a democratic breakthrough, because Hong Kong's citizens have a direct right to vote, but the decision also makes it clear that the Chinese leadership is keeping the process through a closely controlled nomination committee in its hands.
Under a new clause, only candidates "with love for the country and love for Hong Kong" will be admitted.
The decision follows a summer when some of Hong Kong's largest and most publicly effective protests took place for several years.

Behind the pro-democracy campaign in Hong Kong lies the Occupy Central With Love and Peace movement, whose organisers have threatened to shut down the financial district if Beijing does not allow genuine universal suffrage.
On Sunday evening, within hours of the proclamation, hundreds of Occupy Central supporters had gathered in the rain in front of the government headquarters in Hong Kong.
At the demonstration, the organizers said that their movement had reached a new level of civil disobedience and they were planning protest waves in the coming weeks.
However, they did not give any details, apparently in order to avoid problems with the authorities.

In an online communication, the organizers shared that the movement "has considered the occupation of the central district only as a last resort, an action that should take place only when all the possibilities for dialogue are exhausted and there is no other choice.
We are sorry to have to say that today all the opportunities for dialogue have been exhausted and that the occupation of the central district will definitely take place.

The authorities in Hong Kong have been preparing for the announcement of Beijing for days, and on Sunday in front of the government building there were tightened security measures including police and barricades.
The unrest is exacerbated by the feeling of many in Hong Kong that they are slowly losing control of their city.
The arrival of people from the mainland increases competition for products and services.
Furthermore, there is growing fear that Hong Kong’s values, such as democracy and freedom of speech, will start to crumble under Beijing’s growing pressure.
Some criticized the demonstrations of the Occupy Central Movement as jeopardising Hong Kong's business lifeline.
"The protests they are talking about could cause great economic damage, depending on how many are involved and how long they last," said legal expert Regine Ip, who has long criticized the movement.
We do not want to raise fears that Hong Kong will go out of control.
This impression is bad for investment.
The state-controlled Chinese media also recently reported on the democracy activists in Hong Kong as subversive agents controlled by Western powers.
This summer, activists organised an unofficial referendum on electoral rights, in which 780,000 people took part - more than a fifth of Hong Kong's voters.
In July, tens of thousands took part in one of the largest democracy demonstrations in the history of the region.
The tradition of school graduation balls in the United States is now transferred to universities, where freshmen performances are offered with the private airplane.
We are looking forward to responding to this demand and offering the first luxury travel service in the UK for students of today.
In order to achieve a particularly impressive performance at the university, the company also offers transport options such as private aircraft, Rolls-Royce Phantom, Aston Marten or McLaren P1.
Mr Stewart also stated that the service had a security side.
This service is an ideal alternative for students who would otherwise have to cuddle their habits in a dangerously overloaded car across the country.
Together with our new VIF options, this year we are looking forward to ensuring that students reach the university with a minimum of effort and a maximum of luxury.
A company spokesman said that there were no new bookings as the service had just been introduced, but added that "students would book the service in the coming weeks".
The company also stated that it expects a market for this offer despite the tuition fees of £9,000 per year.

Students today differ greatly in their expectations and demands from students 10, 20, 30 or 40 years ago - it is more important than ever to make a great first impression, and with VIF you can do just that.
The National Student Union, however, criticized the service as cancelled.
Megan Dunn, Vice President of NUS for Higher Education said: "This offer seems completely separate from the lives of the majority of students.

Feminists criticize racial issues and police behaviour after Ferguson
The unarmed teenager was killed by a police officer in Ferguson, Mo. earlier this month.
The participants raised their hands in the air and sang, "Head up, don't shoot," while waiting for the funeral.
Following two weeks of protests in Ferguson, Mo, over the shooting of unarmed teenager Michael Brown, blogger Miriam Zoila Perez noticed a change in online discussions of white feminists.
According to their experience, white feminist commentators put gender before race when it comes to addressing reproductive rights and income inequalities.
However, while tensions in the Middle West rose and received attention throughout the country, Perez saw that white women's responses were 100% about race.

Compared to the responses of black women shortly after the 9 August shootings, the personal essays with titles such as "Gedanken zu Ferguson von einer weißen Frau" and "Feminism is not just about the oppression of women" came relatively late.
But for Perez this meant an important change.
"I don't think there are many people in feminism who talk about whiteness and privilege in such a high-class way," she said.
People felt compelled to express something about the incidents.
It is characteristic of the crisis in which we find ourselves and because the situation in Ferguson is so ethnized that they have to express that.

For English professor Koritha Mitchell of Ohio State University, Ferguson brought to light problems that black Americans face every day, but which are not considered "women's issues" in the cultural space.
"I can post something funny about myself and my partners on Facebook and get 150 likes from everywhere," Mitchell said.
When I post about how colourful people are being besieged in their own country, the silence is astonishing.
"How can it be safe for women to talk publicly about a relationship, but not about security in public?" she asked.
For black women like Mitchell, who have studied race, gender, and sexuality in the history of the United States, there is no dichotomy between race and gender problems.
For them, black women have not had the luxury of separating the topics cleanly; they live every day in a combined reality.

While white women are now linking the issues of race and gender in feminist mainstream circles, Angela Hattery, Professor of Women and Gender Research at George Mason University, says that their predecessors did the opposite.
"Between 1865 and 1890, at least 10,000 black men were lynched and the reason was almost always the rape of a white woman," Hattery said.
White women had to participate in the story to justify the lynching.

For Hattery, the split between white and black women came at the point when white women's election campaigners such as Susan B. Anthony analyzed the country in the late 19th century and found that the struggle for the right to vote could only be successful for one group: women or blacks.
"They made the decision to stand for women's right to vote, and the right to vote for blacks should come later," Hattery said.
When one remembers such things, one becomes powerfully aware of why coloured women do not trust white women.
We have not done our job well.
We have never helped black women protect their husbands and sons.
Even after women were granted the right to vote in 1920, it took another decade for white women to organize against lynching in the Association of Southern Woman for the Prevention of Lynching.
The group was founded almost 40 years after the original request for help from black women, Mitchell says.

For Mitchell, the flood of white feminist responses to the questions raised by Ferguson - police behaviour, racial discrimination - is a reflection of the times when white feminists "played" with the problems that black women have faced for generations.
"Wouldn't it be great if activists who have such traditional feminist platforms took the right to raise a child as seriously as they do with the right to birth control?" asked Mitchell.
Second-generation feminists who built their careers on the struggle for reproductive rights and access to contraceptives are now trying to understand what this means.

The well-known white feminist activist Gloria Steinem went on Facebook two weeks after the shooting of Michael Brown and published a pointed article by Rebecca Carroll, a columnist for the Guardian, in which she demanded more protests from white Americans on the subject of racism.

"I hope that women who have a different but parallel reason to understand a danger inherent in the body - and opinions about race that are clearly different in public polls - will lead to the changes," Steinem wrote.
Although Steinem advocates a more cross-sectional feminism in which race as well as gender issues are addressed, some of her comments on race issues in America are surprising.

Christina Sommers, a researcher at the American Enterprise Institute and author of "Who Stole Feminism?" told She The People that young men in the United States, especially young men of color, "are far more vulnerable than their sisters," but Steinem's remarks about Ferguson contradict her earlier criticism.
There are now hundreds of special programs for girls and young women, but almost nothing for boys.

But when the White House recently launched a small program, My Brother's Keeper, to help vulnerable young black and Hispanic men, there were angry reactions from many feminists, including Gloria Steinem.
The relationship between the police and the black community is not the only problem that is pushing mainstream feminism to the forefront.

After the US Border Police arrested nearly 63,000 unaccompanied minors at the country's southwest border this year, the issue of immigration reform is also on the surface again - this time as a women's issue.

Andrea Mercado, co-chair of We Belong Together, an organization that mobilizes women for immigration reform, said that in order to rethink the issue as an essential women's issue, she simply needed to publish the stories of immigrant women.
"They speak for themselves," Mercado said.
If the vast majority of work visas go to male immigrants, the women who accompany them are in a position where they are vulnerable to domestic violence and exploitation.
"These stories find a resonance in women's organisations," she said.

The city talks of nothing else, and everyone is quite excited.
We thought that such a gain could occur.

Leonidas asked to the Gladiator Arena
Not only the gladiators stood knee-deep in the Matsch during the first Rheinbacher Römertag in the leisure park.

However, the attraction of the event was strong enough to attract far more than 1,000 visitors yesterday, who defied the rain showers and the autumn cold and remained fascinated by the historical spectacle.
There was a colourful chorus of representations, performances, games, exhibition pieces and information about the time of the Romans and their significance for the Rhineland.

The main attraction of the day was undoubtedly the martial fighters troop from the Gladiator School "Amor Mortis", which used every rainy break to demonstrate their robust martial art in the arena prepared with soft sand.
Gladiator owner "Leonidas" proved to be a humorous and wise presenter and sent his men into the ring one after the other for a heroic duel in various Gladiator performances.
At first, the "Provocators" were in line with a right wing shield and a short sword, as well as a leg shield on the left leg and arm shield on the right arm.
It was followed by the "Essedarii" with chest shield, short sword and root plant as well as an iron Gladiator helmet, leg and arm protection.
Particularly impressive was the performance of the "Retiarius", who attacked the "Secutor" with a sword net, a trident and a dove and after a short fight the buffalo fell to the ground.
As the swords struck each other metallicly, the shields scrambled and the plants flew rushing through the arena that could become a fear and a shock for the health of the gladiators.
But the imposing "Summa Rudis", the masculine referee, always had an attentive eye on them.

"We wanted to revive the Roman everyday life and make the culture of the Roman period viable," Lorenz Euskirchen, chairman of the organizer "Freundeskreis Römerkanal", explained the intention behind the spectacle.
After two years of preparation, the theme park became an "Oppidum Romanum", a Roman city for one day, as Deputy Mayor Claus Wehage stated in his greeting.
After all, the Romans brought not only war and conquest into our region, but also Roman culture and numerous buildings that we still admire today.
Remains of it were also to be admired on the Roman day, for example "Aqueduct marble" from the eleven-metre high and 1400-metre long Roman canal bridge, which stood directly at Lüftelberg.
The Frontinus Society faced the water and energy supply once and now, and Managing Director Petra Fricke knew: "Today we still draw benefits from the knowledge of that time".
This is also confirmed by the graduate measuring engineer Ralph Heiliger of the "EngineerteamZwei" from Rheinbach, who presented the Roman measuring instruments such as chorobat, groma or dioptra.
The Roman villa in Blankenheim presented sketches and models from the excavations of 1894 as well as brick stones from the original hypocasus, the hot air heater that once heated the Roman villa.
Impressive are also the footprints left by Wolf and Fox two thousand years ago in the clay footprints before they were burned.
In 2011, the Office for the Conservation of Landmarks of the Landesverband Rheinland excavated the remains of a Roman villa in the North Commercial Park in Rheinbach.
Covering walls of a commercial building with a drain for drying grain and milking have been found.
The building probably belonged to a Villa Rustica, an agricultural estate, archaeologist Dr. Jennifer Morscheiser explained.
She presented a series of finds from these excavations in a glass vitrine, including a large dish, several fine glass vessels and parts of a tiny necklace.
Morscheiser believes that the villa probably existed from the first to the fourth century after Christ, until the Germans invaded the then Roman Rhineland.
In addition, the children engaged in the Roman wind mill game, similar to today's mill game, or they wrote their names with metal handles on wax boards, as the Roman students once did.

At the stand of the Römerthermen Zülpich the children were allowed to put mosaics themselves, at the stand of the glass museum Rheinbach to make glass mosaics and at the stand of the nature center Eifel Nettersheim to use a heavy wheat mill made of stone to grind the flour for a flat bread or a bowl.

The visitors drove through the amusement park with the originally reconstructed Roman carriage drawn by two cold-blüters and passed the impressive stand of the municipal gymnasium, which presented the results of their "Roman Project Weeks".
With a Roman week from 13 to 21 September, the municipality of Wachtberg will also take part in the Rhine-wide Roman Year 2014, which is to commemorate the death of Emperor Augustus 2,000 years ago.

Together with the Homeland and History Associations as well as the Wachtberger Wander-Verein, the Partnershipsverein and the Laienspielkreis Oberbachem, the thematic walks, a lecture, Kochabende and guided tours for school classes will be offered and will remind of the Roman past of Wachtberg.

For example, a Roman legionary will tell about his work on the abandoned Wachtberg, plants will be presented as living monuments from the Roman period and a funny lesson on intercultural understanding between a group of Wachtberger "Germans" and attracted Romans will be presented.
The Adendorf elementary school devotes itself to Roman subjects as part of a project week.
With the Roman Week, the numerous, but often no longer visible, traces of the Romans in Wachtberg are to be re-examined.
In the Wachtberger Rathaus, a small presentation will commemorate the discovery of the Berkumer Matronenheiligtum in 1879.
Ebola: The epidemic burdens West Africa’s economy
The Ebola epidemic in West Africa is also a serious blow to the economy.
Markets are vanishing - and international companies are moving away.
The devastating Ebola epidemic is hitting the West African economy hard.
Crops are rotting in the fields, mines have been abandoned and markets have disappeared - the virus has hit the region hard.
Several international companies are already going a long way.
"The Ebola epidemic is not only a medical crisis, but also an economic one," said the head of the African Development Bank, Donald Kaberuka.
Liberia is hit hardest
"It's a total disaster, we're losing a lot of money," says Alhaji Bamogo, who sells clothing at the second largest market in Liberia's capital, Monrovia.
Only those who want to buy food or something to disinfect against Ebola come to the market.
Liberia is the worst affected by the virus, with more than 600 people suffering from the fever here alone.
Recently, the health authorities declared that the disease had spread to every corner of the country.
The virus has also spread to Guinea, Sierra Leone and Nigeria.
In total, more than 1,500 people have already died, and thousands more were trapped.
Foreign companies deploy employees
Companies operate throughout the resource-rich countries.
Foreign companies such as the steel company Arcelor Mittal are withdrawing their employees, and several international airlines are no longer flying to the affected regions.
Local traders and farmers are also responding: few merchants are leaving their hometowns to buy supplies.
In some areas of Sierra Leone and Liberia, which are subject to quarantine, cocoa and coffee beans on the fields, which are important for export, are being destroyed.
The farmers do not dare to leave their homes for the harvest.
Food is scarce
"People are going to travel less and less," says Phillipe De Vreyer, a Parisian expert on West Africa's economy.
The man, for example, who usually goes to the market and sells his vegetables, prefers to stay home.
The population is therefore experiencing the consequences of the epidemic directly and forcefully: food is becoming scarce.
In the markets, the stock of basic foods such as rice is declining.
At the same time, the region, which is heavily dependent on international companies, threatens to damage its image - with far-reaching consequences.
The biggest danger is that international companies will basically avoid the area for a long time, says Philippe Hugon of French think tank Iris.
It is crucial how far and how long the virus will spread.
Investors may get the impression that "it is dangerous to live in Guinea, Sierra Leone and Liberia and thus to invest," warns Hugon.
The disease also burdens the strained state budgets of the states
The disease also burdens the already strained state budgets of the affected states.
The rating agency Moody's fears that their budgets will be heavily burdened by the high expenditure on the health system and, in addition, by the deteriorating economy.
The African Development Bank has already pledged to contribute $60 million (EUR 45 million) to the health systems of the affected countries.
The effects are already evident in Nigeria, where so far only a few cases of Ebola have been diagnosed.
Although the oil-rich region in southern Niger Delta has not been affected so far.
But elsewhere, many people are already staying at home for fear of infection.
Reservations in hotels are also significantly declining.

The Schützenverein "Tannenwald" Berngau celebrates its 50th anniversary from 12 to 14 September.

Blaskapelle provides for the music
Highlights on Sundays are the festive service and 9.30 a.m. in the parish church and the large festive march at 14 a.m.

The main chapel is the Blaskapelle Berngau.
Mayor Wolfgang Wild and State Secretary Albert Füracker took over the patronage.

The original name "Schützengesellschaft Tannenwald Berngau" comes from 1907, when on March 21, the association for "social entertainment through exercise in room stunts and small rifle shooting" was founded.
The Nazi regime had caused the dissolution of the association in 1937.
Only in 1964, 19 young men found themselves again, who on 30 April baptised the "new" Schützenverein "Tannenwald" Berngau in the Gasthaus Lukas.
Karl March and Adolf Ried led the club through a difficult initial period as shooter champions, primarily in finding a clubhouse and installing the shooting operation.
Already in the autumn of 1965 the Schützenverein started in the Gasthaus "Leininger" with two teams in the round competitions.
In the following years, the sportsmen, who were now organized in seven teams, established themselves in all classes up to the 1st Gauliga.
The club's records were broken every year and the magical limit of 380 rings was first reached in 1980 by Rudi Meier.
Just as the performance of the active guards has increased, the number of members has also developed positively.

After the club's premises "Leininger" have no longer been sufficient to meet the demands of a modern Schützenverein, the then board of directors under the leadership of Johann Rinn decided to create a future domizil in the cellar rooms of the new "Landgasthof Härteis".
On 8 May 1988, after a workload of 2700 hours, Pastor Strasser granted the ecclesiastical blessing for the new guard rooms.
One of the great highlights in the club's history was certainly the 44th Gauschießen, connected with the solemn dedication of the new shotgun in July 1991.
On 23 and 24 April 1994, the Schützenverein celebrated its 30th anniversary.
In 1995, a group of criminals was founded.
Josef Schmalzl became Böller's rapporteur.
A big challenge for the "Böllerer" and for the association as a whole was the direction of the Bayerische Böllertreffen 2005.
In many hours of voluntary work, the members of the association last year have modernised the rooms and the shooting system at the Berngauer Hof and thus brought it to the latest state of the art.
Eleven teams in indoor racing
You can also see the sporting achievements of the Schützenverein.
A total of eleven teams currently participate in the round competitions: six air rifle teams, one air pistol team, one sports pistol KK1, one youth and two AH teams.

The first team with Lars Ellrich, Katharina Ellrich, Steffi Grad and Kerstin Kellermann has risen in the 2013/14 round from the Gauoberliga (highest league in Schützengau ANB) to the District League 1.
The second team with Verena Moosburger Alexandra Meier, Eva Schuhmann and Tobias Graml has moved from the Gauliga Nord to the Gauoberliga.
In addition to shooting, events such as bockstechen, carnival and kingsball, club trips and Christmas celebrations have a tradition.
The guards are also present at the feasts in the parish and community.

Tony Stewart's return to the racetrack ended about halfway through his race at the Atlanta Motor Speedway.
Stewart raced against the wall for the second time after placing his right front tires in lap 172 and ending his evening.

No decision has yet been made as to whether Stewart should face an indictment.

After a restart in round 122, Buschs
Car No. 18 out of control after exiting from curve 2 and collided with Stewart, both cars driving against the wall.

Hundreds of prison workers from all over Bulgaria organised a nationwide protest in front of the Ministry of Justice in the capital Sofia.
In the peaceful demonstration, they reiterated their demands for the restoration of their old working conditions, which have recently been changed.
Higher salaries are also on a demand list to be discussed with the interim Justice Minister Hristo Ivanov.

NATO does not want to break agreements with Russia
NATO will not break its agreement with Russia due to the planned deployments in Eastern Europe as a result of the Ukraine crisis.
NATO Secretary-General Anders Fogh Rasmussen said in Brussels on Monday that NATO adheres to the 1997 NATO-Russia Council founding agreement.
The NATO chief, however, accused Russia of "a gross breach" of the agreement.

Documents and statements from the Russian side indicate that "they regard us as opponents".

Genetic disorder often misdiagnosed
A British woman says she thought she would die as a result of a misdiagnosis over many years.
Karin Rodgers lived almost all her youth in the belief that she had only a few years to live after being diagnosed with another disease.
She actually suffered from Charcot Marie Tooth Disease (CMT) - a group of incurred disorders that damage the nerves outside the brain and spinal cord.
Charity CMT UK shared that misdiagnosis is a common problem in people with CMT because so little is known about the disease.
Approximately 23,000 people in the UK are likely to suffer from CMT, which can lead to motor disorders such as muscle weakness, an insecure gait and crippled toes.
People with the disease also suffer from dizziness or pain. The disease is incurable and progressive, which means that symptoms become worse over time.
When Rodgers was 13, she believed she was suffering from Friedreich-Ataxie (FA) - a disease with very poor chances of survival.
Rodgers thought she would sit in a wheelchair before she was 18 and die before her 30th birthday.
The mother of two children, who is now 51 years old, said, "As a child, I knew I couldn't do the same as the others.
I fell down constantly and everything lasted longer with me.
I could never ride a wheelchair or skateboard with the other children and was often handcuffed at school because of my way of walking and walking.

Rodgers said that at the age of 13, after several operations to relieve her Achilles tendons and stretch her feet, she reviewed her medical records when her doctor left the room and read that she was suffering from FA.
"I felt guilty because I was curious, so I didn't tell anyone, but I went home, looked for the disease in the library and wrote to the FA Society," she said.
When I received the answer, I was shocked and panicked.
I thought I would be in a wheelchair at 18 and die at 25, and slowly lose all my skills in the meantime.
I did all this on my own and planned my own funeral.
She said that when she was 17, she realized that her abilities had not declined as much as she had imagined and asked her doctor.
He simply stood up, embraced me and said, "My love, I don't think you have that, otherwise you'd be in the wheelchair already."
I think you have something far less life-threatening.
After some genetic tests, CMT was found in her.
"When he told me what CMT was, I felt like I was a winner," she said.
Charity CMT UK has launched a CMT Awareness Month to raise awareness of this disease.
Stabsfeldwebel a. D. Berni Diether has been working as a firefighter since the closure of the former military training ground

Since then, the 6,500-hectare area has been the core of the Biosphere area Schwäbische Alb, which is open to hikers and cyclists on 13 marked paths.
Tax burden on businessmen in Washington rises with economic recovery
A recovery of the economy means more customers, more sales and new jobs.
It also means higher taxes.

State and local tax returns for companies in the country increased slightly last year, while economic recovery accelerated, according to a new study published last week, and Washington-area companies were no exception.
Companies in the District, Maryland and Virginia regions together paid $27.6 billion to state and local authorities in fiscal 2013, an increase of 3.8 percent over 2012 revenues of $26.6 billion.

The corporate state and local tax burden increased by 4.3 percent last year to $671 billion, compared to 3.9 percent the previous year, and it was the third consecutive year of growth after several years of declining revenues in 2009 and 2010.
State taxes increased more than local taxes by 4.3 percent, according to a study conducted by Ernst & Young Services Agency and the Centre for State Taxation, a tax policy group.
More than half of the district's tax revenues, 56 percent, come from corporate taxes, while 36 percent of Maryland's revenues come from companies.
Virginia has the lowest corporate tax revenues of 28 percent.

Much of the increase in tax revenues is due to a recovery in corporate property values, the researchers say, which led to a real estate tax increase of 3.7 percent this year after three consecutive years with growth rates of less than 1 percent.
While a large portion of these gains came from large states such as California, New York, and Texas, the sequence also seems to apply to the Washington area.

Companies in the District, Maryland and Virginia jointly paid more than $10 billion in state and local property taxes last year, compared to $9.6 billion in 2012 - an increase of 4.2 percent over the course of the year.
But the apparent recovery in property values in Maryland is not so effective in raising state and local tax revenues, as property taxes here amount to just over a fifth of corporate tax returns.
Companies in Virginia and D.C. pay almost half of their state and local taxes in the form of property taxes.

"What's happening in Maryland is that a lot of real estate, especially in the D.C. tax area, is either owned by the government or by non-profit organizations that don't pay real estate taxes," said Douglas Lindholm, Managing Director of the Center on State Taxation.
Maryland is therefore forced, for example, to rely much more on income taxes to provide the same services that other states offer.
The recent recovery in corporate tax revenues cannot be attributed solely to the recovery of the real estate market
Company revenues also seem to be recovering, according to the data.
Companies in the region reported income taxes at state organizations of $2.3 billion, compared to $2.1 billion in 2012.
Maryland introduced $1 billion in corporate income taxes, the highest in the region.
While the trend is in the same direction, the local tax burden on businesses does not increase evenly in all three locations.
The growth rate in the district was 4.3 percent of the national average, while the growth rate in Maryland was significantly higher, 4.9 percent.
Virginia alone reported an under-average tax revenue of 4.1 percent.
Virginia has the lowest corporate income taxes in all three departments at 6% (all three have fixed corporate tax rates).
The corporate tax rate in Maryland is 8.25 percent and in the District is relatively high at 9.975 percent.
A comparable study by the US Chamber of Commerce earlier this year showed that Virginia has lower state and local corporate taxes and a better tax climate overall than Maryland.
The district was not investigated in the study.
Despite the advantages, Virginia is under pressure from its southern neighbors.
North Carolina has passed laws to lower its corporate tax rates this year from 6.9 percent to 6 percent, the same rate as Virginia, and the rate will fall to 5 percent next year.
If the state continues to meet its income targets next year, this law could reduce the state’s corporate income tax rate to 3 percent by 2017.
Meanwhile, small businesses in the Washington area seem to be doing better and are therefore paying more state and local taxes, according to the latest study.

Corporate taxes paid as personal income taxes by small businesses – a transitional structure under which most small businesses are organized – in the District, Maryland, and Virginia increased by 20 percent last year to $2.4 billion, a significantly faster rate of growth than corporate taxes as a whole.

The researchers say that the trend and increase in corporate taxes across the country will likely continue this year, with an increase in general military tax revenues for the state and local governments by 6.2 percent in the first three quarters of 2014 compared to the same period last year.
Nevertheless, Washington could backtrack if the federal government’s spending cuts affect the region’s labour market.
Partner city: German beer for Guangzhou
Hop and malt - also a popular combination in China.

Frankfurt's partner city in China now wants a brewery and also hopes for a direct flight between the two cities.

More business traffic
A second wish of the Chinese hosts would be a direct flight between Frankfurt and Guangzhou, said Vice-Chairman Li.

"This is a very good idea," replied Schäfer-Gümbel - the Chinese Deputy Minister Li Jinjun, an intimate acquaintance of Germany, nodded approvingly.
Managed Partnership
The faithful Guangzhou vice-president hopes to be able to attend a partnership meeting in Frankfurt next year.
Li Yiwei was already on the Main, but not yet in this role.
He only took office this year after his predecessor had been expelled from the office on corruption charges.

The new top politician, Li Yiwei, had worked for an American company before his party career, which is highly unusual in the Chinese Communist Party.
Before taking office in Guangzhou, he worked as a senior official in Fujian, where the automaker VW built a large factory.
Frankfurt has officially entered into more than a dozen city partnerships.
The connection to Guangzhou, 9,000 kilometres away, belongs to those maintained by both sides, for example with a student exchange.
Last year, the 25th anniversary of the German-Chinese connection was celebrated.
With its economic power, the southern Chinese metropolis on the Pearl River is almost as strong as all of Hesse.
Next year, it wants to achieve a gross domestic product of 250 billion euros, Li reported.

Amazon buys Twitch for $1.04 billion

AMAZON just confirmed what information had reported on Monday morning: The online retailer - and video producer, and a variety of other things - buys the video streaming service Twitch for $1.04 billion (970 million US dollars).
The announcement comes as a surprise, not because no one had expected a takeover of Twitch, but because it was widely assumed that YouTube would acquire the company.
Three months ago it looked like the sale of Twitch to Google's video service for a cool billion was a decided thing, and the collaboration also appeared natural.
Twitch, founded only three years ago as Justin.tv, was launched as a general streaming service - a live version of YouTube.
Instead, it quickly became a platform for players who wanted to publish their bravery pieces in games, a "YouTube for live games", according to an insider.
The Twitch interface.
And "let's play", a video game in which better-informed people give the (mostly older) games a touch of science fiction theater, are already very popular on YouTube.

It is true that YouTube is often referred to when you want to describe Twitch, so the news that YouTube wanted to buy Twitch was somewhat boredly recorded, a textbook example of an established tech company buying up a potential competitor.
It is a mystery why the deal with YouTube did not come about, as the company reportedly was willing to pay as much as Amazon.

All we know about it at the moment is this statement by Emmet Shear, President of Twitch: "We chose Amazon because they believe in our community, they share our values and long-term visions, and they want to help us get there faster."
Another secret is, to be honest, the incredible success of Twitch.

For snobs like me who explain that they prefer to do sports than watch, it's hard to understand the attraction that comes from watching others play instead of taking control consoles into their own hands.
It's one thing to look over a friend's shoulder at 3 a.m. while she's walking through Resident Evil, and it's quite another to watch a spider be shot in the head 20 times in a row in Call of Duty.
All these games you could watch right now.
Another problem is that many of the most popular games today are ego games, so watching without own control of the viewing perspective can be a really good recipe for headaches.
I admit that the fast runs in which the Roger Bannisters of our electronic age complete games in record time are entertaining.
But as long as a game or humor virtuoso isn't involved, his Twitch channel is probably not that interesting.
But what do skeptics like me already know about it?
Twitch is visited by 55 million different visitors per month and is the fourth largest source of Internet traffic spikes.
And how exactly does Amazon want to make money from it?
It’s hard to imagine Twitch integrating into Amazon Instant Video as elegantly as YouTube’s Twitch could have easily swallowed.
But Twitch has something that every company would like: thousands of young men being recruited as advertising customers.
As the chairman of Twitch, Shear, said, Amazon and Twitch "both believe in the future of gaming," and the medium shows no signs of shrinking, not even - swallow - as a spectator sport.

Will the castle societies soon be back on track?
Finally, there was always a clash between the two Wolfratshaus Burgvereins.
The boards are now considering possible cooperation.
The deceased Richard Dimbath, former chairman of the Wolfratshauser Burgfreunde, led the project in Guédelon, France as a model for the reconstruction of the Wolfratshauser Castle.
A year ago, there was no good climate between the castle club and the castle friends Wolfratshausen.
Until now, the views on how to deal with the history of Wolfratshaus Castle and a possible reconstruction seemed to be very different.
Now the two camps are moving towards each other: talks on a common approach are to be held soon.
This is confirmed by the club chairmen Torsten Sjöberg (Burgverein) and Herbert Piffl (Burgfreunde) on request of our newspaper.
"I called Mr. Piffl and suggested that we could come together once," reports Sjöberg.
In his opinion, all members of both clubs could rejoin the club in the future.
Thus, quicker visible successes are to be recorded.

While the castle friends around the suddenly deceased Richard Dimbath had until last an eye on a reconstruction of the castle on the mountain forest, the castle association around Sjöberg stands for the "exploration and experience" of the site at the forefront.
Herbert Piffl, the second chairman of the Burgfreunde, said he was very happy about the call.
Since Dimbath's death, he has represented the castle's friends.
A new chairman is to be found in mid-September at a meeting of members.
According to the 74-year-old, the association currently has around 40 members.
"After the death of my friend Richard Dimbath, we first let the association activities rest out of respect." This "thinking phase" was necessary to "consider how it could go on".
According to Piffl, the new chairman will then go into talks with the castle club.
Until then, the castle friends could also make a current mood picture within their group.
There is not yet a candidate for the presidency, Piffl says.
"But I am confident that someone will be found." He himself does not want to run because he lives in Bad Tölz.
The new chairman should be a Wolfratshauser.
The Tölzer wants to work on the project "but very much likes to continue to work".
In Piffl's eyes, the different positions on reconstruction will probably remain in place in the near future.
He credits Dimbath as a "missionary" who always believed in the reconstruction of the castle.
Two similar, already far-reaching projects in Austria and France would show that this idea is not an airlock.
Due to the high participation of the population as well as by volunteers from all over the world, they are a tourist magnet.
Piffl: "I was also sceptical at the beginning.
But over time, I have become more and more convinced that it makes sense to push the project forward." It could be created a "uniform feature" for the Flößerstadt.
There is nothing else here.
In addition, Piffl believes the project could be financed by EU grants, visitor tickets and potential sponsors.
"I personally do not want to simply throw the idea of reconstruction overboard." He hopes that the Burgverein may be moving a little at this point.
Their goal of documenting history first is "important and good".
Afterwards, we could look further.
Clever ways to save on university textbooks
Since the cost of university textbooks for many students is more than $1,000 per year, the fast-secondary student Matt Schroeder came up with a clever saving idea.
He invented a leasing system for books by students of higher semesters and offered a nominal compensation to delay the re-sale.
"My math book normally costs $180, but I got it for $10 for a semester and a Chick-fil-A-Keks," said Schroeder, 19, who attends Covenant College in Georgia.
The books needed for the last semester would have cost him $430, he said.
He gave out $120.
The college management shared that students spend on average more than $1,200 a year on textbooks and study materials, but that there are different cost-saving options for students.
Online courses and creative approaches such as the Schroeders are increasingly the solution of choice for students.
The rental of textbooks is becoming more popular, so students can use a book for a semester, often at a significantly lower price than when they buy it.
Neebo Inc, which operates more than 250 university bookstores, reported that the rental of textbooks has doubled since 2011.
Surveys in the industry show that about a quarter of the books in college bookstores were rented last spring, said Neebos Vice President Tevor Meyer.
Less than half of all textbooks are purchased in campus bookstores, according to the National Association of College Stores.
Here is the one-off for the best deals.
Buy online
Some new books online only cost a third of the price for which they are available in the campus bookstore.
The ninth edition of "Calculus" vno Ron Larwon, Bruce Edwards and Robert Hostetler costs nearly $290, but can be purchased at the specialized textbook retailer Chegg.com for $239.99.
Used buy
If the notes of others or normal traces of use do not matter to you, used books are a good option.
"Calculus" is used to have on Chegg.com for $93.49.

Matt Casaday, 25, a graduate student at Brigham Young University, says he spent 42 cents on Amazon.com for a used edition of "Strategic Media Decisions: Understanding The Business End Of The Advertising Business."
The book was sold for $48.
Academics such as Ingrid Bracey, head of the University of Massachusetts at Amherst College Without Walls, recommended that students ask their professors if earlier expenses are allowed.
Sometimes the updates are not relevant for the seminar work.
In such cases, older issues can often be purchased for a fraction of the cost of the latest issue.
Aside from Chegg and Amazon, eBay Inc's Half.com is a popular alternative for used books.
Renting
Renting textbooks is worth considering if you treat them fairly well, remember to give them back, and do not want to keep the books after completing the course.
You can save more than 80 percent of the cost of a newly purchased book.
For example, a student could rent "Calculus" for the duration of a semester for about $20.
Please check the terms and conditions of the shop where you rent, as well as the penalties that may apply for writing notes, subtractions or traces of use.
Tenants careful: If you do not return the book, penalties may even exceed the price of a new book.
E-books
E-books instead of conventional textbooks are also an option.
Sometimes these books are de facto rented by providing an electronic license for a certain period of time by wholesalers such as Amazon.com, Chegg and Barnes & Noble Inc.
At Chegg you can rent "Calculus" for 6 months for about 61 $.
Bracey says students in literature courses often find the best offers, as many classics can be downloaded for free nowadays, while scientific and engineering textbooks can be very expensive.
Look around anyway.
Joe Gault, 29, who will soon attend Pepperdine Law School, recommends the ISBN number for book pricing, so you can be sure to find the right textbook.
And before you order online, Gault said, you should check if the book is actually in stock.
This lesson he learned on the hard tour.
He bought a book that had four weeks' delivery time and finally paid the full price at the college bookstore.
Why "Guardians of the Galaxy" became no cashier

Sylvester Stallone's "The Expendables 3" played less than 30 million dollars of its $90 million budget in the United States, while "Sin City: A Dame to Kill For" played only 12 million dollars of its $70 million budget.
Cameron Diaz's film "Sex Tape" grossed only $14.6 million at the opening weekend, while children's films such as "Drachenzähmen leicht gemacht 2" also disappointed.
An article by Telegraph film critic Robbie Collin suggests that in children's films the lack of quality of the films themselves could be the reason.
Collin described 2014 as "the worst year" ever for children's films and described "Drachenzähmen leicht gemacht 2" as a purely "functional" fantasy sequel.
For films for a slightly older audience, however, it seems that the quality of the films is not necessarily the problem.

In July, Entertainment Weekly compared the average CinemaScore and Metacritic ratings for each summer film premiere shown on at least 2,000 screens between American Memorial Day and July 20, 2013 and the current year.
The results are based on the opinion of cinema visitors and film critics and indicate that this year's film hits are the same as last year's.
Some commentators believe that the development is due to changing visual habits and the growing popularity of web streaming services such as Netflix.
Director Jon Favreau, who is currently working on Disney's forthcoming jungle book film, told Hollywood Reporter: "I believe times are changing."
We must accept that and not try to follow the past.

In contrast to the currently weak cash results of Hollywood productions, Netflix recently generated revenues of $1.2 billion in streaming content, almost twice as much as last year, when revenue was $837 million.
Last summer, director Steven Spielberg criticized the film studios for focusing too much on comics and predicting a Hollywood "cold melt".
In light of the current downturn, some commentators argue that his gloomy prophecy could contain a true core.
Due to the potential box office hits expected in summer 2015, including Avengers: Age of Ultron, Minions and Jurassic World, other representatives of the film industry are more optimistic:

X-Men producer Simon Kinberg recently described the decline in box office results as simply "cyclical" and told Hollywood reporters: "Next summer will be the biggest summer at the box office ever, and nobody will worry about the business anymore."
When the 2nd table tennis district class was abolished a few years ago in order to tighten the league division, this has been a step in the right direction.
Now the Deutsche Tischtennisbund has added an additional 3rd Bundesliga to the programme.
The consequence: Those who have not ascended are descended.
Although Göttingen's top-class Torpedo team has avoided relegation in the Oberliga-Relegation, it will only play fifth-class next season.
Torpedo's women remain in fourth place, despite their magnificent breakthrough in the regional league.
The boys and girls of Torpedo start in the Lower Saxony League, as well as the boys of SC Weende.
The SG Lenglern and the Torpedo-Reserve join the new league, but no more Göttingen clubs are represented in the national league.

Güntersen, the TTC and the TTV Geismar II are here with from the party.

With nine teams each

In a district class, Geismar, Tuspo Weende and Bovender SV enter the season.
In the first season of the newly founded regional association, the two Göttinger Kreisligen start with nine teams each.
In the West-Staffel are the Rot-Weiß II, Bovender SV III, Laubach II, Torpedo IV and V, MTV Grone, Dransfelder SC II, Mielenhausen and SG Lenglern II.
In the Eastern-Staffel play among others Sattenhausen/Wöllmarshausen, Nikolausberg and Landolfshausen.
The women's league consists of Sattenhausen/Wöllmarshausen II, Bilshausen, Hemeln, Seulingen II, Tuspo Weende and SG Rhume.
This is still better than in the district of Osterode, where there are no more women's teams at the district level.
It is remarkable that none of the six 2nd class units reaches full strength, and the innovative and forward-looking circle management will have to think about this.
NATO Summit: First protests in Newport and Cardiff
On the weekend there were protests by opponents of the NATO summit in Newport.
On Saturday, hundreds gathered in the centre of Newport for an anti-Nato march.
On Sunday, about 150 people gathered in Cardiff in front of the city hall to hold a so-called counter-summit.
Stephen Fairclough followed developments on the weekend for us and spoke to demonstrators who travelled from Bridgend to Belgium.
Teenagers flew out of the Blue Mountains
TWO teenage bus scouts were saved by rope after being caught overnight in the Blue Mountains in NSW.
The 16-year-old girl and the 19-year-old man broke up shortly after Sunday morning in Govetts Leap in Blackheath for their tour.
Concerned relatives called the police around 8:00 p.m. when the two had not returned home.
A search team from local police and rescue services broke up and the couple were found around 23 o'clock near the Bridal Veil waterfalls.
The girl had been injured on her knee and the man was crushed and had hit his head.
Rescuers stayed with the couple overnight, and they were flown out on Monday morning.
They were delivered to Blue Mountains Hospital in a stable condition with an ambulance.
Anti-government protests escalate in Pakistan
About 1,000 demonstrators had been pushed by soldiers from the PTV building, said Information Minister Pervaiz Rashid.
The station resumed broadcasting after nearly half an hour.
PTV Director Athar Farooq said that the demonstrators armed with sticks had damaged equipment in the editorial office.
No deaths or injuries were reported.
The demonstrators demand the resignation of the head of government whom they accuse of electoral fraud.
Police reported that clashes between some 3,000 demonstrators and security forces had resumed Monday, about a kilometre from Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif's residence.
According to hospital reports, a policeman was injured.
On the weekend, at least three people were killed and more than 500 injured as demonstrators tried to penetrate Sharif's residence.
They demand the resignation of the Prime Minister.
The powerful military had called for a political solution to the conflict on Sunday evening after a meeting at Army Headquarters, "without wasting time and without violence".
The statement further stated: "The army remains committed to its role in ensuring the security of the state".
The escalating violence has raised concerns about military intervention, which has been more frequent in the past.
The protests, led by opposition politician Imran Khan and preacher Tahirul Kadri, have been going on since Independence Day, August 14.
Sharif refuses to resign.
Khan and Kadri had called on their followers on Sunday to persevere.
"We will not go back without forcing Sharif to resign," Khan said.
Hadi expressed a similar opinion.
Khan accuses Sharif of fraudulently winning the parliamentary elections in May last year.
Hadi calls for the withdrawal of the central and provincial governments.
Then a transitional government is to reform the electoral system and call new elections.
More than 40,000 security forces are deployed to protect the government district.
The demonstrators had initially stood peacefully in front of the parliament until Khan and Kadri forced them to enter Sharif's residence on the weekend.

Under this apple reigns peace
We showed a powerful tribe at our race show of the summer series "My piece of the Rhöner Glück" last Friday.
Several of these tree giants are still in the county, the pictured specimen is the "Geißruheiche" above Unterweißenbrunn.
A steep footpath leads up to the 600-year-old oak.
It passes by domes, basalt stone piles and basalt stone meadows.
A bit below the stone quarry of Bauersberg, a kilometre north of the road to Weisbach, is where it stands.
Vital looks like the natural monument, it rises above the other trees of the surrounding area and reminds with a width of more than eight meters of an American mammoth tree.
A small Buddha on a tree trunk indicates that it is a spiritual or mystical place.
However, despite intensive research, there were only indications of the origin of the name.
Dr. Wolfgang Schneider has additionally consulted the Bischofsheim archive and interviewed elderly people from Unterweißenbrunn to find out what attachment it has to the Geißruheiche.
The result of his investigations remained the rather dull explanation for the name.
Accordingly, up to about 80 years ago, the goat herds must have driven their animals from Unterweißenbrunn to the tiresomely roasted and stone-free meadows.
At the foot of the tree are said to have rested the animal keepers exhausted from the ascension.
Meanwhile, the area has regained its importance, because on the meadows are actually again grazing goat herds.
Schneider further found out that the area has also been declared the core area of the Biosphere Reserve.
However, you should be careful when entering the stone collections, because the basal, heated by the sun, is also a popular place for crusaders.
A hiking trail leads from Unterweißenbrunn to the tree, which is somewhat hidden.
Further paths are marked upwards in the direction of Hochrhön and invite you to an extensive hike.
Where is the water castle?
However, a water castle, which is being sought in our next task, is rarely found in the height.
The reflection in the tomb already gives a good impression of the building, but we have some historic buildings in the county that could be fitted to the building.
Where is our "Stuck of Rhöner Glück"?
My piece of phoenix happiness
