Andrew Lawson was such a man whose personality power could shake everything around, even in such a gigantic organization as the National Health Service.
As an anesthesiologist, he devoted his career to relieving patients both from the sufferings of illness and from the pains of treatment.
Among those who approached him, his wife recalls, was an M-6 officer who had to live with the devastating consequences of torture.
Lawson understood that while doctors are obsessed with diagnoses and diseases, those who are undergoing treatment are primarily concerned with something completely different - pain.
Once in 2007, however, he turned out to be the one who began to suffer.
"I didn't feel as usual," he wrote in May last year.
It was difficult for me to find strength in myself.
While struggling with flu-like symptoms, he discovered that he was annoyed with his wife, Juliet.
"I want everything to happen faster, not later," he said.
When Juliet left for work for a week, Lawson discovered that he was unusually and unexplainedly upset.
There was something wrong.
He asked his colleague to make a chest X-ray.
Just two weeks earlier, he was skiing in the French Alps.
X-ray results came.
It was mesothelioma, an incurable cancer that affects the pleura, or lung shell.
For most cancers, it is difficult to determine the exact cause.
Although some smokers get lung cancer, for example, not all lung cancer patients smoked.
But with mesothelioma differently.
In almost all cases, the reason is contact with asbestos, a fiber-based building material that was once called a "miracle", but which is now known to be deadly dangerous.
For most of us, mesothelioma is a disease that cannot be ignored.
Asbestos, after all, is a material from the past.
The most dangerous type of asbestos has not been used in the UK since the 1960s, when the recommended industrial ban came into force.
Even when it was used, only people from specific industries worked in close contact with it: pipe insulators, builders, carpenters and dock workers, for example.
Industrial toxin from another era, it hardly seems cause for concern today.
But such calm is wrong.
The United Kingdom, it turns out, is today at the peak of the epidemic of mesothelioma.
There are more people dying of mesothelioma than in any other country on the planet.
With an annual death rate of around 2,500 people, more than twice as many people die from this disease than from car accidents.
Annual deaths from mesothelioma since 1980 and projected future deaths in the United Kingdom

The reason why we feel its fatal consequences now is that although the use of asbestos has been illegal for many years (all types of asbestos were ultimately banned by law in 1999), the development of mesothelioma usually takes decades.
And the attack of mesothelioma is not limited to veterans of the specialties of industrial construction.
Asbestos was, and in many cases remains, laid in the homes where we live, the offices where we work, the schools where we study, and the shops where we shop.
As a result, mesothelioma does not pay attention to class, level of well-being, profession or age.
The ballot boxes, from fashionable London's department stores to private schools, turned out to be no salvation.
The building of the parliament is covered with asbestos.
Even hospitals designed to treat us have become reservoirs of this deadly cancer.
Andrew Lawson was not old.
He was not a pipe insulator.
In fact, he had to think about where he could come into contact with an asbestosist.
Then he conceived.
"It seems there could have been a lot of asbestos in the tunnels at the Haitian hospital where I spent six years in internship," he wrote.
All - students, nurses, doctors and cargomen - used these tunnels.
Interestingly, how many of my peers are suffering from the same disease?
This was a question to which, unfortunately, he could give a partial answer.
"Of the four doctors who trained at the Gaia Hospital and who subsequently developed mesothelioma in the last five years," he noted in a letter in 2010, "I remained alive."
How many of us get this disease?
Andrew Lawson was diagnosed with mesothelioma when he was 48 years old.
When he died on February 17, this year, he was 55.
It is unusual to live so long.
Fifty percent of patients with mesothelioma die within 8 months of diagnosis.
She is always deadly.
So now we can only repeat the question of Lawson: "How many of us get the same disease?"

According to the leading expert on mesothelioma in the UK, Professor Julian Pito, it is most likely that between 1970 and 2050, when the asbestosis epidemic in the UK is to survive, about 9,000 people will die.
Most people now do not imagine that they will die in this way.
Asbestos mine in Quebec, Canada Alamy
A quick view of reports from courtrooms, where victims often seek compensation, shows how far the mesothelioma attack has spread.
This June, for example, Marks & Spencer admitted that they had unwittingly contacted Jenis Ellen with an asbestosist.
She worked in the network for nine years, from 1978 to 1987, managing the clothing departments at two facilities, one of which was the main store on Oxford Street.
Ms. Ellen was only 18 when she started working at M&S.
She now has two children over 20 years of age.
"Before it happened," she says, "I never heard of mesothelioma, I barely knew of asbestos.
I could not imagine that it would affect me.
Few people really know a lot about asbestos.
In fact, asbestos is not a single substance, but a group of six minerals.
They got their name from the word "asbestosform", which means a fiber structure that informs them of strength and flexibility.
Of these six, three were often used in construction.
The chrysotile, widely known as white asbestos, is more commonly found in buildings today.
It was used in roof panels, floor tiles, thermal insulation of pipes, heating hoses, even in brake valves of cars.
It is less deadly than other forms of asbestos, but is still recognized by the European Union and the World Health Organization as a "serious source of health damage" that can lead to death.
More dangerous, however, are brown asbestos (amosite) and blue asbestos (crocidolite).

The UK was once the world's largest importer of brown asbestos, and experts suggest that "there are eternal, albeit indirect, grounds to believe that this is the main reason for the exceptionally high number of patients with mesothelioma [in the UK]".
A staff member of Marks & Spencer was exposed to asbestos in the company's main store on Oxford Street, London Alamy
Janis Ellen may not have thought of herself as a typical mesothelioma victim, but Julian Pito's work suggests that her story is far from unusual.

He conducted a study of patients which suggests that "a substantial percentage of mesothelioma, when there is no known exposure at work or at home, were most likely caused by exposure to asbestos from the environment".
Much of this influence, he says, is due to "the usual use and influence of the weather" on our buildings.
No one seems to be sure that he is safe.
The report by Goddard Consulting, which examined the Westminster Palace, demonstrates how people, even at the very centre of government, could be affected unconsciously.

In 2009, Goddard reported that technical mines and pipelines behind parliamentary committees were infected with asbestos, the deadly fibers of which could be moved by something as harmless as "strong air flows".
Members of parliament are often accused of pursuing their own interests, but in this case the opposite seems to be true.

Although Parliament's Maintenance Directorate insisted that the Westminster Palace received a "clean sanitary certificate," it now acknowledged that £1 billion needed to be spent on rebuilding the Parliament, improving electricity and removing the asbestos, and that after the 2015 general election, members of Parliament would probably sit in the nearby QE2 conference centre, not on the green rooftops of Westminster.
The Goddard report noted that "the situation with the asbestos was not managed according to different rules".
It is not possible to know whether this control error will cost a lifetime.
All you can do now is wait.
One of those who has never been able to identify their contact with asbestos is Graham Abbott, a general practitioner.
Like Andrew Lawson, Abbott, 50, suspects he was exposed to asbestos while working in hospitals.
"I worked in a hospital that successfully filed claims for asbestos," he says, "but I can't prove it in my case.
It is so difficult to remember all places where he worked and dates.
What he clearly remembers is the day in early December 2009 when he was hit by something that looked like the flu.
He was 45, and he was in the middle of the operation late in the evening.
Suddenly I began to get sick.
It started very quickly.
I felt terrible.
I thought I couldn't go all the way home.
Being a doctor, Abbott knew that pain came from the plexus, the shell around the lungs.
However, like Janis Ellen, he simply had no reason to suspect mesothelioma.
Eventually, he could not go to work for a month.
The doctors performed X-rays of the breast cell and placed pleural catheters to extract fluid from the lungs and send it for analysis.
However, his condition remained undiagnosed.
Gradually his health improved and he returned to work.
But from time to time the same symptoms returned, often after he was engaged in sports and breathed heavily.
In 2011, one of Abbott's patients came to his clinic with similar symptoms, and he was subsequently diagnosed with mesothelioma.
However, even then, Abbott did not link this to his own case.
After all, his patient was dozens of years older and worked with the asbestos directly.
The connection in this case was obvious.
In September 2011, Abbott's condition deteriorated again, and his consultant showed his results of CT and X-rays to a group of specialists.
In December 2011, exactly two years after Abbott began to feel bad, a sensor equipped with a camera was inserted between his breast cell and his light body.
I am optimistic.
I usually just go further," he says.
I was not too worried about it, frankly.
But Rachel, my wife, was worried.
The result of the biopsy came in the week between Christmas and New Year: "I was told it was mesothelioma."
Graham Abbott: diagnosed with mesothelioma
Subsequently, Abbott entered a meeting with Macmillan's nurses, one of whom suggested that he contact a lawyer.
It was then that he realized the scale of the epidemic.
"Asbestos has been widely used, especially in large public buildings, where asbestos heat insulation on pipes was quite common," he says.
People who were affected by asbestos in these buildings are now suffering from this disease.
Thus, mesothelioma now affects younger people in non-typical professions.
The most dangerous asbestos-isolated pipes in hospitals were located in the basements, so it is unlikely that patients would be affected.

But many employees who walked down pedestrian tunnels to get from one building to another (like Andrew Lawson) or ate in underground dining rooms (as Graham Abbott often did) were almost certainly exposed to the toxic substance.

For several decades after the war, it turns out that hospitals were a place where, theoretically, life was saved for the citizens, but a place that posed a threat to the lives of the doctors who treated them.
It is still being removed today.
The pupils installed their burners of Buenos Aires on asbestos stands
And it’s not just hospitals.
Asbestos is often used in offices, shops, libraries and municipalities due to its surprising insulation and fire resistance.
Schools too.
In fact, many were probably the first to be affected by asbestos in the classroom.
Throughout the country, in countless chemistry classes, schoolchildren installed their Bunsen burners on asbestos stands.
There are websites that address the problem of asbestos in schools.
Meanwhile, in our houses, such harmless things as floor tiles or sarai roofs usually contained asbestos.
"It's an industrial poison that's embedded in a huge number of our buildings," says Andrew Morgan, a lawyer who represented Andrew Lawson in the case against Gay Hospital.
In one case, the only contact a sick woman could remember was the removal of a garden rose in the 1970s.
Therefore, be careful to cut down garden saws.
The effect of diagnosis when it is known that the disease is incurable is enormous.
"It takes quite a long time to realize this," says Graham Abbott.
I went back to work and tried to continue, but I realized I couldn't focus on what I was doing.
I spent two weeks in surgery.
Then I realized that I would have to go away and deal with myself.
Well, I won’t meet Christmas anymore
One of the most difficult things was moving from a doctor's position to a patient's position.
Like an infinite number of patients before him, he remembers how he was overwhelmed with the amount of information that had to be received.
"It was difficult to realize everything," he says.
"I asked my doctor, "How much time do I have?"
I was given about 12 months.
I remember thinking, "Well, I'm not going to see Christmas anymore.
That's all."
Mesothelioma is particularly dangerous because it is the mechanics of how we sustain life - the breathing act itself - that causes cancer that kills.
Most cases of mesothelioma are caused by contact with asbestos.
The asbestos consists of tiny fibers.
When the asbestos is destroyed and the fibers are inhaled, they can get stuck in the neck, the shell of the lungs.
Asbestos hair irritates the pleurous tissue and can cause cell mutations.
"The problem arises because of the inhalation of asbestos fibers," said Professor Tom Treger, a cardiothoracic surgeon who came to the Gaia Hospital in 2001.
It was the hospital where Andrew Lawson suspected he had been exposed to asbestos, now, ironically, the leading center for the treatment of mesothelioma.
The coach knew Lawson and treated some of the others who were likely to have been affected while training at the hospital.
When the asbestos spots fall into the lung tissue, says the Trainer, "the breath pulls them to the periphery where the envelope is.
This is, in essence, an invasive process from the very beginning.
The usual treatment options for other forms of cancer are much less effective in mesothelioma.
The effectiveness of surgical intervention, for example, is highly controversial.
Some people think it's worth trying.
The trainer does not agree.
"It's impossible to cut a cloth," he says.
It is impossible to approach it with a knife.
Meanwhile, this cancer "is not very well subjected to chemotherapy", which "acts", but does not cure.
"Sometimes there are sick people who live a long time," says the trainer.
But in the end, they all die.
Fortunately, some patients live much, much longer than expected.
The writer Stephen Jay Good died 20 years after the diagnosis.
Two and a half years after diagnosis, Graham Abbott continues to fight.
After he fell ill with mesothelioma, Abbott was introduced to Andrew Lawson, who, four years after diagnosis, became a support and counselling office for the same patients.
"Allo, Cancer Central," he said cheerfully when they called.
"He was very positive," says Abbott.
He was diagnosed four years ago, and he is still very energetic.
At first, Abbott was offered six cycles of chemotherapy, which would take four months and extend his life for just one month.
"I was in despair," he says.
I wanted to surrender.
Lewison, however, "hosted to give the whole thing a somewhat more positive look".
After meeting with several specialists, Abbott decided to continue his treatment with Professor Loik Lange-Lazdongsky, Professor of Toracular Surgery at Gaia Hospital.
"We had the advantage that I didn't need directions, I just called them and they accepted me," Graham admits.
The average patient would have to receive direction and approval for funding.
Money plays a crucial role for patients with mesothelioma to get the best of the available treatments.
However, when such treatments finally inevitably become ineffective, many patients face yet another financial cause for concern – the future of the families they leave behind.
And then they appeal to the courts for compensation.
Andrew Lawson contacted Andrew Morgan of Field Fisher Waterhouse LLP.
"It has been known that asbestos is harmful to health since 1898," Morgan says.
But what changed in the 1960s was that it became clear that even very small numbers could put health at risk.
It was at this time that the company's dishonesty was discussed.

Andrew Lawson and Gaia Hospital eventually settled the case, but this was not a "complete settlement", according to Morgan, as Lawson was unable to conclusively prove that his mesothelioma was the result of contact with an asbestos patient at Gaia Hospital.
After an investigation into his death, the hospital's representative confirmed, nevertheless, that "the asbestos in the underground rooms we were talking about was removed in the 1990s."
It was too late for Andrew Lawson.
How to remove asbestos
In fact, linking fatal contact with asbestos to one company or workplace – usually decades later – has proved to be a big problem for patients with mesothelioma requiring compensation.
Many of their former employers have changed ownership or closed.
The insurance records may have been lost.
And those who defend themselves against claims know that on their side is time, which the plaintiffs, of course, do not have.
In response, this year, serious new legislative acts came out that make it easier for patients with mesothelioma to recover compensation, even if their former employers cannot be traced.
Under this law, a £350 million fund has been created, funded by the insurance industry, for those who have been diagnosed after July 2012 and who can prove contact but who have no one to judge.
In such cases, patients will receive 80 per cent of the amount that the court could award in the ordinary case of compensation - about £120000.
About 300 successful claims under this scheme are expected each year.
Andrew Morgan, like many who work with patients with mesothelioma, believes that £350 million represents a "very good job" for the insurance industry.

"This is a deal written by the insurers for the insurers," he says, hinting that the sum is a quarter of what the insurers would have to pay if there had not been a temporary interruption and patients with mesothelioma could have followed the company and filed a lawsuit in the ordinary way.
Even Mike Penning, formerly the Minister of Labour and Pensions, admitted that the law was “inadequate.”
However, both Penning and Morgan admit that, with seven people dying every day, rapid action was needed.
"People are suffering so much, and they need help today," Penning said during the second reading of Bill on mesothelioma last December.
By that time, Graham Abbott had been in the hands of Professor Loik Lange-Lazdongsky for 19 months.
After initial consultations, Lang-Lazdongsky recommended a surgical procedure, which, unlike Tom Tscher, he believed to be effective.
This was followed by radiation therapy and chemotherapy - tritherapy, in which Lang-Lazdongsky can boast of a total of 40 percent of survivors in five years.
Abbott felt a surge of strength.
"This is of course one of the most important things," says Abbott.
You see it in patients all the time.
There is some power that supports you.
When you surrender, the condition can deteriorate very quickly.
Graham Abbott underwent surgery in March 2012.
By the end of August he had completed the last of six cycles of chemotherapy.
The subsequent scans did not show any signs of the disease.
Then I was scanned in March [2014].
There were some spots in my breast cell.
I was supposed to be fifty.
This is not a life threat.
This is the end of life.
And again Abbott went through six cycles of chemotherapy.
Now there is no trace of tumors.
However, this process is both physically and emotionally difficult.
It is possible to think about practical things - about finances, when I die, for example, or about what to show to my wife, how the timer works on the fighter.
When you get bad news, you become unhappy.
We need to look ahead.
Like Eli's father, 16 years old, and Tamzin, 14 years old, it's not always easy.
"It's hard for a parent," he says.
It was difficult to understand what to say and how much to say.
When I was diagnosed for the first time, I told the girls that I had a disease that meant I would not live to old age.
They reacted very differently.
Tamin is very social and energetic.
She told all her friends, and we got a lot of calls very quickly.
Ellie was more restrained.
She didn't say much.
Such conversations are something that all cancer patients have to face.
But for patients with mesothelioma, such discussions are not balanced by hope, even a glimmer of possibility of survival.
This disease brings with it (also as, ultimately, for Steven Jay Guld) a dark certainty.
As Andrew Morgan says, "the mesothelioma is not a life threat.
The bodies of the anointed pharaohs are wrapped in asbestos.
Asbestos fibers are used to strengthen the pots and increase the heat resistance.

The modern commercial use of asbestos begins in Italy, where it is used to make paper (even banknotes) and fabrics.
Large asbestos mines are being opened in Canada and South Africa and soon thereafter in America, Italy and Russia.
It is the ideal heat insulator for steam engines and Industrial Revolution turbines.
The world production of asbestos grows more than 30,000 tons per year.
Statistics from Prudential reveal premature mortality among those who work with an asbestos practitioner and who are therefore denied life insurance.
Nellie Kershaw dies in Rochedale.
Dr. William Cook testified that the asbestos particles in her lungs "were, without any doubt, the main cause of death".
This is the first such case.

Compensation is not paid.
During the Second World War, shipbuilding developed intensely, one of the most deadly professions from the point of view of contact with asbestos.

China refuses to give Hong Kong the right to choose its leaders; protesters pledge revenge
The Chinese parliament decided on Sunday not to allow Hong Kong voters to nominate candidates for the 2017 election, despite growing demands for democratic reform.
Such a move is likely to trigger long-awaited protests in Hong Kong’s business district, as activists began planning and mobilizing within hours of the announcement.
The decision of the National People’s Assembly basically allows communist leaders to remove all candidates who are not loyal to Beijing.
"It didn't deceive our expectations, but it still leads to anger," said legislator Emily Lau, chairman of the Democratic Party.
This is not what Beijing has promised.
They deceived the people of Hong Kong.
And it is obvious that we are dealing with an authoritarian regime.

Protecting China's decision, Li Fei, deputy secretary general of the Standing Committee of the National People's Assembly, said it would be too "chaotic" to allow Hong Kong's leader to be nominated for the general election.
Since 1997, when the United Kingdom transferred control of Hong Kong back to China, Beijing has promised to allow residents of the region to vote for the head of government from 2017 onwards.

Chinese leaders have presented Sunday’s decision as a democratic step forward, as it gives Hong Kongers the right to vote directly; however, the decision also makes clear that Chinese leaders will continue to hold the process firmly in their hands with the help of a nomination commission heavily controlled by Beijing.
And, according to the new article, only candidates who "love the country and love Hong Kong" will be allowed.
The decision was taken after the summer, when one of the largest and widely publicized protests in Hong Kong for many years occurred.

Much of the pro-democracy campaign in Hong Kong lies behind the Occupy Central With Love and Peace movement, whose organizers have threatened to shut down Hong Kong’s financial district unless Beijing guarantees genuine universal suffrage.
On Sunday evening, several hours after the statement, hundreds of Occupy Central supporters gathered in the rain in front of the Hong Kong government headquarters.
At the demonstration, the organizers stated that their movement is moving to a new stage of civil disobedience and that they will rise to the protest waves in the coming weeks.
However, they did not provide details, apparently seeking to avoid problems with state bodies.

In an online application, the organizers reported that the movement "considered the possibility of seizing the central district only as an exceptional measure, an action that can only be undertaken if all possibilities of dialogue are exhausted and there is no other choice.
We are very sorry to announce that to date all possibilities of dialogue have been exhausted and the capture of the central area will undoubtedly take place.

Government authorities in Hong Kong had been preparing for Beijing's statement for several days, and on Sunday security measures were reinforced at the government headquarters with police and barricades in place.
At the root of the riots lies the feeling that many in Hong Kong are slowly losing control of their own city.
The arrival of inhabitants from the mainland increases competition in the sphere of goods and services.
There is also a growing fear that Hong Kong’s values, such as democracy and freedom of speech, will begin to weaken under increasing pressure from Beijing.
Some criticize the Occupy Central movement, saying that its demonstrations put at risk Hong Kong's vital business.
"The protest they are talking about can cause great economic damage depending on how many people will participate and for how long," said legislator Regina Ip, who has long criticized the movement.
We do not want the concern that Hong Kong is out of control to spread.
This is an idea that is harmful to investment.
Chinese state media also reported in recent days that Hong Kong democracy activists were shown to be Western-led divergents.
This summer, activists organized an unofficial referendum on electoral law, which attracted 780,000 participants – more than one fifth of Hong Kong’s voters.
And in July tens of thousands went out for one of the largest pro-democracy demonstrations in the history of the region.
The American culture of graduation balls goes back to university life: first-year students were offered to arrive on a private plane
We are pleased to respond to this demand by launching the first UK luxury travel service for current students.
To leave a bright impression on arrival at the university, the company also offers transport options such as a personal aircraft, Rolls-Royce Phantom, Aston Martin or McLaren P1.

This service is an ideal alternative for students who usually have to carry their things across the country in a dangerously overcrowded car.
In conjunction with our new VIF options, we look forward to helping students this year get to the university with the minimum of effort and the maximum of luxury.
The company's representative said that since this service has just been launched, orders have not yet been received, but added that "students will start ordering this service in the next few weeks".
The company also stated that despite the need for students to pay £9000 a year for their education, it hopes to find a market for this service.

Today's students are quite different from the students 10, 20, 30 or 40 years ago in terms of expectations and hopes: it is more important than ever to make an excellent first impression, and VIF is exactly what you need to do that.
However, the National Union of Students criticized the service as being disconnected from reality.
Megan Dunn, NSS Vice President for Higher Education, said: "This project is incredibly alienated from the lives of most students.

Many students who begin university studies this month are facing a cost-of-living crisis when affordable financial support in the form of loans and grants fails to cope with rapidly rising spending on basic needs before they can even start thinking about spending thousands of pounds on something like a simple boarding pass.
Feminists raise the issue of race and police behavior after Ferguson
An unarmed teenager was killed by a police officer in Ferguson, Missouri earlier this month.
Those who came up raised their hands, chanting, "Hands up, don't shoot," while they waited in line for the funeral.

Following two weeks of protests in Ferguson, Missouri in connection with the murder of Michael Brown, an unarmed teenager, blogger Miriam Zoila Pérez noticed a shift in online conversation among white feminists.
In her experience, white feminists who left comments placed gender above race when it came to promoting reproductive rights and income inequality.
However, as tensions grew in the Middle West and attracted national attention, Peres saw responses from white women who focused 100% on race.

Compared to the reaction of black women shortly after the 9 August assassination, personal essays with headlines such as "Feminism is not just about the oppression of women" and "Feminism from a white woman's point of view" appeared relatively late.
But for Peres they demonstrated a significant shift.
"In feminism, I don't think there are many people who talk about white skin color and privileges at such a high level," she said.
People felt the need to say something about what happened.
This is very symbolic of the crisis we are facing, and because (the situation in Ferguson) is so bound up with racial affiliation, they felt that it should be pointed out.

For an English professor at the University of Ohio, Corita, Mitchell Ferguson explored the problems that black Americans face every day, but which are not perceived as "female problems" in the cultural sphere.
"I can write something funny on Facebook about what's going on with me and my partner, and I'll get 150 likes everywhere," Mitchell says.
When I write something about how coloured people are being attacked in their own country, silence rings.
"Why is it safe for women to talk publicly about relationships, but not about security in the public sphere?" she asks.
For black women like Mitchell, who have studied issues of race, gender, and sexuality in the history of the United States, there is no dichotomy between issues of race and gender.
From her point of view, black women are in a position to clearly share these problems; they face a complex reality every day.

While white women now combine racial and gender issues in the feminist mainstream, Andrew Hattery, a professor of female and gender studies at George Mason University, says their predecessors did the opposite.
"Between 1865 and 1890, at least 10,000 black men were lynched, and the reason for this was almost always the rape of a white woman," said Hattery.
A white woman was needed to confirm the story to justify the lynching.

From Hetter's point of view, the split between white and black women occurred when white suffragettes such as Susan B. Anthony studied the situation in the late 1800s and saw that the struggle for electoral rights would only be effective for one group: women or blacks.
"They decided to put all the eggs in the basket for women's right to vote, and the right to vote for blacks should have appeared later," said Hattery.
Looking back at such things gives us a clear idea of why colorful women do not trust white women.
We did nothing good.
We have never helped black women to protect their husbands and sons.
Even after women gained the right to vote in 1920, it took ten years for white women to unite against lynching in the Association of Women of the South for the Prevention of lynching.
This group appeared almost 40 years after black women first asked for help, Mitchell said.

From Mitchell’s point of view, the rise in responses by white feminists to the problems raised by Ferguson’s situation – police behaviour, racial discrimination – reflects a time when white feminists had to “catch” the problems that black women have faced over several generations.

"In fact, it would be great if activists who have such a [traditional feminist] ideology were as serious about the right to raise a child as they are about the right to contraception," Mitchell asked.
Second-wave feminists who have made careers in the fight for reproductive rights and access to contraceptives are now beginning to understand what this means.

Two weeks after the murder of Michael Brown, Gloria Steinem, a prominent white feminist activist, used Facebook to publish a sharp article by Guardian columnist Rebecca Carroll calling for white Americans to participate more in racism protests.

"I hope that women who have a different but similar reason to understand the dangers involved in the body - and views on racial issues that differ significantly in public opinion polls - will be at the forefront of change," Steinem wrote.
While Steinem advocates more cross-sectional feminism, which includes both racial and gender issues, her comments on race in America still surprise some.

Researcher at the American Entrepreneurship Institute Kristina Sommers, author of "Who Stole Feministism?", told She The People that young men in the United States, especially young people of color, are "much more vulnerable than their sisters," but Stein's remarks about Ferguson contradict the criticism she had previously made.
Now we have hundreds of special programs for girls and young women, but almost nothing for boys.

However, when the White House recently launched a small program, “Save My Brother” to help vulnerable black and Spanish-speaking boys, there was angry reaction from many feminists, including Gloria Steinem.
Police relations with the black community are not the only problem promoting the front-line of traditional feminism.
After the U.S. Border Service arrested some 63,000 unaccompanied minors on the country’s southwestern border this year, immigration reform has come to light again – this time as a women’s issue.

Andrea Mercado, co-chair of We Belong Together, an organization that mobilizes women in support of immigration reform, said that in order to address this issue as important to women, she simply needed to share the stories of immigrant women.
"They speak for themselves," said Mercado.
When the overwhelming majority of workers’ visas are issued [for male immigrants], the women who come with them find themselves vulnerable to domestic violence and exploitation.
"These stories find a response from women's organizations," she said.
Ipswich house "with pig" for sale

We thought that such a win could be secret.

Ministry of Economic Development wants to accelerate the growth of the electric car market

This week, the Ministry of Economic Development will submit to the government a comprehensive plan for the development of clean transport in Russia, Deputy Director of the Department of the Ministry Oleg Pluzhnikov told at the round table held by "Vedomosti" at the Moscow Auto Salon - 2014.
The plan was drawn up on the instructions of the government, one of the main objectives is to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.

It is expected that the document will be adopted in late September - early October, says Pulzhnikov, the proposed measures concern electric vehicles and hybrids - the plan for the development of vehicles on gasoline fuel in Russia already exists.
The plan (copy available at "Vedomosti") is planned for 2014-2017.
It is necessary to develop criteria for evaluating electric and hybrid transport and to decide how to stimulate the use and production of clean vehicles.

The report to the government, which will describe tax and customs measures to support electric transport, will be prepared by December 2014; the scheme of preferential lending and preferential leasing will appear by April 2015; and proposals to reduce car prices, stimulate localization and create service infrastructure will be developed by October 2015.
In 2014-2015, it is planned to amend regulatory acts to facilitate conditions for the construction of charging infrastructure (in parking lots, petrol stations, etc.).

In addition, federal officials intend to formulate within 2015 proposals for regional authorities to also encourage the use of clean transportation – in the form of providing it with advantages in traffic and parking, for example; and by February 2016 – and proposals to expand public procurement of such transportation.

Finally, by October 2014, the Ministry of Economic Development will add criteria reflecting the effectiveness of supporting the production of clean transport and development of charging infrastructure to the list of indicators for the evaluation of the activities of regional authorities.
The electric car market in Russia is only being formed - in 2013 around 100 electric cars were sold throughout the country.
At the beginning of 2014, the import duty on electric cars has been imposed, so sales will amount to about 500 units, Mitsubishi Motors CEO in Russia Andrey Pankov predicts.
But the five-fold growth does not make electric cars any noticeable: in 2013, according to the European Business Association, 2.78 million light and light commercial cars were sold in Russia.
For the time being, only Mitsubishi Motors imports electric vehicles to Russia.
Renault is preparing to start imports - the company focuses primarily on corporate customers, says Renault Director for Strategic Planning and Partnerships in Russia Nicolas Remis.
The majority of other electric transport manufacturers have taken a forward-looking stance towards Russia.
The development of electric cars is also at the Russian manufacturers - ", GAZ, "", but the production is negligible.
For example, in January-July 2014, according to ASM Holding, AutoVAZ produced 30 electric cars.
The demand is low due to the cost of electric cars, admits the director of "AvtoVAZ" for engineering Sergey Amanov, without state support there will be no breakthrough in this segment....

The development of the Russian electric car market in addition to the cost of cars (the electric cars that are sold in Russia, on average twice as expensive as the analogues with internal combustion engines) is holding back the development of charging infrastructure (fuel - units), says Sergey Tzelikov, CEO of Autostata.

Due to the high cost and low rates of lowering the cost of electric cars in the next 3-4 years will remain the bottom segment of the Russian market, forecasts the editor-in-chief of "Avtorevyu" Mikhail Porodhansky, Celikov agrees with him.
Car manufacturers, on the contrary, say that some models of electric cars are already close to the normal cost.

The Russian electric car market has good prospects, the main thing is to build confidence in consumers that "electric mobility" is real; this, in particular, will be promoted by the emergence of all new charging stations, stresses the president of the BMW Group in Russia Wolfgang Schlimme.
Such infrastructure projects are implemented, for example, by the state company Rosnets: several stations have been built in Moscow, and soon there will be about 80 more.
Negotiations on the construction of the gasoline network are also conducted with other regions.

According to Vladimir Sofia, director of Rosnety department, the company believes in the electric car market and is ready to build filling stations throughout the country, but there are also problems: a small number of electric cars in the country and the absence of a single standard for charging electric cars of different brands.
In addition, Rosnet as a network company does not have the right to sell electricity, the possibility to do this in relation to charging electric cars is being studied.
Pankov believes that the most effective measure of state support for the formation of the electric vehicle market in Russia is the imposition of customs duties.
The zero rate will be in effect until the end of 2014, the possibility of extending it and expanding the preferential list is being studied.
Replacing the transport tax with environmental (the idea is discussed and concerns all cars) will also support the market, but not as tangible as customs preferences, Pankov believes.
Transportation tax in Russia is small, says Pankov, unlike, for example, Norway, where the tax reduction led to a sharp increase in sales of electric cars - now they account for 12% of the market.

In Russia there are also incentive measures for car owners, such as free parking in the city center (as already done in Moscow), Pankov believes, or the possibility of moving electric cars on defined lanes, which in Russia does not yet exist.

News Economics — Will Kiev compensate Rosneft for $140 million losses?
Head of Rosneft Igor Sechin stated that the company estimates the damage from the shooting of the Lischansky refinery in Ukraine at $140 million.
He reported this in an interview with Spiegel.
"We estimate the damage at $140 million and will negotiate with the Ukrainian government for compensation," said Sechin.
According to him, the modernized Lissachinsky Refinery was scheduled to be put into operation in 2014.
However, part of the factory was destroyed by Ukrainian artillery.
"There were no fights, there were no 'buried insurgents', but the Ukrainian artillery destroyed part of the industrial facility.
In addition, the technological oil that has been pumped into the pipes has been lost,” he said.
Recall, on July 18 in connection with the shooting of Lischansky refinery the oil storage tank burned and the buildings of two warehouses were destroyed.
Lischansky Refinery is the main oil refinery in Ukraine, the first stage of the enterprise was put into operation in October 1976.
The total capacity of the Lisichan refinery is about 7 million tons of oil raw material per year.
The plant is capable of producing Euro-4 fuel as well as Euro-5 diesel.

It was decided to start repairs at the plant.
A year later, Rosneft acquired Lischansky Refinery together with other Ukrainian assets of TNK-BP.

Twitter tried to become more interesting for new users
Twitter's microblogging service has changed the process of registering users to involve new participants more quickly in active interaction with the platform.
This measure should reduce the number of people who dropped their microbiologists.
Now new Twitter users will be able to view a large number of accounts recommended by the service during registration to immediately build up their reading circle.
Recommendations are made on the basis indicated when registering interests.
At the same time, Twitter automatically sets a subscription tab for all automatically selected accounts.
Because of this, the user will have to remove the tabs manually, so that they do not read those who are not interested in them.
If before users of the microblogging service saw only avatars of recommended users, now Twitter draws a sample of one of the popular tweets of a blogger to help make an impression about a person.
This is the biggest change in the Twitter registration page in the last three years.
Recently, Twitter is actively working on the modernization of the service.
This activity is primarily linked to the continuing efforts of the service to achieve infallibility.
In 2014, the microblogging service faced a slowdown in the growth of the user base and a decline in reader activity.
At the moment, the company desperately needs more loyal customer resources, who, once entering, would stay long.

Car Recycling Program resumed on September 1
Since September 1 in Russia the program of car recycling is renewed.
By 31 December 2014 10 billion rubles will be allocated for these purposes.

As the head of the Ministry of Industry and Trade of the Russian Federation Denis Manturov explained, the money is allocated from the limits, which have already been brought to the Ministry of Industry and Trade of the Russian Federation by redistribution from other directions of support.
The program covers all cars over the age of six years.
The amount of compensation will be from 40 thousand for a car to 350 thousand rubles for a cargo.
Earlier in Russia, a similar program of vehicle disposal was already in place.

The main difference of the current project, the Minister explained, is that now it is not only the disposal of cars for obtaining a subsequent discount, but also the possibility, if the car has reached the age of more than six years, to purchase a new one with a discount when the old one is handed over to the dealer in "trade-in", Interfax reports.
The previous federal recycling program, which ran from January 1, 2010 to December 31, 2011, lost over 16 billion rubles.
Thanks to it, the level of production of cars in 2010 amounted to about 1.2 million units (plus 101.4% compared to 2009).
The creator of Coming Out Simulator will release a game about modern journalism
Game designer Nicky Case, known for the game Coming Out Simulator, decided to release a game about contemporary journalism.
He spoke about his project in an interview with Kill Screen.
Keys began work on the game a few weeks ago, but the fact became widely known only now.
The game was inspired by events in Ferguson, where protests are taking place after a policeman killed an unarmed black teenager.
The focus of the project, which has not yet been named, will be on how informational coverage of stories affects their consequences.
The hero of the game, a civilian journalist, will need to photograph what is happening in areas where clashes between police and the population take place.
The hero can photograph what is happening in different ways, which will influence the course of events.
If he shoots the scene so that the policemen look like heroes and the protesters are bandits, the police will treat him better and let him go where no ordinary person can go.
If he covers events differently, his photos can turn peaceful protests into massive riots.
Points in the game will have to be collected with the help of the hero Twitter, in which new subscribers will appear if the photos posted there will become popular.
The game has no title yet.
The date of release and the platform on which it will appear are unknown.
Keys, however, published an image showing how the event can change depending on how a photograph of it is taken and processed.

In an interview with Kill Screen, Case explained that he had been thinking about the concept of such a game for a long time, but initially wanted to devote it to events in the Gaza Strip, not to protests in the United States.
After he began collecting material for the game, the game designer realized that he lacked knowledge and skills to cover the history of the region.
However, when he saw the media covering events in Ferguson, he decided to make a game based on what happened.
Nicky Case is an independent developer who produces browser games.
His most famous project was Coming Out Simulator, released in 2014.
This game, which tells about events from Case's own biography, is devoted to how a bisexual teenager tries to tell about his relationship with gay parents.

Tony Stewart's return to the track ended a little more than halfway through the race at Atlanta Motor Speedway.
Stewart crashed into the wall for the second time after his right front tire broke off in 172 laps, putting an end to his performance.
Stewart brought his broken car to the garage and then left without talking to the reporters.
Chairman of his team Chad Johnston said that 14 members of the team were upset, but will now focus on the race for the next weekend in Richmond, Virginia.
"I would like to have a more successful attempt and a more successful finish for him," Johnston said.

Stewart first crashed into a wall earlier in the race Sunday evening after a collision with Kyle Bush, which required repairs to the right side of his car.
"I started today with quite a lot of hope to come to the finish successfully," said Johnston, adding, "It just didn't work out."

The Army Controls Thailand’s New Government
General Prayut (right) appointed the Minister of Defence of the Republic of Yugoslavia, Mr. Yorit Wangsuan (left)

Thailand's military governor and prime minister, General Prayut Chan-Ocha, announced the composition of the country's new cabinet, in which more than a third of the posts are held by generals or retired generals.
Representatives of the army received key positions: Ministers of Defence, Finance, Foreign Affairs and Trade.

On Monday, Prayut Chan-Ocha was officially confirmed as Prime Minister following the King of Thailand's official approval of the appointment of the Chief of the Temporary Military Government to the post.
The 60-year-old soldier who took power in the country as a result of the May 22 bloody coup was the only candidate for the prime minister's post.
He was elected Prime Minister at a parliamentary session.
Earlier the army appointed deputies of parliament.
According to Prayuta Chan-Ocha, the coup was the only way to maintain stability.
He was preceded by six months of demonstrations, during which protesters demanded the resignation of Prime Minister Yinglak Chinawat's government.
Officially, Prayut Chan-Ocha will be the provisional prime minister, as the military plans to hold general elections at the end of 2015.
However, there are fears that the military are trying to strengthen their power in the country.
The military came to power on May 22
against the backdrop of a complete paralysis of civil power.
The leaders of the main political parties were temporarily arrested.
Immediately after the military came to power, they temporarily arrested the country's leading politicians, including Prime Minister Yiinglyk Chinawat.
Some journalists and public figures were also detained.
The current political crisis is rooted in 2006, when the army removed Prime Minister's brother Yiinglyk Chinawat Taksin.
Both are popular among the rural population, especially in the northern regions of the country, which has ensured them success in elections many times.
However, many representatives of the middle class and the capital elite joined the anti-government movement, which has virtually paralysed the country since November 2013.

The exchange rate of the dollar rose on the MМВB above 37 rubles on news about the preparations by the West of new sanctions against Russia.
This is a new historical record.

The dollar by "morning" settlements at 10:29 msk rose by 26.9 kunas and was 37.02 roubles, the exchange rate of the euro rose by 30 kunas - up to 48.73 roubles, according to the data of the Moscow Exchange.
The bi-currency basket grew by 28 копеек to the level of the previous closing and cost 42.28 rubles.
Before the events in Crimea, the dollar reached its peak on February 19, 2009 - at that time it cost 36.43 rubles, and on March 3, 2014, it was already 37.005 rubles.

On the night of August 29, the White House reported that US President Barack Obama and German Chancellor Angela Merkel are discussing the possibility of introducing additional sanctions against Russia.
The weakening of the ruble has a long-term character, both in pairs with the euro and in pairs with the dollar.
The long-term forecast assumed this mark, - says senior analyst of "Alpari" Anna Bodrova.
Everything related to Ukraine will be reflected in the courses.
As long as this continues, investors will react.
Today the rumours about the invasion of troops have not been confirmed by any party, but the market has proved very emotional.
All the talks that he was resilient to such news yesterday were overwritten.
The week, according to the specialist's forecasts, will close around these levels - 36.90 and 37.05 rubles per dollar.
The tax period is over, oil prices are weak, politics, sanctions, the problem of gas transit through Ukraine are all linked to one chain.
Inflation growth is also forecast: the current prices for the autumn will increase from 5 to 10%.
Soon, moreover, seasonal vegetables and fruits will be finished, and a vacuum will arise as the networks reorient to other suppliers.
"The dollar approached the mark in 37 rubles, passed it and returned back, there is no strong hysteria, - commented the head of the market analysis department "Opening Broker" Konstantin Bushov.
They will still be watching whether the promised sanctions will be imposed on Saturday, how NATO will settle.

The ruble, according to him, weakened sharply after the end of the tax season, then there was news about Ukraine, moreover, the Central Bank last week stated that until the end of the year completely moves to a floating rate and refuses any currency interventions.
If you look at the daily fluctuation, it was no different from the previous ones during this month, all was scared by the mark in 37 rubles, - continues the analyst.
And so, in terms of turnover nothing powerful happened.

The troubled times for the currency market were, I remember, when there was an increased demand for currency at the end of January, and also on March 3, when the Central Bank shipped a record amount of currency.
The UFS IC also sees the positive side of the weakening of the ruble.

First of all, it is an increase in the revenue part of the budget from export operations, as well as an increase in the competitiveness of domestic producers due to the increase in imports, says UFS IC chief analyst Alexey Kozlov.
Negative points can be attributed to the increase in imports of goods and services.

The sharp fluctuations in the Russian currency significantly reduce the attractiveness of investments in the Russian economy, provoke an increase in inflationary pressure and, as a consequence, become a cause of higher borrowing money, which in turn, hampers the development of the country’s economy.
Speaking of the stock market, the depreciation of the ruble slightly aggravates the decline in share prices expressed in ruble.
For example, the MICEX Index declined by 1.67% on Thursday, while the RTS Index lost 3.27%.
The significant difference in the relative magnitude of the index decline is due to the weakening of the ruble over the day by more than 1.5%.
The weakening of the ruble has an emotional character and is explained by the massive desire to buy the currency.
As practice shows, emotions gradually disappear, and ruble quotes partially or completely restore lost positions.
"We believe that soon we will be able to see the ratio of the dollar and the Russian currency near the level of 36 rubles per dollar," - says Alexey Kozlov.
Genetic disorders are often misdiagnosed
Brittany said that she had spent many years thinking she would die after an incorrect diagnosis.
Carolyn Rogers spent much of her teenage years thinking that she had only a few years to live after being diagnosed with another disease.
In fact, she had Sharco-Mari-Tuta disease (SMT) - a group of hereditary disorders that cause damage to nerves outside the brain and spinal cord.
The charity CMT UK reported that misdiagnosis is a common problem among people with MS because so little is known about the condition.
Approximately 23,000 people in the UK are believed to have MMT, which can cause motor symptoms such as muscle weakness, uncertain walking, and stiff toes.
Patients may experience vomiting or pain, and the condition does not heal and progress, which means that symptoms increase over time.
When Rogers was 13 years old, she thought she was suffering from the attack of Frederick (A.F.) - a condition for which the prognosis was very bad.
Rogers thought she would be kneaded to the wheelchair by the time she was 18 and would die before she was 30.
The mother of two children, now 51, said, "As a child, I knew I couldn't do what the others did.
I was falling every day, and I had more time for everything.
I had never been able to ride rollercoaster or skateboard with other children, and I had to wear a lot of clothes at school because I was walking and running.

Rogers said that when she was 13, after several operations to release the Achilles tendon and straighten her feet, she looked at the medical card when her doctor came out of the room and there was written that she had AFS.

"I felt guilty because my nose was dry where it shouldn't be, and so I didn't tell anyone, but I went home, found information about this condition in the library and wrote to the Association of AF," she said.
When I received the information in response, I was shocked and experienced the worst panic possible.
I thought that I would be in a wheelchair at 18 and die before I turned 25, and that I would gradually lose all my abilities in that period.
I went through it alone, and I planned my own funeral.
She said that by the time she was 17, she realized that her ability to walk had not deteriorated as much as she thought, and asked her doctor about it.
He simply got up, hugged me and said, "My dear, I don't think you have this disease, because you would already be in a wheelchair."
I think you have something that represents a much smaller threat to life.
After several genetic tests, she was diagnosed with FMT.
"When he explained what SMT was, I thought I pulled out a happy ticket," she said.
The UK-based charity SMT announced a month of information on SMT to try to raise awareness of the disease.
Tax burden on entrepreneurs of Washington area grows as the economy recovers
The emerging economy means more customers, more sales, and more jobs.
This also means higher taxes.

State and local tax accounts for companies across the country increased moderately last year, as economic recovery accelerated, according to a new study published last week, and companies in the Washington area are no exception.
Companies in the county, Maryland, and Virginia paid $27.6 billion to state and local governments in fiscal 2013, 3.8 percent more than $26.6 billion collected in 2012.

Tax burdens on businesses at both state and local level increased by 4.3 percent last year, to $671 billion, compared to 3.9 percent a year earlier, and this was the third consecutive year of growth after consecutive years of declining accounts in 2009 and 2010.

Taxes levied by the state increased faster, 4.3 percent, than local taxes, 3.9 percent, according to a study conducted by a professional services firm, Ernst & Young, and the State Taxation Center, a tax policy group.
More than half of the county's tax revenues, 56 percent, are taxed on entrepreneurs, while 36 percent of Maryland's tax revenues are taxed on firms.
Virginia, with 28 percent, brings the lowest amount of tax revenues, proportionally, from entrepreneurs.

To a large extent, the increase in tax revenues is due to the return to the remaining value of real estate companies, say researchers, that raised real estate taxes by 3.7 percent this year after three years in a row, when the growth was less than 1 percent.
While most of these revenues come from larger states such as California, New York, and Texas, it appears the same is happening in the Washington area.

Companies in the county, Maryland, and Virginia collectively paid $10 billion in state and local property taxes last year, $9.6 billion more than in 2012, an increase of 4.2 percent compared to the previous year.

However, the observed return on real estate does not have any similar effect on the growth of state and local tax revenues in Maryland, where real estate taxes barely exceed one fifth of corporate tax accounts.
Companies in Virginia and the District of Columbia pay about half of their state and local tax bills in real estate taxes.

"What's happening in Maryland is that so much of their real estate, especially the tax base around the District of Columbia, belongs to either the government or a non-profit organization that doesn't pay real estate taxes," said Douglas Lindholm, executive director of the state's Taxation Center.
Thus, Maryland is forced to rely much more, for example, on income taxes to pay for the same services that exist in other states.
The recent increase in tax revenues from entrepreneurs cannot be fully explained by the recovery of the real estate market.
Entrepreneurs’ incomes also seem to be improving, according to the data.
Companies in the region reported a state-level corporate income tax of $2.3 billion, an increase of $2.1 billion from 2012.
Maryland collected $1 billion in corporate income tax revenues, the largest in the region.
Although trends are in the same direction, the tax burden of entrepreneurs at the local level is not increasing at the same rate in all three localities.
The growth rate in the District of Columbia was at the same level as the average in the country, 4.3 percent, whereas growth in Maryland was significantly faster, 4.9 percent.
In Virginia alone, tax revenues rose below the average of 4.1 percent.
In Virginia there was the lowest corporate income tax of three jurisdictions (each with the same corporate rate), equal to 6 percent.
In Maryland the corporate rate is 8.25 percent, whereas in the county it is relatively high - 9.975 percent.

A similar US Chamber of Commerce study earlier this year showed that Virginia has lower taxes for entrepreneurs at state and local level and, overall, a more favourable tax climate for entrepreneurs than Maryland.
The county was not assessed in this study.
Despite its advantage, Virginia is under competitive pressure from its southern neighbour.
North Carolina recently signed legislation reducing corporate rates this year from 6.9 percent to 6 percent, as in Virginia, and the rate will fall to 5 percent next year.
If the state continues to meet its tax revenue targets next year, this law could raise the income tax rate for entrepreneurs even to 3 percent by 2017.
Meanwhile, small businesses in the Washington area seem to feel better and thus pay more taxes on the state and local level, according to a recent study.

Taxes on entrepreneurs paid in the form of an individual income tax by small business owners – the transitional structure under which most small businesses operate – in the Districts of Columbia, Maryland, and Virginia increased by 20 percent last year to $2.4 billion, at a much faster rate than taxes on entrepreneurs in general.

Researchers say that the trend and increase in business tax revenues across the country is likely to continue this year, with revenues from turnover taxes in state and local governments rising by 6.2 percent in the first three quarters of 2014 compared to the same period last year.
However, the Washington area may lag behind, as federal spending cuts affect the labor market in the region.
Bronze Age of Russian judo
The domestic judo world championship brought to the national team of Russia two silver and seven bronze awards.
On this indicator the Russians lost only the main favorite of competitions - the national team of Japan.
The tournament in Chelyabinsk started on Monday, and the first day brought the Russian team a silver medal.
Its owner became Beslan Mudranov, who acted in the category to 60 kg.
At the same time in the same final wrestling with Boldбаатар Ганбат from Mongolia the outcome of the confrontation decided only one remark, received by the Russian.
And here the second day of tournament became the most successful for the national team of Russia - on Tuesday were won immediately three medals.
In men's competitions in the category to 66 kg silver went to Mikhail Poyalev, and bronze - Kamal Khan-Magomedov.
In the final duel, the Russian lost to the 2011 and 2013 world champion Masashi Ebinome.
Khan-Magomedov, in the quarterfinal stage losing to his compatriot, won the consolation tournament and became the holder of the bronze award.
In the women's tournament of the category to 52 kg also to the third step of the podium of honour arrived Natalia Kuzyutin.

In the semi-final she lost the current world champion Mailind Kelmendi from Kosovo, who at this championship acted under the flag of the International Federation of Judo and successfully defended the title.
In the dispute for bronze Kuzutina won at Ma Inan from China, but after the end of tournament still admitted that the third place - it is not at all what she expected.
And again the obstacle on the way of the Russian to gold was Kelmendi, who defeated Kuzyutin earlier in the final of the European championship.
On the third day of tournament in Chelyabinsk the bronze in the cup of the national team of Russia put Musa Mogushkov, fighting in category to 73 kg.
In the quarter-finals his opponent became former representative of Moldova Viktor Skovortsov, now playing for the UAE team.
But then the Russian won two fights and became the winner of the award.
Mogyshkov performed at the home championship with the injury of a holenop, which he plans to relieve in the near future, so and will take a break in competitions.
As for the former Moldovan Skvortsov, he and he at this tournament reached the bronze medal.
Interestingly, that another of his compatriots, who accepted sports citizenship of the UAE, Ivan Remarenko with bronze finished the performance in category to 100 kg.
The fourth day of the M-2014 also brought to the Russians one bronze, which in the category to 81 kg won Ivan Nifontov.
In the final he defeated the Frenchman Alan Schmitt.
On Friday at the tournament three sets of awards were played at once, but Russians by tradition were limited to one bronze in the men's tournament to 90 kg.
Its owner was Kirill Questions, and the national team of Russia this medal was guaranteed: his opponent on the comforting final was his compatriot Kirill Denisov.
However, the match did not take place: Questionov's opponent was unable to get on the tatami due to an injury.
Men's bronze was won by the owners and on the sixth day of competitions - it was placed in the coupling of the national team by Renat Saidov, who acted in category over 100 kg.
In the final, he won a clear victory over Brazilian David Moura.
Thus ended the individual part of world superiority.
On the last day of tournament in Chelyabinsk, on Sunday, titles of world champions in team competitions were played.

Both Russian national teams - both male and female - were one of the main applicants for awards, but, as in individual competitions, representatives of the beautiful sex did not get lucky - to the medal they did not reach.
And here the Russian judoists won the team silver.
In decisive confrontation they in persistent wrestling with the score 2-3 lost to the main favorites of competitions - the team of Japan.
At the same time the national team of Russia led 2-0 after a clean victory of Khan-Magomedov and willful - Denis Yartsev (weight to 73 kg).
However, in the heavier weight categories with their Japanese rivals were not able to cope Murat Khachatiyev (81), Mahomed Magomedov (90) and Aslan Kambiyev (100).
On the same scenario developed and bronze match in the women's tournament, where the Russian national team, leading 2-0, lost to the Japanese - 2-3.
At the team competitions in Chelyabinsk was the President of Russia Vladimir Putin, who after the end of tournament congratulated the men's national team with silver.
"The second place - it is very honorable, but I want to say that it was obvious that you could become champions, - said Putin, whose words are quoted by RIA Novosti.
To lose to the Japanese, the natives of judo - there is nothing sinister here.
But I am sure that you can win with them.
The Russian national team at the home world championship performed much better than a year ago at competitions of the same level, held in Rio de Janeiro.
Then in the asset of the Russian team there were only three medals - one silver and two bronze.
At the same time the current tournament was missed by the Olympic champions Arsen Galstyan and Mansur Isayev.
We are all, of course, great maximalists.
Yes, I want gold medals.
But let us remember that if a person in the Olympic cycle is in the eighth strongest, then he is a potential winner of the Olympics.

Even more in such a form of sports as judo", - summed up the results of tournament the Minister of Sports of the Russian Federation Vitaly Mutko, the words of which the press service of the championship brings.
Japan's national team was expected to be the best in Chelyabinsk, winning 11 medals of different dignity, five of which turned out to be gold.
The next World Cup will be held in the summer of next year in Astana.

All the kings will be able
The debut album of the band Royal Blood - a new hope of British rock, brought rock duo from clubs straight to stadiums is on sale.

The Royal Blood duo has been on stage for a year, but already has an active nomination for the BBC Music Award, a warm-up tour with the Arctic Monkeys, and a visit to a New York gig by Jimmy Page himself.
Their debut album of the same name received 100,000 pre-orders a few months before its release, and the contract for its release is in the portfolio of Warner Music.

Given the current appalling situation on the music market, the situation is out of the row, after all it is not about a new Lane Del Rey or another sweet voice of the representative of "new R'n'B", but about a duet of British-looking cowboys playing with the same level of volume and intensity that last time was in fashion a couple of decades ago.
Overall, bets on the first album were particularly high due to all the above circumstances and were already well justified.
The Duet had taken for granted a name which had not been claimed by even desperate hairy metalists before, and the blood of which kings seemed to be flowing in their homes was also understandable.
This is, of course, primarily about the heroes of the previous level Led Zeppelin: like the big quartet, Royal Blood set their goal to stir up the blood of British rock, taking it to a new height.
It is perhaps premature to make predictions about the success of this enterprise yet, but something can already be affirmed.
Ten songs laid down in thirty minutes is not so much a demonstration of the phenomenal talent of the composer as a confident and powerful declaration of intent.

Some of the merits of the individual numbers, of course, cannot be denied: let's say, the pilot single "Out Of The Black" is characterized by what is remembered not by a melodic line, but by a drum part.
The musicians joke that this song is easier to sing than to drink.
It is also worth highlighting the powerful "Little Monster" and the closing track "Better Strangers" with a Shakespeare quote in the title.
However, the truth is that each of these songs will sound great at a party of heavy rock lovers, but when played consecutively they merge into more or less homogeneous painting.
And this is not necessarily bad, even the opposite.

Royal Blood's strength lies in the fact that they do not claim the laurels of the new Lennon and McCartneys (they soon become Motörhead's successors), but have brought numerous rock duo from the ghettos of the indie clubs.
Their music, despite some diversity, is created for stadiums, in a space designed for fewer than a couple of thousand people, it is clearly close.
The secret is partly in the cunning use of the bass, replacing the guitar in the usual format, invented at the beginning of the zero The White Stripes.
However, it is not only about the instruments, but also about the very approach to the composition of songs.

The heroes of the retrorock of the zeroes were chosen with great difficulty outside the postmodern paradigm, with great reluctance to recognize themselves not simply as epigons, but as independent creative units.
Royal Blood already sounds so powerful and aggressive that this effort successfully drags some secondaryness and hardness of the music material.
And finally, who said that rock should be smart?
Amazon buys Twitch for $1.04 billion

AMAZON has just confirmed what Information reported on Friday morning: The online store - and the video producer, and a hundred other things - buys the streaming video reproduction service Twitch for $1.04 billion ($US970 million).
This news came as a surprise, not because no one expected Twitch to be sold, but because many expected YouTube to be a buyer.
Three months ago the sale of Twitch to Google video service for a good billion looked completely ready, and such a combination seemed natural.
Twitch, founded just three years ago as Justin.tv, set out to be a streaming service of a general nature - a real-time version of YouTube.
Instead, it quickly turned into a platform where gamers broadcast their in-game moments; "YouTube for real-time games," according to Business Insider.
Twitch interface.
And "let's play", the genre of video clips in which allies give (mostly old) games processing, as in "Mystery Theater", are already popular on YouTube.

The fact is that YouTube is often mentioned when describing Twitch, so the news that YouTube acquires Twitch was met with little interest, a classic example of an incumbent technology company buying a potential competitor.
It is a mystery why the deal with YouTube failed, given that, according to the information, he was willing to pay no less than Amazon.

All we have at the moment is a statement from Twitch CEO Emmet Shire: "We chose Amazon because they believe in our community, they share our values and long-term goals, and they want to help us achieve them faster."
Another secret, frankly, is the incredible success of Twitch.

Snowballers like me, who claim that they will be better engaged in sports than watching it, it is difficult to understand the attractiveness of watching games instead of taking in the hand of a chess player.
One thing is to watch through a friend's shoulder at 3 a.m. when she crawls through Resident Evil, and quite another is to watch as some outsider gets 20 shots in the head in a row in Call of Duty.
All the games that you could watch right now.

Another problem is that many of the most popular games today are designed for one person, so watching them without controlling the angle of vision on your own can be a recipe for headaches worthy of Do It Right.
I agree that the high-speed walks in which Rogers Bannister of our electronic age finish whole games in record time are entertaining.
But if it's not about the virtuosity of the game or humor, it's unlikely that his Twitch channel will be interesting at all.
But what do skeptics like me know?
Twitch has 55 million unique visitors a month, and is the fourth largest source of peak internet traffic.
How exactly will Amazon make money on this?
It is hard to imagine that Twitch will turn into Amazon Instant Video as elegantly as YouTube could simply absorb Twitch.
However, Twitch has something that any company would be happy to receive: crowds of young men that advertisers dream of.
As head of Twitch Shire said, Amazon and Twitch "both believe in the future of games", and this channel does not show signs of enthusiasm, even - oh - as a spectacular sport.

North Korea has launched a small-range missile into the waters of the Japanese Sea, reports "Renhap".

Deputies propose to speed up the entry into force of the law on personal data
In case of success of the initiative, Russian data will not be stored on servers abroad from January 1, 2015
The State Duma has introduced a draft law that provides for the date of entry into force of the already adopted law on Russians' personal data - from September 1, 2016 to January 1, 2015.
The initiative is based on the legislative activity of the lower chamber.
Its authors were deputies of the State Duma Vadim Daygin, Yaroslav Nilov (LDPR), Yevgeny Fedorov (United Russia), Vladimir Parakin (Just Russia) and Alexander Yushchenko (CPRF).

Such a change, in the opinion of the authors of the initiative, will contribute to more efficient and effective provision of the rights of citizens of the Russian Federation on the preservation of personal data and observance of the secret of correspondence in information and telecommunication networks.
The law, whose entry into force is rushed by parliamentarians, obliges to store in the territory of the Russians personal data processed through the Internet.

It also makes mandatory the recording, systematication, accumulation, storage, refinement and extraction of personal data of Russian citizens in databases located in the territory of Russia, as well as the indication of the location of such databases.
In addition, the law gives Roskomnadzor the right to restrict access to information processed in violation of the Russian legislation in the field of personal data on the basis of a court decision.
The law also proposes the creation of so-called "black lists" of violators sites - an automated information system "Register of violators of the rights of personal data subjects".
This law was adopted by the State Duma in the summer.
The bill was drafted by Andrei Lugova and Vadim Daygin of the PLDP and Alexander Yushchenko of the CPRF.
Daggin and Yushchenko are also among the authors of the current bill on the postponement of the date of entry into force of the already adopted law.
Those who do not have data centers in the Russian Federation will have to pay for rent

Commenting on the bill introduced to the State Duma today, the first deputy head of the Duma Committee on Information Policy Leonid Levin stated that he does not see problems for the date of entry into force of the law on the protection of personal data.

According to him, those companies that by January 1, 2015 will not have their own personal data stores of Russians in the territory of the Russian Federation, will be able to rent them, for example, "to Rostelecom", which repeatedly said that they are ready to provide their servers for rent and already provides their servers, to Mail Group, to Western companies, which today already provide their servers".
“At the same time, there are several independent data centers ready to cooperate in this area,” he added.

"If companies decide to comply with the law and continue to work in the territory of the Russian Federation, I see no problems - they will receive technological opportunities for placement," - concluded Levin.
The controversial bill

Immediately after the publication of the draft law, the Russian Association of Electronic Communications expressed concern that if the bill is passed, Russians will no longer be able to use many global internet services.
In particular, it is about the services of online booking of flights and hotels.

According to the association, "the draft law deprives subjects of personal data - citizens of the Russian Federation of the right to dispose of their own data by emphatically determining that their recording, systematization, etc. should be provided only in databases located in the territory of the Russian Federation".

The RAEC statement emphasizes that a more effective measure would be the creation of a mechanism for informing the user where the recording is taking place, and the systematization of his personal data.
In this case, he or she will be able to choose on which territory the above-mentioned actions will be carried out.
The adoption of similar bills on the "localization" of personal data in other countries has led to the abandonment of global services and to significant economic losses.
The participant of the test of the ice water wind blows out the jaw

Isabelle Roberts cried so loudly when ice water was poured on her head that it damaged the structure of her face.

Isabel Roberts in a second before the accident
